Summary 0:
Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 on the harmonisation of markets in financial instruments
SUMMARY
The Capital Markets Union (CMU) project aims to create a single market for capital in the European Union (EU) in order to provide businesses with the finance they need to develop and create jobs. This Regulation aims to establish a harmonised approach to marketing communications for both alternative investment funds (AIFs) and undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS). It also aims to address the issue of the cross-border distribution of such funds.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out requirements for marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS.
It also establishes common principles concerning fees or charges for supervisory and investigatory powers for competent authorities, and a central database for cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS.
It sets out rules on pre-marketing for qualifying venture capital funds and qualifying social entrepreneurship funds.
KEY POINTS
Marketing communications
Marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS must be identifiable as such and describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. They must also include information on the risks and rewards of such investment in a prominent manner.
In addition, all information included in marketing communications addressed to investors must be presented in a manner that is fair, clear and not misleading. To ensure a level playing field between AIFs and UCITS, the standards for marketing communications apply to marketing communications of AIFs and UCITS.
Common principles concerning fees or charges
By 2 February 2020, competent authorities must publish and maintain up-to-date information on their websites listing the fees or charges levied by the competent authorities for supervision of cross-border activities.
ESMA central database on cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS
By 2 February 2022, ESMA must publish on its website a central database on cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS, publicly accessible in a language customary in the sphere of international finance, listing:
all AIFs that are marketed in a Member State other than the home Member State, their AIFM, EuVECA manager or EuSEF manager, and the Member States in which they are marketed; and
all UCITS that are marketed in a Member State other than the UCITS home Member State, their AIFM, EuVECA manager or EuSEF manager, and the Member States in which they are marketed.
The database must be kept up to date.
Ex-ante verification of marketing communications
AIFMs, EuVECA managers, EuSEF managers and UCITS management companies must ensure that all marketing communications addressed to investors are identifiable as such and describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or units of a UCITS in an equally prominent manner, and that all information included in marketing communications is fair, clear and not misleading.
By 2 February 2021, ESMA must issue guidelines, and thereafter update those guidelines periodically, on the application of the requirements for marketing communications, taking into account on-line aspects of such marketing communications.
By 2 February 2021, competent authorities must publish on their websites the hyperlinks to the websites of competent authorities where the information referred to in the first paragraph of this point is published.
By 2 February 2022, ESMA must publish on its website a central database on cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS, publicly accessible in a language customary in the sphere of international finance, listing:
all AIFs that are marketed in a Member State other than the home Member State, their AIFM, EuVECA manager or EuSEF manager, and the Member States in which they are marketed; and
all UCITS that are marketed in a Member State other than the UCITS home Member State as defined in point (e) of Article 2(1) of Directive 2009/65/EC, their UCITS management company and the Member States in which they are marketed.
The database must be kept up to date.
Pre-marketing
A manager of a qualifying venture capital fund may engage in pre-marketing in the Union, except where the information presented to potential investors:
is sufficient to allow investors to commit to acquiring units or shares of a particular qualifying venture capital fund;
amounts to subscription forms or similar documents whether in a draft or a final form; or
amounts to constitutional documents, a prospectus or offering documents of a not-yet-established qualifying venture capital fund in a final form.
By 2 February 2021, ESMA must issue guidelines, and thereafter update those guidelines periodically, on the application of the requirements for pre-marketing, taking into account on-line aspects of such pre-marketing.
By 2 February 2021, competent authorities must publish on their websites the hyperlinks to the websites of competent authorities where the information referred to in the first paragraph of this point is published.
By 2 February 2022, ESMA must publish on its website a central database on cross-border marketing of AIFs and UCITS, publicly accessible in a language customary in the sphere of international finance, listing:
all AIFs that are marketed in a Member State other than the home Member State, their AIFM, EuVECA manager or EuSEF manager, and the Member States in which they are marketed; and
all UCITS that are marketed in a Member State other than the UCITS home Member State as defined in point (e) of Article 2(1) of Directive 2009/65/EC, their UCITS management company and the Member States in which they are marketed.
The database must be kept up to date.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 2 August 2017.
BACKGROUND
This Regulation aims to establish a harmonised approach to marketing communications for both alternative investment funds (AIFs) and undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS). It also aims to address the issue of the cross-border distribution of such funds.
For more information, please see the European Commission website.
KEY TERMS
AIF: alternative investment fund.
UCITS: undertaking for collective investment in transferable securities.
MAIN DOCUMENT

Summary 1:
Ensuring safe products on the EU market
SUMMARY
The Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 sets out the rules for ensuring safe products on the EU market. It covers all products, except food, feed, medicinal products, living plants and animals, products of human origin and products of plants and animals relating directly to their future reproduction.
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out the tasks of economic operators, such as manufacturers, importers and distributors. It also defines the powers and obligations of the national market surveillance authorities.
Economic operators have a role in ensuring that products placed on the market comply with the EU rules and regulations. The tasks of economic operators include:
checking whether the products they place on the market comply with the EU rules and regulations;
keeping the contact details of other economic operators up to date;
cooperating with the authorities in charge of the control on products entering the EU market.
The regulation sets out the powers and obligations of the national market surveillance authorities. The authorities have the power to:
perform appropriate checks on the characteristics of products on an adequate scale, by means of documentary checks and, where appropriate, physical and laboratory checks based on adequate samples;
take appropriate measures in the event of a product posing a risk to health or safety;
cooperate with each other and the authorities in charge of the control on products entering the EU market.
The regulation also sets out the powers of the authorities in charge of the control on products entering the EU market. These authorities have the power to:
perform controls on products entering the EU market;
cooperate with each other and the national market surveillance authorities.
The regulation also sets out the procedures for dealing with non-compliant products. It provides for a rapid information exchange system to alert consumers and other end users to non-compliant products and to prevent them from being placed on the EU market.

Summary 2:
Facilitating the provision of online services and retransmissions of television and radio programmes
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes a legal framework for the provision of online services and the retransmission of television and radio programmes across the EU.
KEY POINTS
This directive establishes a legal framework for the provision of online services and the retransmission of television and radio programmes across the EU.
It facilitates the provision of online services for certain types of programmes, such as news and current affairs programmes, and for certain types of programmes produced by a broadcaster, such as a broadcaster’s own productions which are exclusively financed by it.
It lays down rules for the transmission of programmes through the process of direct injection, which is a technical process by which a broadcaster transmits its programme-carrying signals to an organisation other than a broadcaster, in such a way that the programme-carrying signals are not accessible to the public during that transmission.
It simplifies the clearance of rights for the provision of online services and the retransmission of television and radio programmes across borders.
It allows agreements concluded between a collective management organisation and operators of retransmission services for rights that are subject to mandatory collective management under this directive to be extended to apply to the rights of rightholders who are not represented by that collective management organisation, without those rightholders being allowed to exclude their works or other subject matter from the application of that mechanism.
It does not oblige broadcasters to provide online services across borders or to retransmit programmes originating in other EU countries.
It is without prejudice to the contractual freedom of rightholders and broadcasting organisations to agree, in compliance with EU law, to limit the exploitation of their rights, including those under Directive 2001/29/EC.
It is without prejudice to the right of broadcasters to communicate to the public or make available to the public programmes in their online services or to provide such online services in a Member State other than the Member State of their principal establishment.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It applies from 7 June 2021.
BACKGROUND
The digital revolution has transformed the way in which television and radio programmes are distributed and accessed. Users increasingly expect to have access to television and radio programmes through traditional channels, such as satellite or cable, and also through online services.
This directive aims to facilitate the provision of online services and the retransmission of television and radio programmes across the EU.
For further information, please see the European Commission's website on the ‘digital single market’.
KEY TERMS
              
Broadcasting organisation: a body which transmits television and radio programmes intended for reception by the public.
Direct injection: a technical process by which a broadcasting organisation transmits its programme-carrying signals to an organisation other than a broadcasting organisation, in such a way that the programme-carrying signals are not accessible to the public during that transmission.
Ancillary online service: an online service which provides access to television and radio programmes in a strictly linear manner, simultaneously to the broadcast, and services that give access, within a defined time period after the broadcast, to television and radio programmes which have been previously broadcast by the broadcasting organisation, so-called ‘catch-up services’.
Retransmission: the simultaneous, unaltered and unabridged retransmission by a cable or microwave system for reception by the public of an initial transmission from another Member State, by wire or over the air, including that by satellite, of television or radio programmes intended for reception by the public.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Directive (EU) 2018/1972 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2018 establishing the procedure for the assessment of the impact of legislation on the EU audiovisual media services market and amending Directive 2010/13/EU (OJ L 329, 16.12.2018, pp. 1-11).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Directive 2014/26/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 February 2014 on collective management of copyright and related rights and multi-territorial licensing of rights in musical works for online use in the internal market (OJ L 84, 20.3.2014, pp. 72-88).
Directive 93/83/EEC of the Council of 27 September 1993 on the coordination of certain rules concerning copyright and rights related to copyright applicable to satellite broadcasting and cable retransmission (OJ L 248, 6.10.1993, pp. 15-21).

Summary 3:
Regulation (EU) 2019/1831 — the.eu country code top-level domain
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the.eu country code top-level domain (ccTLD) for the European Union (EU) and its variants in other scripts, in order to support the digital single market, to build an online EU identity and to encourage cross-border online activities.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all domain names registered under the.eu ccTLD.
The registration of domain names under the.eu ccTLD can be requested by any of the following:
a citizen of the EU, regardless of their place of residence;
a natural person who is not an EU citizen and who is a resident of an EU country;
an undertaking established in the EU;
an organisation established in the EU.
A domain name may be registered or reserved by the EU countries for their operational functions. The EU countries may also register or reserve domain names for broadly recognised geographical or geopolitical terms that affect their political or territorial organisation.
The regulation sets out the principles and procedures for the registration of domain names and the conditions for the implementation of the.eu ccTLD.
The regulation establishes the conditions for the designation and characteristics of the registry, which manages the.eu ccTLD.
The registry must be a not-for-profit organisation and must have its registered office, central administration and principal place of business within the EU.
The registry must comply with the EU data protection rules, principles and guidelines.
The registry must cooperate with the European Union Intellectual Property Office and other EU agencies with a view to combating the speculative and abusive registrations of domain names, including cyber squatting, and providing simple administrative procedures, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises.
The registry must adopt clear policies aiming to ensure the timely identification of abusive registrations of domain names and, where necessary, should cooperate with competent authorities and other public bodies relevant to cybersecurity and information security which are specifically involved in the fight against such registrations, such as national computer emergency response teams (CERTs).
The registry must provide domain holders with the possibility of transferring their domain names to another holder in accordance with the principles and procedures on the functioning of the.eu ccTLD.
The registry must set up and manage, with due diligence, a WHOIS database facility for the purpose of ensuring the security, stability and resilience of the.eu ccTLD by providing accurate and up-to-date registration information about the domain names under the.eu ccTLD.
The registry must be designated by the European Commission following a selection procedure.
The Commission may request information from the registry to ensure that the principles and procedures on the functioning of the.eu ccTLD are respected.
The Commission may convey specific instructions to the registry for correcting or improving the organisation, administration and management of the.eu ccTLD.
The Commission may consult the.eu Multistakeholder Advisory Group and other relevant stakeholders and may seek expert advice on the results of the supervisory activities provided for in this regulation and on ways to improve the organisation, administration and management of the.eu ccTLD by the registry.
The regulation sets out the conditions for the supervision of the registry by the Commission.
The Commission shall designate an entity as the registry following the completion of the procedure referred to in the regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 19 October 2019.
BACKGROUND
The rapid evolution of the TLD market and the dynamic digital landscape require a future-proof and flexible regulatory environment.
The.eu ccTLD is one of the largest ccTLDs. The.eu ccTLD is used by the EU institutions, agencies and bodies, including for European projects and initiatives. The purpose of the.eu ccTLD is, through good management, to help enhance the EU identity and promote EU values online, such as multilingualism, respect for users' privacy and security and respect for human rights, as well as specific online priorities.
The regulation amends Regulation (EC) No 733/2002 to allow EU citizens to register a.eu ccTLD name, regardless of their place of residence, from 19 October 2019.

Summary 4:
Connecting Europe Facility
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE FACILITY DO?
The Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) supports key infrastructure projects in the transport, energy and digital sectors across the EU.
It aims to improve the links between Europe’s cities and villages, and boost the EU’s economy.
KEY POINTS
CEF objectives
The CEF supports projects that help to achieve the following objectives:
building, developing, modernising and completing the EU’s trans-European networks (TEN-T) in the transport, energy and digital sectors;
facilitating cross-border cooperation in the field of renewable energy;
building, developing and modernising the digital networks in the EU.
CEF budget
The CEF’s budget is €33.71 billion for the 2021-2027 period.
CEF budget for the transport sector
The CEF’s budget for the transport sector is €22.8 billion for the 2021-2027 period.
CEF budget for the energy sector
The CEF’s budget for the energy sector is €5.5 billion for the 2021-2027 period.
CEF budget for the digital sector
The CEF’s budget for the digital sector is €5.4 billion for the 2021-2027 period.
Projects of common interest
Projects of common interest (PCIs) are defined as those projects that make an important contribution to the EU’s strategic connectivity objectives. They are also projects that provide the network infrastructure supporting the digital transformation of the economy and society, as well as the EU’s Digital Single Market.
The European Commission publishes a list of projects of common interest in the field of transport, energy and digital connectivity infrastructure on its website.
Eligible actions
The CEF supports the following actions:
actions relating to projects of common interest in the transport sector;
actions relating to projects of common interest in the energy sector;
actions supporting cross-border projects in the field of renewable energy;
actions supporting operational digital platforms directly associated to transport or energy infrastructures, or both;
actions supporting the digital transformation of the economy and society.
Rules for providing funding
The CEF is implemented in direct management in accordance with the Financial Regulation. The Commission may delegate some tasks to the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Investment Fund (EIF) in accordance with the EIB Group Implementing Regulations.
The Commission establishes the work programmes for each sector in accordance with the Financial Regulation.
The Commission regularly assesses the uptake of funds for cross-border projects in the field of renewable energy against the reference amount set out in the regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
The CEF is the EU’s main financial instrument to support the development of the EU’s key infrastructure networks in the transport, energy and digital sectors.
For more information, see the European Commission’s website on the Connecting Europe Facility.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) 2021/763 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 May 2021 establishing uniformed conditions for providing financial support for the trans-European transport network and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1316/2013 (OJ L 206, 12.6.2021, pp. 1-36).

Summary 5:
Addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online — Regulation (EU) 2019/883
Addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online — Regulation (EU) 2019/883
The dissemination of terrorist content online constitutes a threat to the security and safety of persons and a risk to the democratic functioning of the Union. This Regulation aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the digital single market by addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online and by strengthening safeguards to the freedom of expression and information in an open and democratic society.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
              
It establishes a framework to ensure the identification and removal of terrorist content online, while ensuring the respect of the fundamental rights of individuals, including the freedom of expression and information, in an open and democratic society.
KEY POINTS
              
The Regulation applies to providers of information society services, such as hosting service providers, which store and disseminate to the public information and material provided by a user of the service on request, irrespective of whether the storing and dissemination to the public of such information and material is of a mere technical, automatic and passive nature.
Providers of services such as cloud infrastructure, which are provided at the request of parties other than the content providers and only indirectly benefit the latter, are not covered by this Regulation.
The Regulation does not affect the powers of national authorities and courts to establish the liability of hosting service providers where the conditions set out in Directive 2000/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council (the E-commerce Directive) for liability exemption are not met.
The Regulation does not apply to providers of audiovisual media services as defined in point (a) of Article 1(1) of Directive 2010/13/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council (the Audiovisual Media Services Directive).
The Regulation applies to providers of information society services offered in the Union irrespective of the country of their main establishment. A substantial connection to the Union should exist where the hosting service provider has an establishment in the Union, its services are used by a significant number of users in one or more Member States, or its activities are targeted towards one or more Member States.
The Regulation does not apply to providers of services such as registries and registrars, as well as providers of domain name systems (DNS), payment or distributed denial of service (DdoS) protection services, which are not covered by the scope of Directive (EU) 2018/1972 of the European Parliament and of the Council (the ePrivacy Directive).
Hosting service providers are required to remove or disable access to terrorist content in all Member States as soon as possible and in any event within one hour of receipt of a removal order.
The competent authority of the Member State where the hosting service provider has its main establishment or where its legal representative resides or is established may, on its own initiative, scrutinise the removal order to determine whether it seriously or manifestly infringes this Regulation or the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Hosting service providers may be subject to specific measures to address the risks related to the dissemination of terrorist content online. Specific measures may include, for example, the use of technical measures, such as the application of automated filters, the use of human oversight and verification, the application of human review of flagged content, the application of automated review of flagged content or the application of human review of flagged content in combination with automated review of flagged content.
The competent authority may require the adoption of additional appropriate, effective and proportionate specific measures in order to address the risks related to the dissemination of terrorist content online.
Hosting service providers are required to preserve the content for administrative or judicial review proceedings for 6 months or longer upon request from the competent authorities or courts.
Hosting service providers are required to provide the competent authorities with information on the measures taken to address the risks related to the dissemination of terrorist content online, including on the specific measures taken in response to removal orders.
Hosting service providers are required to provide the competent authorities with information on the measures taken to address the risks related to the dissemination of terrorist content online, including on the specific measures taken in response to removal orders.
Hosting service providers are required to inform the competent authorities promptly of content that contains information involving an imminent threat to life or a suspected terrorist offence.
Hosting service providers are required to designate or establish a contact point to facilitate the expeditious handling of removal orders.
Hosting service providers are required to designate in writing a legal representative in order to ensure compliance with and the enforcement of the obligations under this Regulation.
The competent authorities of the Member States are required to designate a competent authority to handle the removal orders, to designate or establish a contact point to handle requests for clarification and feedback in relation to removal orders issued by that competent authority, and to designate or establish a contact point to facilitate the expeditious handling of removal orders.
The competent authorities of the Member States are required to ensure that the competent authorities and the contact points designated or established pursuant to this Regulation are adequately resourced and staffed.
Hosting service providers are required to include in their terms and conditions provisions to address the misuse of their services for the dissemination of terrorist content.
The competent authorities of the Member States are required to ensure that the competent authorities and the contact points designated or established pursuant to this Regulation are adequately resourced and staffed.
Hosting service providers are required to include in their terms and conditions provisions to address the misuse of their services for the dissemination of terrorist content.
Hosting service providers are required to include in their terms and conditions provisions to address the misuse of their services for the dissemination of terrorist content.
Hosting service providers are required to provide the competent authorities with annual transparency reports containing information about action taken in relation to the identification and removal of terrorist content.
Hosting service providers are required to provide the competent authorities with annual transparency reports containing information about action taken in relation to the identification and removal of terrorist content.
Hosting service providers and content providers have the right to challenge removal orders before the courts of the Member State of the competent authority that issued the removal order and the right to challenge the decision pursuant to Article 4(4) or to Article 5(4), (6) or (7), before the courts of the Member State of the competent authority that took the decision.
Hosting service providers are required to ensure that the competent authorities are promptly notified of the removal or disabling of access to terrorist content.
Hosting service providers are required to ensure that the competent authorities are promptly notified of the removal or disabling of access to terrorist content.
Competent authorities are required to ensure that the competent authorities and the contact points designated or established pursuant to this Regulation are adequately resourced and staffed.
Competent authorities are required to ensure that the competent authorities and the contact points designated or established pursuant to this Regulation are adequately resourced and staffed.
Competent authorities are required to ensure that the competent authorities and the contact points designated or established pursuant to this Regulation are adequately resourced and staffed.
Hosting service providers are required to ensure that the competent authorities are promptly notified of the removal or disabling of access to terrorist content.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 17 July 2020.

Summary 6:
Horizon Europe, the EU's new research and innovation programme
SUMMARY
Horizon Europe is the EU's new research and innovation (R&I) programme for the period 2021-2027. It replaces Horizon 2020, the EU's current R&I programme, which runs until 2020.
WHAT DOES THE PROGRAMME DO?
It aims to ensure that Europe produces world-class science and innovation results and strengthens its social foundation.
It will support all stages of the R&I process, from early research to market deployment, and will work with all types of organisation from universities to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and large companies.
It will focus on key challenges, such as climate change, healthy living and demographic change, food security and sustainable agriculture, safe societies, and digitalisation and industry.
It will also support the European Research Area (ERA), a single market for research and innovation, by ensuring that scientific and technological knowledge is shared across the EU and that researchers can work together across borders.
KEY POINTS
The programme’s budget for 2021-2027 is € €95.5 billion, which is 7 % more than the budget of Horizon 2020 for the same period.
The programme is based on 3 pillars:
Excellence science: this pillar will support the best research, including through European Research Council grants, and will fund the European Institute for Innovation Technology (EIT) and the Joint Research Centre (JRC).
Breakthrough innovations: this pillar will support breakthrough innovations in areas such as health, digital and industry.
Innovative Europe: this pillar will support SMEs and large companies, as well as public sector organisations, to innovate, create new products, services and businesses and generate growth and jobs.
The programme also supports missions, which are ambitious goals over the next 10 years that aim to improve people’s lives and ensure the EU’s competitiveness in the world. These missions are:
cancer: to prevent and cure cancer by 2030;
climate change: to adapt to climate change and to achieve climate neutrality by 2050;
digital society: to empower a digital world and economy by 2030;
demographic change: to ensure growth by increasing prosperity and well-being for all;
food: to ensure healthy and safe food for all;
independence: to ensure independence and autonomy for all;
planetary health: to ensure a healthy planet for people, nature and economy by 2050;
secure societies: to ensure secure societies by 2030.
The programme will also support European Partnerships, which are strategic, long-term public-private partnerships that bring together all relevant actors and address major societal challenges.
The programme is funded by the European Union (EU) budget.
WHEN DOES THE PROGRAMME APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021 until 31 December 2027.
BACKGROUND
Horizon 2020 is the EU’s current R&I programme. It is the biggest EU research and innovation programme ever with €75 billion of funding available over 7 years (2014-2020).
Horizon Europe builds on Horizon 2020 and aims to achieve a high-impact European research and innovation performance.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s Horizon Europe website.
KEY TERMS
European Research Area
The European Research Area is a single market for research and innovation. It is based on the idea that scientific and technological knowledge should be shared across the EU and that researchers should be able to work together across borders.
Research and innovation
Research and innovation is the process of turning new ideas into innovative products and services that meet the needs of consumers and generate economic growth.

Summary 7:
The space programme of the European Union
The space programme of the European Union
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/696 on the European Union Space Programme and establishing EU Agency for the Space Programme
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the European Union (EU) Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme (EU Agency).
KEY POINTS
Scope
The EU Space Programme aims to develop Europe’s strategic autonomy and strengthen its competitiveness in the space sector.
The programme includes the Galileo, EGNOS, Copernicus, GOVSATCOM, and space surveillance and tracking (SST) components.
The EU Agency is responsible for the implementation of the EU Space Programme.
It replaces the European GNSS Agency (GSA).
It is composed of a management board and a secretariat.
The management board is composed of representatives of the EU countries, the European Commission and the European Parliament.
The secretariat is composed of a director-general and a staff.
Galileo, EGNOS, Copernicus, GOVSATCOM, and SST
Galileo is a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) that provides the European Union (EU) and its citizens with highly accurate navigation and timing across Europe and around the world.
EGNOS is a satellite navigation system that improves the accuracy of GNSSs such as the American GPS or Russian GLONASS in Europe.
Copernicus is a programme that provides reliable and accurate information to manage environmental challenges and to develop resilience to disasters.
GOVSATCOM is a programme that provides the EU and its Member States with reliable and secure space-based services for government users.
SST is a programme that aims to ensure the safety of space activities and to prevent and mitigate risks to space assets and to human life and property on Earth.
Funding
The EU Space Programme is funded through the multiannual financial framework (MFF).
The Commission will prepare a multiannual plan every 5 years, taking into account the strategic objectives of the programme.
The Commission is responsible for implementing the EU Space Programme.
It is also responsible for ensuring the programme’s security.
The Commission may entrust tasks to the EU Agency.
The EU Agency is responsible for implementing the programme and for ensuring the programme’s security.
It may entrust tasks to other entities.
The Commission may entrust tasks to other entities.
It may entrust tasks to the European Space Agency (ESA).
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
The EU Space Programme aims to develop Europe’s strategic autonomy and strengthen its competitiveness in the space sector.
Galileo, EGNOS, Copernicus, GOVSATCOM, and SST are the 5 components of the EU Space Programme.
Galileo is a GNSS that provides the EU and its citizens with highly accurate navigation and timing across Europe and around the world.
EGNOS is a satellite navigation system that improves the accuracy of GNSSs such as the American GPS or Russian GLONASS in Europe.
Copernicus is a programme that provides reliable and accurate information to manage environmental challenges and to develop resilience to disasters.
GOVSATCOM is a programme that provides the EU and its Member States with reliable and secure space-based services for government users.
SST is a programme that aims to ensure the safety of space activities and to prevent and mitigate risks to space assets and to human life and property on Earth.

Summary 8:
EU Digital Innovation Hubs
EU Digital Innovation Hubs (DIHs) support European companies in the digital transformation of their business processes and products.
EU Digital Innovation Hubs (DIHs) support European companies in the digital transformation of their business processes and products.
What are DIHs?
EU Digital Innovation Hubs (DIHs) are one-stop-shops for European companies that want to use the latest digital technologies in their products and processes. They provide companies with access to cutting-edge digital technologies, such as artificial intelligence (AI), cybersecurity and high-performance computing (HPC), and to a network of experts in digital transformation.
DIHs are coordinated by the European Commission and financed through the Digital Europe Programme (2021-2027).
What do they do?
DIHs provide European companies with the knowledge, expertise and services they need to successfully use new digital technologies in their business processes and products. They support companies from the very start of the digital transformation process through to the market launch of their new products.
DIHs help companies by:
advising them on the best digital technologies for their business;
testing their products and processes;
matching them with the right experts and partners;
providing training and education on digital technologies;
providing access to digital technologies and facilities;
supporting the digital transformation of the wider public sector.
DIHs are part of the European network of digital innovation hubs, which is coordinated by the European Commission.
How are DIHs funded?
DIHs are financed through the Digital Europe Programme (2021-2027), which has a budget of €7.6 billion. The Programme is implemented through direct management by the European Commission.
What is the Digital Europe Programme?
The Digital Europe Programme (2021-2027) aims to support the digital transformation of industry and to foster better exploitation of the industrial potential of policies on innovation, research and technological development, for the benefit of citizens and businesses across the Union, including its outermost regions and its economically disadvantaged regions.
The Programme is established for a period of 7 years to align its duration with that of the multiannual financial framework laid down in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making (13).
EU Digital Innovation Hubs are part of the European network of digital innovation hubs, which is coordinated by the European Commission.
When will the Programme start?
The Programme will start on 1 January 2021.

Digital Europe Programme
Digital Innovation Hubs
What is the Digital Single Market?
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE PROGRAMME DO?
It supports the digital transformation of industry and the take-up of results, as well as the rolling out of novel technologies and innovative solutions.
It supports the digital transformation of areas of public interest, such as healthcare, mobility, justice, earth or environmental monitoring, security, the reduction of carbon emissions, energy infrastructure, education and training, and culture.
It supports the development and acquisition of the advanced digital skills needed for the deployment of cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence (AI) or high-performance computing (HPC).

Summary 9:
Internal market programme 2021-2027
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DECISION DO?
It lays down the objectives of the EU’s Internal Market Programme for 2021-2027 (IMI), the forms of EU funding and the rules for providing such funding, and the system of governance of the programme.
KEY POINTS
WHAT DOES THE PROGRAMME SEEK TO ACHIEVE?
The programme seeks to ensure that the internal market continues to deliver benefits for all citizens and businesses in the EU.
The programme supports the development and proper functioning of the single market, in particular through:
ensuring fair competition and transparency in the market;
promoting a high level of consumer protection and financial market integration;
encouraging the development of digital and green technologies;
supporting the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
The programme is based on 3 main pillars:
creating a fair and transparent single market;
ensuring a high level of consumer protection;
supporting the competitiveness of SMEs.
The programme is one of the main drivers of the EU economy and provides a legal framework for 70 % of EU legislation.
WHAT ARE THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THE PROGRAMME?
The programme has 4 specific objectives:
To ensure a well-functioning internal market and a fair and transparent market environment, including through the prevention of unfair trading practices and the fight against market distortions.
To promote a high level of consumer protection and financial market integration, including through better enforcement of EU legislation.
To ensure the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, including through the development of digital and green technologies.
To support the development of a European data economy, including through the development of European statistics.
The programme covers a wide range of actions, including:
support for the European Single Portal for Services;
support for the European Single Portal for Goods;
support for the European Single Portal for Consumer Protection;
support for the European Single Portal for SMEs;
support for the European Single Portal for Statistics;
support for the European Single Portal for the Internal Market.
The programme also provides support for the implementation of the European Green Deal.
The programme is based on the principle of subsidiarity and the principle of proportionality.
The programme has a budget of €7.5 billion.
WHEN DOES THE PROGRAMME APPLY?
The programme applies from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021.

Summary 10:
EU rules on firearms
SUMMARY
EU rules on firearms
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes common EU rules on the acquisition and possession of firearms. It also aims to prevent the illicit trade in firearms and the misuse of firearms.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The directive applies to:
firearms, essential components and ammunition, as well as their packaging;
the placing on the market and the export of firearms and essential components;
the acquisition and possession of firearms;
the acquisition and possession of ammunition;
the acquisition and possession of essential components.
The directive does not apply to:
firearms and essential components for hunting or target shooting;
firearms and essential components for military purposes;
firearms and essential components for official use by the armed forces, the police or the public authorities;
firearms and essential components for official use by collectors, museums, galleries or similar institutions;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of scientific or technical experimentation or development;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of historical, cultural, scientific, technical, educational or heritage purposes;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of film or television recordings;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of theatrical performances;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of sports events;
firearms and essential components for the purpose of security.
Firearms and essential components
The directive requires:
firearms, essential components and ammunition to be marked and registered in a computerised data-filing system;
dealers and brokers to report transactions involving firearms or essential components to the national competent authorities;
authorisations to acquire and possess firearms to be issued only to persons who have been granted a licence or who are specifically permitted to acquire and possess firearms in accordance with national law;
firearms and ammunition to be stored in a secure manner when not immediately supervised;
firearms classified in category A to be prohibited;
firearms classified in category B to be acquired and possessed only by persons who have been granted a licence;
firearms classified in category C to be acquired and possessed only by persons who are specifically permitted to acquire and possess such firearms in accordance with national law;
firearms classified in category D to be acquired and possessed only by persons who have been granted a licence or who are specifically permitted to acquire and possess such firearms in accordance with national law;
devices with a cartridge holder which are designed to fire only blanks, irritants, other active substances or pyrotechnic signalling rounds to be rendered permanently inoperable;
firearms which have been deactivated to be rendered permanently inoperable;
firearms to be accompanied by a European firearms pass, which must be produced whenever required by the authorities of the Member States;
the competent authorities of the Member States to exchange information on authorisations granted for the transfer of firearms to another Member State and on refusals to grant authorisations.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
              
It applies from 20 May 2016.
BACKGROUND
              
The European Union has established common rules on firearms in order to ensure that firearms and ammunition can be acquired, possessed and used only by persons who have been granted a licence or who are specifically permitted to acquire and possess them in accordance with national law.
The directive establishes a harmonised system for the acquisition and possession of firearms in the European Union. It also aims to prevent the illicit trade in firearms and the misuse of firearms.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on firearms and the European Firearms and Commodities Accreditation website.
REFERENCES
              
Directive (EU) 2017/854 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 May 2017 on the interstate transfer of the acquisition and possession of weapons (OJ L 143, 7.6.2017, pp. 1-48).

Summary 11:
Single window for maritime transport
Single window for maritime transport
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2018/1996 on the electronic exchange of information in the field of maritime transport and the rotation mechanism for the ship and port facility security committee
WHAT/WHO?
This regulation establishes a single window for the electronic exchange of information in the field of maritime transport (the ‘single window environment’ or ‘EMSWe’). The regulation also establishes a mechanism to ensure the continuity of the work of the ship and port facility security committee (the ‘SPFSC’).
The regulation applies to ships flying the flag of a member country of the European Union (EU) and to ships without an international registration, which call at an EU port.
The regulation establishes a single window for the electronic exchange of information in the field of maritime transport (the ‘single window environment’ or ‘EMSWe’).
The single window environment (EMSWe) consists of the following elements:
a harmonised reporting interface module for the single window of each EU country;
a common user registry and access management system;
a common location database;
a common hazmat database;
a common ship sanitation database.
The regulation establishes a mechanism to ensure the continuity of the work of the ship and port facility security committee (the ‘SPFSC’).
KEY POINTS
Reporting obligations
The regulation establishes a common set of reporting obligations and data elements (the ‘EMSWe data set’). The European Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend the EMSWe data set.
EU countries may impose additional reporting obligations on ships calling at their ports. The Commission is empowered to adopt implementing acts to take account of these additional reporting obligations.
The Commission is also empowered to adopt implementing acts to determine the definitions, categories and data specifications for the data elements.
EU countries must ensure that the single window is operational from 15 August 2021. Until that date, EU countries may continue to use their national single windows and their national reporting systems.
EU countries must ensure that the single window is operational from 15 August 2021. Until that date, EU countries may continue to use their national single windows and their national reporting systems.
The Commission must ensure the continuity of the work of the ship and port facility security committee (SPFSC) from 15 August 2021.
The Commission must ensure the continuity of the work of the ship and port facility security committee (SPFSC) from 15 August 2021.
The Commission is empowered to adopt implementing acts to lay down the functional and technical specifications, quality control mechanisms and procedures for deploying, maintaining and employing the harmonised interface module and the related harmonised elements of the single window.
FROM WHEN?
The regulation applies from 15 August 2019.
The regulation establishes a 4-year period from 14 August 2019 for the Commission to adopt the delegated act referred to in Article 3 of the regulation.
BACKGROUND
The single window environment (EMSWe) is a single electronic gateway for the submission of information by the shipping industry in the field of maritime transport. It allows for the automated exchange of information between the different stakeholders in the maritime sector.
This regulation establishes the single window environment (EMSWe) and a mechanism to ensure the continuity of the work of the ship and port facility security committee (SPFSC).
The regulation is part of the European Commission’s ‘Digital Transport Networks’ initiative, which aims to use digital technologies to facilitate the movement of goods and people across the EU.
The single window environment (EMSWe) will replace the SafeSeaNet system, which was established by Directive 2002/59/EC.
KEY TERM
Single window environment: a comprehensive reporting entry point for maritime transport operators, performing the functionalities of data collection from the declarants and data distribution to all relevant competent authorities and providers of port services.

Summary 12:
interoperability of electronic road toll systems
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It aims to ensure that electronic road toll systems in the European Union (EU) are interoperable and that the cross-border enforcement of the obligation to pay road fees is facilitated.
KEY POINTS
Road fees are fees that users pay to use a specific road infrastructure or a specific vehicle access regulation scheme.
The EU already ensures the interoperability of electronic road toll systems in the EU through the Eurovignette. The Eurovignette is a sticker that drivers of vehicles registered in the EU must display on their vehicles when driving on certain roads in other EU countries.
The Eurovignette is based on the principle of user pays, which means that the user of a service pays for it.
The Eurovignette was initially intended to cover only motorways and other roads with heavy traffic. However, it has since been extended to cover other roads and has become a way to finance the construction and maintenance of the road network.
The Eurovignette also applies to certain urban vehicle access regulation schemes such as low emission zones and restricted access zones.
The directive does not apply to parking fees.
The directive applies to electronic road toll systems which require the installation or use of on-board equipment (OBE).
The directive does not apply to road toll systems which are not electronic within the meaning of point 10 of Article 2 of the directive.
The directive applies to small, strictly local road toll systems for which the costs of compliance with the requirements of Articles 3 to 22 would be disproportionate to the benefits.
The directive does not apply to parking fees.

the obligation to pay the road fee;
the obligation to display the vignette.
The directive does not apply to:
small, strictly local road toll systems for which the costs of compliance with the requirements of Articles 3 to 22 would be disproportionate to the benefits;
parking fees.
The directive does not apply to:
vehicles with a maximum authorised mass below 3.5 tonnes;
vehicles which are not motor vehicles or trailers;
vehicles used exclusively for the transport of goods by rail or inland waterway transport;
vehicles which are used or intended for use in the course of a trade or business;
vehicles used or intended for use by or on behalf of the State.
The directive does not apply to:
vehicles used or intended for use by or on behalf of the State.
In order to ensure that vehicles that are exempt from the application of the directive do not use the road infrastructure for which a road fee is due, the directive does not apply to vehicles which are exempt from the application of the Eurovignette.

Summary 13:
EU network of immigration liaison officers
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a European network of immigration liaison officers to improve coordination and cooperation between Member States, the European Commission and EU agencies in third countries.
KEY POINTS
Immigration liaison officers
These officers are appointed by Member States, the Commission and EU agencies in third countries. They are responsible for collecting information on migration, asylum and border management and sharing it with other officers and with EU institutions and agencies.
The Commission has set up a secure web-based information exchange platform to share information and statistics.
Steering Board
The Steering Board for the European network of immigration liaison officers is composed of one representative from each Member State, two representatives from the Commission, one representative from the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, one representative from Europol and one representative from the European Asylum Support Office (EASO).
The Commission representative chairs the Steering Board and prepares the work of the Board.
The Board coordinates the work of the networks of immigration liaison officers, and it adopts a biennial work programme and biennial report on their activities.
The Commission is responsible for the Secretariat of the Board.
Reporting
The Commission must report to the European Parliament and the Council on the application of the regulation 5 years after its adoption.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 July 2019.
BACKGROUND
The sharp increase in migration in 2015 and 2016 put migration, asylum and border management systems under pressure.
The objective of EU migration policy is to replace irregular and uncontrolled migratory flows with safe and well-managed pathways, through a comprehensive approach aimed at ensuring, at all stages, the efficient management of migration flows in accordance with Chapter 2 of Title V of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
The Commission is committed to protecting the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all migrants, regardless of their migratory status, in full compliance with international law.
KEY WORDS
Migration, asylum, border management

Summary 14:
EU identity cards and residence cards
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules for EU countries to issue new identity cards to EU citizens and residence cards to family members of EU citizens who are not nationals of the EU.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to:
identity cards issued by EU countries to their own nationals;
residence cards issued by EU countries to family members of EU citizens who are not nationals of an EU country.
The regulation does not apply to:
identification documents issued on a provisional basis with a period of validity of less than 6 months;
residence cards issued to non-EU nationals who are not family members of an EU citizen.
EU countries must issue new identity cards in the ID-1 format and include a machine-readable zone (MRZ) and a highly secure storage medium.
The new cards must contain a facial image of the holder and two fingerprints in interoperable digital formats.
EU countries may issue an identity card with a validity of less than 5 years, for identity cards issued to minors, in exceptional cases and where the period of validity is limited in compliance with EU and national law, and for identity cards issued to persons aged 70 and above.
The regulation also sets out rules for the collection of biometric identifiers.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 2 August 2020.
BACKGROUND
The regulation is part of the European Commission’s action plan to tackle travel document fraud and strengthen security at the EU’s external borders. It complements other measures to increase security, such as the introduction of the new generation of EU passports and residence permits for third-country nationals.
For more information, see the European Commission’s website on EU travel documents.
KEY TERMS
National identity card: an identity card issued by an EU country to its own nationals.
Residence card: a residence card issued by an EU country to family members of an EU citizen who are not nationals of an EU country.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) 2019/1006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2018 on the issuance and use of information and guidance documents, and repealing Regulation (EC) No 995/2010 (OJ L 191, 28.7.2019, pp. 36-49).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EC) No 1030/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 June 2002 laying down a uniform format for residence permits and residence documents (OJ L 157, 15.6.2002, pp. 1-4).
Directive 2004/38/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 29 April 2004 on the right to move and reside freely within the EU and on its absorption by the Schengen Agreement (OJ L 229, 29.6.2004, pp. 35-44).

Summary 15:
Interoperability between EU information systems
The European Commission has presented a proposal for a regulation establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa. This proposal establishes a new legal framework to ensure the interoperability of the European border surveillance system (EUROSUR) and the Schengen information system (SIS), as well as of the new European travel information and authorisation system (ETIAS).
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework to ensure interoperability between the following EU information systems:
the Entry/Exit System (EES);
the Visa Information System (VIS);
the European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS);
Eurodac;
the Schengen Information System (SIS);
the European Criminal Records Information System for third-country nationals (ECRIS-TCN).
The regulation also adapts the procedures and conditions for the designated authorities and for the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) to access the EES, VIS, ETIAS and Eurodac for the purposes of the prevention, detection or investigation of terrorist offences or of other serious criminal offences.
KEY POINTS
The regulation establishes a framework for interoperability between the following EU information systems:
the Entry/Exit System (EES);
the Visa Information System (VIS);
the European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS);
Eurodac;
the Schengen Information System (SIS);
the European Criminal Records Information System for third-country nationals (ECRIS-TCN).
The regulation also adapts the procedures and conditions for the designated authorities and for the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) to access the EES, VIS, ETIAS and Eurodac for the purposes of the prevention, detection or investigation of terrorist offences or of other serious criminal offences.
Interoperability components
The regulation establishes 4 interoperability components:
a European search portal (ESP);
a shared biometric matching service (shared BMS);
a common identity repository (CIR);
a multiple-identity detector (MID).
Access to EU information systems
The regulation also lays down the conditions under which the designated authorities and Europol may access the EES, VIS, ETIAS and Eurodac, and support the purposes of the EES, VIS, ETIAS, Eurodac, SIS and ECRIS-TCN.
The conditions for access to the interoperability components are the same as those applicable to the underlying EU information systems.
The regulation also provides for the creation of a central repository for reporting and statistics (CRRS) to generate cross-system statistical data and analytical reporting for policy, operational and data quality purposes.
The CRRS will provide statistical data and analytical reporting on the performance of the interoperability components and the underlying EU information systems.
Security and data protection
The regulation provides for appropriate measures to ensure the security and the protection of personal data, and to prevent any misuse of data, including through automated data quality control mechanisms.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 15 May 2020.
BACKGROUND
The regulation implements the roadmap to enhance information exchange and information management, including interoperability solutions, in the area of justice and home affairs, which was adopted by the Council in June 2016.
The regulation also implements the European Commission’s Action Plan on Integration and Migration, which was adopted in May 2018.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on the interoperability between EU information systems.
KEY TERMS
              
Entry/Exit System (EES): a system to register and store data on the entry and exit of third-country nationals at the EU’s external borders.
Visa Information System (VIS): a system that stores data on visa applications and decisions.
European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS): a system to check whether a third-country national is eligible to travel to the Schengen area.
Eurodac: a system that stores data on asylum applications.
Schengen Information System (SIS): a system that stores data on persons who are sought across the EU for the purpose of deportation or extradition.
European Criminal Records Information System for third-country nationals (ECRIS-TCN): a system that stores data on criminal convictions and convictions or sentences passed in third countries.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) 2018/1806 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2018 establishing a framework for interoperability between European Union information systems in the field of borders and visa and amending Regulations (EC) No 767/2008, (EU) No 526/2014, (EU) 2016/399, (EU) 2017/2226, (EU) 2018/1240, (EU) 2018/1726 and (EU) 2018/1861 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Council Decisions 2004/512/EC and 2008/633/JHA (OJ L 299, 28.12.2018, pp. 29-55).

Summary 16:
Renovation wave for energy efficiency and renewable energy sources
The renovation wave aims to boost the construction of nearly zero-energy buildings (nZEBs) and zero-energy buildings (ZEBs) and to increase the share of renewable energy sources (RES) in the building sector. The renovation wave aims to boost the construction of nearly zero-energy buildings (nZEBs) and zero-energy buildings (ZEBs) and to increase the share of renewable energy sources (RES) in the building sector.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes a common framework for the promotion of renewable energy sources (RES) and energy efficiency in the building sector.
It sets a binding renewable energy target for 2030, which requires the European Union (EU) to ensure that at least 32% of its total final energy consumption comes from renewable sources by 2030.
KEY POINTS
Binding overall EU target for 2030
The EU sets a binding renewable energy target for 2030 of at least 32% of total final energy consumption. The EU’s contribution to the target is composed of individual national contributions, which are to be set by 31 December 2023.
Member States are required to set their national contributions to the binding renewable energy target by 31 December 2023. These national contributions shall be part of the integrated national energy and climate plans (NECPs) in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2018/1999. The NECPs shall be updated at least every 10 years.
Enabling framework for the building sector
The EU is encouraging the renovation of buildings and the use of RES in the building sector by establishing an enabling framework for the building sector. This framework aims to increase the share of RES in the building sector to at least 35% by 2030.
The framework includes the following elements:
an obligation for Member States to ensure that new buildings and buildings undergoing major renovation meet minimum levels of RES in 2021;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that new buildings and buildings undergoing major renovation meet minimum levels of energy performance in 2021;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that new buildings and buildings undergoing major renovation meet minimum levels of energy performance in 2028;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that new buildings and buildings undergoing major renovation meet minimum levels of RES in 2028;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that all buildings undergo a regular energy efficiency inspection every 10 years from 2027;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that all buildings undergo a regular energy efficiency inspection every 10 years from 2034;
an obligation for Member States to ensure that all buildings undergo a regular energy efficiency inspection every 10 years from 2034;
a right for consumers to become ‘renewables self-consumers’ and a right for them to form ‘renewable energy communities’.
Member States are required to establish a ‘renewables self-consumption framework’ and a ‘renewable energy communities framework’ by 31 December 2023.
In order to ensure that the EU’s energy system is more resilient to external shocks, the EU is also encouraging the use of renewable energy sources in the heating and cooling sector. The EU sets a binding renewable energy target for 2030 of at least 14% in the heating and cooling sector.
This directive repeals Directive 2009/28/EC.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It applies from 25 July 2020.

Summary 17:
EU telecoms single market directive
SUMMARY
The EU telecoms single market directive (EU 2018/1972) aims to ensure that all citizens and businesses have access to high-speed internet networks and services.
WHAT DOES THE DIRECTIVE DO?
It lays down a framework for the development of very high capacity networks and services across the EU.
KEY POINTS
The directive applies to all electronic communications networks and services within the EU. These include:
mobile and fixed networks;
networks for radio broadcasting;
networks for television broadcasting;
networks for radio and television on-demand services;
networks for internet access services;
networks for television and radio programme production centres;
networks for networks used for the provision of electronic communications to public administrations.
It does not cover:
the content of services delivered over electronic communications networks using electronic communications services, such as broadcasting content, financial services and certain information society services;
the content of radio and television programmes;
the content of radio and television on-demand services;
the content of radio and television programme production centres.
The directive:
requires the EU to ensure that all citizens and businesses have access to high-speed internet networks and services;
requires the EU to ensure that all citizens and businesses have access to very high capacity networks and services by 2020;
introduces new rules on radio spectrum management;
introduces new rules on numbering management;
introduces new rules on competition;
introduces new rules on access to civil infrastructure.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It applies from 20 December 2018.
BACKGROUND
The EU telecoms single market directive (EU 2018/1972) is the first step towards the establishment of the Digital Single Market.
KEY TERMS
Very high capacity networks and services: networks and services which are able to deliver speeds of at least 30 megabits per second for download and 3 megabits per second for upload in all regions of the EU.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Directive (EU) 2018/1972 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2018 establishing the opening of a third party box for the European Electronic Communications Code and on its interaction with Directive 2014/53/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (OJ C 1, I, 2018, pp. 1-130).
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 18:
Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles
SUMMARY
This regulation lays down rules for monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles in the EU. The regulation applies to vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2,610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council (Directive 2007/46/EC), and all vehicles of categories M3 and N3; and vehicles of categories O3 and O4.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from heavy-duty vehicles in the EU.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to the monitoring and reporting by Member States and manufacturers of heavy-duty vehicles of data on new heavy-duty vehicles.
It applies to vehicles of categories M1, M2, N1 and N2 with a reference mass that exceeds 2,610 kg and which do not fall within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council (Directive 2007/46/EC), and all vehicles of categories M3 and N3; and vehicles of categories O3 and O4.
The regulation sets out the monitoring and reporting obligations for manufacturers and Member States.
Manufacturers of heavy-duty vehicles must monitor and report to the Commission the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption values determined for each new heavy-duty vehicle.
By 28 February each year, starting in 2020, the competent authorities of the Member States must report those data to the Commission in accordance with the reporting procedure set out in Annex II.
The Commission must monitor, where available, the results of on-road tests performed within the framework of Regulation (EC) No 595/2009 to verify the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 13 in order to supplement this regulation by specifying the data to be reported by the competent authorities of the Member States for the purposes of the verification of the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles.
The Commission may impose an administrative fine in each of the following cases:
where it finds that the data reported by the manufacturer deviate from the data resulting from the manufacturer’s records file or the engine type-approval certificate issued within the framework of Regulation (EC) No 595/2009, and the deviation is intentional or due to serious negligence;
where the data are not submitted within the deadline applicable pursuant to Article 5(1) and the delay cannot be duly justified.
The Commission shall, for the purposes of verifying the data referred to in point (a), consult with the relevant approval authorities.
The Commission shall, on the basis of the principles set out in paragraph 3 of this Article, adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 13 to supplement this regulation by laying down the procedure, methods for the calculation and collection of the administrative fines referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article.
The amounts of the administrative fines shall be considered as revenue for the general budget of the Union.
The Commission shall prepare the analysis with the support of the European Environment Agency.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 13 with a view to amending the Annexes for the purpose of:
amending the data to be monitored and reported by manufacturers of heavy-duty vehicles;
specifying the data to be reported by the competent authorities of the Member States for the purposes of the verification of the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles;
specifying the data to be reported by the competent authorities of the Member States for the purposes of the verification of the CO2 emissions and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles;
amending the air drag value ranges;
defining the criteria, the calculation and the method of collection of administrative fines imposed on manufacturers.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 29 July 2018.

Summary 19:
Ensuring security of gas supply in the EU
SUMMARY
The EU has adopted a new regulation on security of gas supply. The aim is to ensure that gas is available in sufficient quantities for all EU citizens, businesses and industries at all times. The new rules complement existing legislation, which already requires EU countries to take certain preventive and mitigation measures to ensure security of gas supply.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework for EU countries to assess and manage risks to the security of gas supply. It also sets out a system of solidarity between EU countries in the event of a severe gas crisis.
KEY POINTS
The regulation covers both the prevention and the mitigation of risks to the security of gas supply. It sets out preventive action plans, emergency plans and an emergency response mechanism.
The preventive action plans include actions to:
increase gas storage capacity;
diversify gas supply routes;
enable bi-directional capacity on interconnection points.
The emergency plans include measures to:
introduce non-market-based measures;
reduce gas demand;
provide gas to solidarity protected customers;
introduce market-based measures;
use gas from LNG terminals.
EU countries must also:
cooperate with each other and with the European Commission to identify and manage risks;
adopt preventive and mitigation measures;
notify the Commission of any serious gas crisis;
take steps to ensure that gas is available in sufficient quantities for all EU citizens, businesses and industries at all times;
provide for the security of gas supply of customers in the territory of the EU.
The regulation provides for a solidarity mechanism between EU countries. This means that in the event of a severe gas crisis, EU countries that are not affected by the crisis will supply gas to those that are. The regulation also establishes a common risk assessment mechanism and a permanent reserve list for a monitoring task force.
EU countries must adopt the necessary measures to ensure that gas is supplied to solidarity protected customers in the requesting EU country in accordance with the regulation.
The regulation repeals Regulation (EU) No 994/2010.
WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 May 2017.
BACKGROUND
The EU has adopted several pieces of legislation on the security of gas supply, including the Gas Directive (2003/55/EC) and the Gas Security of Supply Regulation (2004/682/EC).
The EU has also adopted a regulation on security of electricity supply (2015/122/EC).
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 May 2017.

Summary 20:
ecodesign and energy labelling: new rules for energy-related products
SUMMARY
The EU has adopted new rules for the ecodesign and energy labelling of products. The new rules will help consumers to make informed choices and to save money on their energy bills, while also reducing the EU's energy consumption and environmental impact.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out a framework for the ecodesign and energy labelling of energy-related products.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all products placed on the EU market for the first time, including second-hand imported products.
Manufacturers, importers and distributors of products must ensure that they comply with the regulation and the delegated acts adopted pursuant to it.
Suppliers must provide the market surveillance authorities with the technical documentation of the product. In addition, they must provide the dealer with the energy label and the product information sheet.
Dealers must provide consumers with the product information sheet, and ensure that the product is accompanied by the energy label.
National authorities must ensure that the product is not placed on the market or put into service if it does not comply with the regulation.
The European Commission is responsible for the establishment and maintenance of a product database. This includes a public part and a compliance part.
The regulation also sets out the procedure for the introduction and rescaling of labels.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 August 2017.
BACKGROUND
The regulation replaces Directive 2010/30/EU. It clarifies and updates the content of the directive, taking into account the technological progress achieved over recent years.
KEY TERMS
              
Energy-related products: products or articles intended to be or are operated by consumers for generating, transporting or using energy.
