Summary 21:
Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework for the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data within the European Union (EU).
It sets out the rules to ensure the free flow of personal data within the EU.
It promotes the protection of individuals' rights.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to the processing of personal data by EU and national authorities and organisations, irrespective of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.
It applies to the processing of personal data of individuals in the EU, irrespective of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.
It applies to the processing of personal data of individuals outside the EU where EU citizens are involved.
It applies to the processing of personal data of individuals in the EU, irrespective of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.
The regulation does not apply to the processing of personal data of deceased persons.
The regulation does not apply to personal data processed for national security purposes.
The regulation does not apply to personal data processed for criminal law purposes.
The regulation does not apply to personal data processed by the individual.
The regulation applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

Summary 22:
Improving the quality of consumer price indices
Improving the quality of consumer price indices
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 549/2013 on the European system of national and regional accounts in the Community
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to establish a common framework for the production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) at both national and EU level.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to:
the harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) at national level;
the HICP at EU level;
the harmonised indices of consumer prices for the purposes of the macroeconomic imbalance procedure.
Scope of the harmonised indices
The harmonised indices of consumer prices (HICP, HICP-CT, OOH price index) and of the house price index (HPI) are based on observed prices, which include taxes on products. The HICP and the HICP-CT are based on the price changes and weights of products included in the household final monetary consumption expenditure. The OOH price index is based on the price changes and weights of products included in the household final monetary consumption expenditure for owner-occupied housing (OOH). The HPI is a necessary basis for compiling the OOH price index.
The regulation does not cover transactions between households, except in the case of rentals paid by tenants to private landlords, where the latter act as market producers of services purchased by households (tenants).
The HICP and the HICP-CT are broken down into categories of the European classification of individual consumption according to purpose (ECOICOP).
The OOH price index and the HPI are broken down into categories of the European classification of individual consumption according to purpose (ECOICOP).
Calculation of the indices
The HICP and the HICP-CT are calculated using the Laspeyres-type index. This index is defined as follows:
The price of a product is denoted by p, the price reference period is denoted by 0, and the comparison period is denoted by t. Weights (w) are expenditure shares of a period (b) prior to the price reference period, and are adjusted to reflect the prices of the price reference period 0;
The index reference period is the period for which the index is set to 100 index points;
The price reference period is the period for which the index is based.
The OOH price index is calculated using the Paasche-type index. This index is defined as follows:
The price of a product is denoted by p, the price reference period is denoted by 0, and the comparison period is denoted by t. Weights (w) are expenditure shares of the price reference period 0;
The index reference period is the period for which the index is set to 100 index points;
The price reference period is the period for which the index is based.
The HPI is calculated using the Fisher-type index. This index is defined as follows:
The price of a product is denoted by p, the price reference period is denoted by 0, and the comparison period is denoted by t. Weights (w) are expenditure shares of a period (b) prior to the price reference period, and are adjusted to reflect the prices of the price reference period 0;
The index reference period is the period for which the index is set to 100 index points;
The price reference period is the period for which the index is based.
Production of the indices
The indices are produced by the Member States. The HICP and the HICP-CT are produced at least once a month. The HPI is produced at least once a quarter. The OOH price index is produced at least once a year.
Quality of the indices
The quality of the indices produced is ensured by the Member States. The European Commission (Eurostat) verifies the sources and methods used by Member States to calculate the indices.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 June 2016.

Summary 23:
EU anti-dumping regulation
EU anti-dumping regulation
The EU has adopted an anti-dumping (AD) system that aims to protect the EU market from dumped imports. The EU has adopted an anti-dumping (AD) system that aims to protect the EU market from dumped imports. It is one of the most important tools in the EU’s trade defence system, which also includes a system for safeguarding and a system for countering subsidies and dumping.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down the rules for investigating whether imports into the EU are dumped and whether they cause injury to the domestic industry.
KEY POINTS
The regulation lays down the rules for investigating whether imports into the EU are dumped and whether they cause injury to the domestic industry. It also establishes the procedures for imposing duties on such imports.
A product is considered to be dumped if its export price is less than the normal value of a like product, in the ordinary course of trade, as established for the exporting country.
The normal value may be established on the basis of prices of other sellers or producers in the exporting country, or, in certain circumstances, in another country.
An investigation may be initiated by the Commission, on its own initiative or following a complaint from a producer or association of producers in the EU. It may also be initiated following a request from a Member State.
The Commission is assisted in its work by a committee which meets at least once a year.
The Commission may impose provisional duties on imports from countries suspected of dumping, if it considers that there is sufficient evidence to justify such duties.
It may also accept undertakings from exporters to revise their prices or to cease exports at dumped prices.
The Commission may also decide to terminate a case without applying duties or to impose definitive duties.
Duties are imposed in the appropriate amounts in each case, on a non-discriminatory basis, on imports from all sources found to be dumped and causing injury.
Duties may be imposed for a period of 5 years at the most. They may be extended in exceptional circumstances.
Duties may be imposed only on imports from exporters or producers which have made themselves known in accordance with the regulation, unless they have accepted an undertaking.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 May 2016.

Regulation (EU) 2016/1035 on protection against subsidised imports from third countries
Regulation (EU) 2016/1035 establishes the rules for the application of countervailing measures against subsidised imports from third countries. These measures consist in the imposition of duties on imports of a product from a country, or from a group of countries, which are found to benefit from countervailable subsidies and to cause injury to the producers of like products in the European Union.
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules for the application of countervailing measures against subsidised imports from third countries. These measures consist in the imposition of duties on imports of a product from a country, or from a group of countries, which are found to benefit from countervailable subsidies and to cause injury to the producers of like products in the European Union.
KEY POINTS
Subsidies
A subsidy is a financial contribution by a government or public body which confers a benefit on certain undertakings or products. These subsidies may be granted directly by the government or indirectly through state-owned enterprises.
A subsidy is considered countervailable if it is specific, that is, it is limited in extent or available only to certain enterprises, or contingent in nature, that is, it is tied to export performance or the use of domestic over imported goods.
If a subsidy is found to be countervailable, the European Commission may decide to initiate an investigation into whether the subsidised imports cause injury to the European Union industry and whether the injury is due to the subsidisation. The Commission then imposes a countervailing duty on the imports from the country or countries concerned.
The Commission may also decide to terminate the investigation without imposing a countervailing duty in the following cases:
if the amount of countervailable subsidies is de minimis, that is, it is less than 5 % of the value of imports of the like product from all third countries during the investigation period;
if the volume of subsidised imports is negligible, that is, it is less than 3 % of the total imports of the like product in the European Union;
if the volume of subsidised imports, actual or potential, or the injury, is negligible.
In order to determine whether a subsidy is countervailable, the Commission may ask for information from the European Union industry, from the country or countries concerned, as well as from any interested party in the European Union or in the country or countries concerned.
The Commission must inform the Member States of any request for information and provide them with copies of the questionnaire.
The Commission must publish a notice in the Official Journal of the European Union within 45 days of the date on which the complaint was lodged.
The Commission must reject a complaint where it considers that there is insufficient evidence to justify proceeding with the case.
The Commission may decide to accept an undertaking offered by the exporter or the country concerned that eliminates or offsets the countervailable subsidies and injury instead of imposing a countervailing duty.
The Commission may decide to terminate the investigation without imposing a countervailing duty in the following cases:
if the amount of countervailable subsidies is de minimis, that is, it is less than 5 % of the value of imports of the like product from all third countries during the investigation period;
if the volume of subsidised imports is negligible, that is, it is less than 3 % of the total imports of the like product in the European Union;
if the volume of subsidised imports, actual or potential, or the injury, is negligible.
In order to determine whether a subsidy is countervailable, the Commission may ask for information from the European Union industry, from the country or countries concerned, as well as from any interested party in the European Union or in the country or countries concerned.
The Commission must inform the Member States of any request for information and provide them with copies of the questionnaire.
The Commission must publish a notice in the Official Journal of the European Union within 45 days of the date on which the complaint was lodged.
The Commission must reject a complaint where it considers that there is insufficient evidence to justify proceeding with the case.
The Commission may decide to accept an undertaking offered by the exporter or the country concerned that eliminates or offsets the countervailable subsidies and injury instead of imposing a countervailing duty.
The Commission must impose a countervailing duty on imports from all sources found to benefit from countervailable subsidies and to cause injury to the European Union industry.
The Commission may decide to increase the countervailing duty in order to achieve the price increase required to remove injury.
The Commission may decide to suspend the countervailing duties in cases where the European Union interest calls for intervention.
The Commission may decide to terminate the investigation without imposing a countervailing duty in the following cases:
if the amount of countervailable subsidies is de minimis, that is, it is less than 5 % of the value of imports of the like product from all third countries during the investigation period;
if the volume of subsidised imports is negligible, that is, it is less than 3 % of the total imports of the like product in the European Union;
if the volume of subsidised imports, actual or potential, or the injury, is negligible.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 July 2016.
BACKGROUND
Regulation (EU) 2016/1035 establishes the rules for the application of countervailing measures against subsidised imports from third countries.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on trade defence.
KEY TERMS
European Union industry: producers as a whole or those members of the industry, measured by production, sales or employment, other than those which are price makers or price setters and which are not affected by the subsidised imports from third countries which they compete against, whether or not those members constitute the majority of the total production of the like domestic product.
Subsidy: any financial contribution by a government or public body, including state-owned enterprises, which confers a benefit on certain undertakings or products.
Countervailable subsidy: a subsidy which is specific, that is, it is limited in extent or available only to certain enterprises, or contingent in nature, that is, it is tied to export performance or the use of domestic over imported goods.

Summary 26:
technical support instrument for structural reforms
SUMMARY
The new technical support instrument (TSI) aims to support EU countries in their efforts to implement reforms. It aims to help them to increase their competitiveness and to achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
The regulation establishes the technical support instrument (TSI) to support EU countries in their efforts to implement reforms.
The TSI aims to help EU countries to:
increase their competitiveness;
achieve sustainable economic and social convergence, resilience and recovery;
strengthen their institutional and administrative capacity, including at regional and local level;
facilitate socially inclusive, green and digital transitions.
The TSI also aims to support EU countries in effectively addressing the challenges identified in the country-specific recommendations (CSRs) and in implementing EU law.
The TSI is part of the structural reform support programme (SRSP) established by Regulation (EU) 2017/825.
KEY POINTS
The TSI has a budget of EUR 864 million for the period 2021-2027.
The TSI supports EU countries’ efforts to implement reforms through the provision of technical support.
EU countries wishing to receive technical support under the TSI shall submit a request for technical support to the European Commission, identifying the policy areas and the priorities for support.
The Commission analyses the request for support on the basis of the urgency, breadth and depth of the challenges identified, the support needs in respect of the policy areas concerned, and the analysis of socioeconomic indicators and the institutional and general administrative capacity of the EU countries concerned.
The Commission then draws up a cooperation and support plan (CSP) in cooperation with the EU country concerned.
The CSP is a detailed plan on how to provide technical support to the EU country concerned, which is based on the request for technical support and the analysis of the Commission.
The CSP sets out the technical support to be provided, the actions to be implemented and the indicative timetable for their implementation.
The TSI provides technical support for the implementation of reforms undertaken at the initiative of EU countries, in the context of economic governance processes, in particular those effectively addressing the CSRs, and in relation to the implementation of economic adjustment programmes.
Technical support can also be provided to EU countries for the preparation, amendment, implementation and revision of recovery and resilience plans pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2021/241.
The TSI also provides technical support to EU countries for the preparation of national recovery and resilience plans pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2021/241.
The TSI provides technical support to EU countries for the preparation, amendment, implementation and revision of recovery and resilience plans pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2021/241.
The TSI provides technical support for the preparation, amendment, implementation and revision of national recovery and resilience plans pursuant to Regulation (EU) 2021/241.
The TSI provides technical support for the implementation of the European Green Deal.
The TSI provides technical support for the digital transformation of the economy and society, including the development of digital skills and digital education.

The TSI provides technical support for the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights.

Summary 27:
Rail passengers’ rights and obligations — Regulation (EU) 2017/2203
Rail passengers’ rights and obligations — Regulation (EU) 2017/2203
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2017/2203 on the cooperation between national authorities with a view to ensuring and facilitating lawful railway traffic in the European Union
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
The regulation aims to ensure that the European rail network is fully integrated and that passengers enjoy the same rights whatever the journey they are taking.
It also aims to ensure a level playing field for railway undertakings.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to international and domestic rail journeys and services throughout the European Union (EU) provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with the rail passenger rights directive (Directive 2012/34/EU).
Rights and obligations
The regulation establishes the rights and obligations of rail passengers and of railway undertakings, as well as those of other actors in the rail sector such as ticket vendors and tour operators.
Rights of rail passengers
The regulation grants the same rights to rail passengers taking international and domestic journeys.
It lays down passengers’ rights in the event of delay, missed connection or cancellation of a service, or in the event of death or injury.
It also provides for the right to compensation in the event of delay or cancellation, as well as the right to assistance for persons with reduced mobility and the right to information.
Obligations of railway undertakings
Railway undertakings have to provide passengers with travel information, including information on the accessibility of trains and stations, as well as the availability of assistance for persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility.
They also have to provide travel information through telematics applications, such as websites or mobile applications, provided that such requirements are not discriminatory.
Railway undertakings have to provide tickets and, where available, through-tickets and reservations.
The regulation sets out the conditions under which assistance is provided to persons with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility.
It also lays down the conditions under which passengers with disabilities and persons with reduced mobility may be refused assistance.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 December 2017.
BACKGROUND
              
The European Commission adopted this regulation in order to improve the level of consumer protection in the EU, to ensure a level playing field for railway undertakings and to guarantee a uniform level of passengers’ rights.
The regulation promotes the use of bicycles and establishes the rights and obligations regarding the carriage of bicycles on trains.
For more information, please see the European Commission website.
KEY TERMS
              
Railway undertaking. A railway undertaking is an undertaking the main object of which is to provide rail services for passengers or goods, or both, on its own account.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) 2017/2203 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 November 2017 on the cooperation between national authorities with a view to ensuring and facilitating lawful railway traffic in the European Union (OJ L 348, 29.12.2017, pp. 1-25).
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 28:
Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA III)
Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA III)
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA III) for the period of the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027 (2021-2027 MFF).
The regulation aims to support the Western Balkans region in adopting and implementing the political, institutional, legal, administrative, social and economic reforms required by the region to comply with European Union (EU) values and to progressively align to EU rules, standards, policies and practices (‘acquis’).
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out the objectives of IPA III. These are to:
support the efforts of the Western Balkans region in adopting and implementing the political, institutional, legal, administrative, social and economic reforms required by the region to comply with EU values and to progressively align to the EU acquis;
contribute to mutual stability, security, peace and prosperity in the region;
promote good neighbourly relations, foster EU integration and promote socioeconomic development;
contribute to the EU’s strategic objectives, in particular the European Green Deal, the digital agenda and the European Semester;
contribute to the implementation of the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
The regulation sets out the priorities for assistance to the region. These include:
the rule of law and fundamental rights;
democratic institutions and public administration reform;
economic development and competitiveness;
good neighbourly relations;
climate change and the environment;
migration and forced displacement;
social cohesion and resilience;
digital economy and society;
research and innovation;
transport;
agriculture and rural development;
education, training, professional and vocational skills;
health;
sustainable connectivity.
The regulation sets out the priorities for assistance for cross-border cooperation between the region and the EU. These include:
promoting employment, labour mobility and social and cultural inclusion across borders;
protecting the environment and promoting adaptation to climate change, the mitigation of climate change, and risk prevention and management;
ensuring a healthy and safe living and working environment;
promoting smart, sustainable, inclusive and safe transport, removing bottlenecks in key network infrastructures, and enhancing energy security and diversification, by investing in projects with high European added-value;
promoting innovation, research and the development of key enabling technologies;
promoting digital skills, digital education and digital entrepreneurship;
promoting the development of a resilient and sustainable agri-food and fisheries sector, as well as the agri-food and fisheries chain;
promoting the development of a modern, efficient and sustainable transport system and the energy sector;
promoting the development of a knowledge-based economy and the digital economy and society;
promoting the development of a modern, efficient and sustainable transport system and the energy sector;
promoting the development of a competitive, modern and sustainable tourism sector;
promoting the development of a modern, efficient and sustainable health care system;
promoting the development of a modern, efficient and sustainable education and training system.
The regulation sets out the rules for the implementation of IPA III. These include:
the establishment of an IPA programming framework for the 2021-2027 MFF, which will include indicators for assessing progress towards the achievement of the specific objectives;
the establishment of an IPA programming framework for the 2021-2027 MFF, which will include indicators for assessing progress towards the achievement of the specific objectives;
the establishment of an IPA programming framework, which will be reviewed on the basis of an annual assessment;
the assessment of the performance of the Western Balkans region and the decision on the assistance to be provided, which will pay particular attention to the efforts made in the fields of the rule of law and fundamental rights, democratic institutions and public administration reform, as well as economic development and competitiveness;
the establishment of implementing measures and methods, which will include the use of direct and indirect management, as well as other methods, such as grants, prizes and procurement;
the establishment of a European Fund for Sustainable Development Plus, which will be managed by the European Investment Bank, for the period of the 2021-2027 MFF;
the establishment of a strategic board, which will advise the Commission on the strategic orientation of investments for the Western Balkans under the European Fund for Sustainable Development Plus and contribute to their alignment with the guiding principles, policy framework and objectives set out in the regulation;
the establishment of key performance indicators for monitoring the implementation and progress of IPA III towards the achievement of the specific objectives.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
In 2018, the European Commission emphasised the firm, merit-based prospect of EU membership for the Western Balkans in its communication entitled ‘A credible enlargement perspective for and enhanced EU engagement with the Western Balkans’. The Western Balkans region is currently made up of 6 countries: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Serbia. These countries have all applied to become EU members and have been assessed on their own merits. The Commission has assessed their progress and has identified shortcomings in each of them. The Commission has provided incentives and guidance to these countries to pursue the necessary far-reaching reforms.
In 2018, the EU and its Member States reaffirmed their unequivocal support for the European perspective of the Western Balkans in the Sofia Declaration. The EU and its Member States reaffirmed their unequivocal support for the European perspective of the Western Balkans in the Sofia Declaration of 17 May 2018 and the Zagreb Declaration of 6 May 2020.
The European Council has granted the status of candidate country to Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Serbia.

Summary 30:
EU rules to protect whistleblowers
SUMMARY
EU countries have agreed to introduce rules to protect whistleblowers in the EU. These rules will be applicable to all sectors, including the financial sector, the public sector, the transport sector, the environmental sector, the food sector, the health sector, the data protection sector, the competition sector, the tax sector, the energy sector and the defence sector.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It sets out common minimum standards for the protection of whistleblowers. These minimum standards apply across the EU, and aim to ensure that breaches of EU law are detected and prevented.
KEY POINTS
Internal reporting
Reporting persons may report breaches through internal reporting channels or procedures provided for by EU countries. These channels or procedures may be operated internally by a person or department designated for that purpose or provided externally by a third party.
External reporting
Reporting persons may report breaches using the channels and procedures referred to in this directive, after having first reported through internal reporting channels, or by directly reporting through external reporting channels.
The directive provides for procedures for reporting and follow-up through external reporting channels. The competent authorities in EU countries are responsible for receiving and following up on reports.
Protection of whistleblowers
The directive provides for the protection of persons who report or publicly disclose information on breaches of EU law. It also provides for the protection of persons who facilitate reporting or who are connected with the reporting persons.
It also provides for protection from liability, and for compensation for damage suffered by persons who report or publicly disclose information on breaches of EU law.
The directive provides for the establishment of internal reporting channels by legal entities in the private sector. It also provides for the establishment of external reporting channels at a central level in EU countries.
It provides for the possibility of the establishment of external reporting channels at a central level in EU countries, where it is necessary for the enforcement of EU law, such as in the area of State aid.
It provides for the possibility of EU countries to extend protection under national law as regards areas or acts not covered by the directive.
It provides for the possibility of the establishment of external reporting channels at a central level in EU countries, where it is necessary for the enforcement of EU law, such as in the area of State aid.
It provides for the possibility of EU countries to extend protection under national law as regards areas or acts not covered by the directive.
It provides for the possibility for legal entities in the private sector to establish internal reporting channels, depending on the size of the entity and the level of risk its activities pose to the public interest.
It provides for the possibility for EU countries to exempt certain legal entities in the private sector from the obligation to establish internal reporting channels, where the activities of those legal entities do not pose a risk to the public interest.
It provides for the possibility for EU countries to limit the scope of protection of persons who report or publicly disclose information on breaches of EU law in certain sectors, such as the financial sector, where the sector-specific rules provide for a high level of protection.
It provides for the possibility for EU countries to limit the scope of protection of persons who report or publicly disclose information on breaches of EU law in certain sectors, such as the financial sector, where the sector-specific rules provide for a high level of protection.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It will apply from 11 December 2021.
BACKGROUND
The EU has been developing rules to protect whistleblowers since 2010. In 2017, the European Commission presented a proposal for a new directive to protect whistleblowers. The new rules will be applicable to all sectors, including the financial sector, the public sector, the transport sector, the environmental sector, the food sector, the health sector, the data protection sector, the competition sector, the tax sector, the energy sector and the defence sector.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on whistleblowing.

Summary 31:
The European Border and Coast Guard
The European Border and Coast Guard
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Border and Coast Guard (EBCG) as a specialised agency of the EU. The EBCG is designed to improve migration management and to strengthen the protection of the EU’s external borders.
KEY POINTS
The EBCG consists of 4 components:
border control, including measures to facilitate legitimate border crossings and to prevent and detect cross-border crime at the external borders;
returns, including the identification of third-country nationals and other pre-return and return-related activities of the Member States;
synergies between the vulnerability assessment and the Schengen evaluation mechanism;
EUROSUR, which is an integrated framework for the exchange of information and operational cooperation within the EBCG to improve situational awareness and to increase reaction capability for the purposes of border management.
The EBCG is accountable to the European Parliament and the Council.
The EBCG has a standing corps of 10 000 operational staff. It has its own command and control structures and a pool of technical equipment, including vehicles, boats, drones, cameras and other equipment needed for possible rapid border interventions.
The EBCG coordinates the activities of the national authorities of the Member States in order to strengthen the protection of the EU’s external borders and to prevent, detect and combat cross-border crime.
The EBCG coordinates the activities of the migration management support teams.
The EBCG supports the Member States in facilitating persons to cross the external borders.
The EBCG provides technical and operational assistance to Member States in the return process.
The EBCG has a network of liaison officers.
The EBCG carries out a vulnerability assessment in order to assess the capacity and readiness of the Member States to face challenges at their external borders and to contribute to the standing corps and technical equipment pool.
The EBCG coordinates the activities of the national coordination centres.
The EBCG develops, deploys and operates an information system capable of exchanging classified and sensitive non-classified information.
The EBCG carries out a risk analysis for European integrated border management.
The EBCG coordinates joint operations, rapid border interventions and hotspots.
The EBCG coordinates the deployment of the border management teams.
The EBCG coordinates migration management support teams.
The EBCG coordinates the deployment of technical equipment.
The EBCG coordinates the return interventions.
The EBCG coordinates the return operations.
The EBCG coordinates the deployment of the forced-return monitors.
WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
From 5 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
Following the 2015 migration crisis, the European Commission proposed a series of measures to strengthen the protection of the EU’s external borders and to restore the normal functioning of the Schengen area. The proposal for a regulation establishing the European Border and Coast Guard (EBCG) was one of these measures.
The EBCG was established in order to improve migration management and to strengthen the protection of the EU’s external borders.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s factsheet.

Summary 32:
cyber security strategy and European Agency for Cybersecurity
SUMMARY
Cybersecurity is a growing challenge. The EU needs to ensure that it is well prepared to face it. The EU cyber security strategy sets out the EU’s priorities in the area of cybersecurity and aims to build up and strengthen the EU’s overall capability in cybersecurity. The EU cyber security strategy sets out the EU’s priorities in the area of cybersecurity and aims to build up and strengthen the EU’s overall capability in cybersecurity.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a European Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) with a mandate to improve EU cyber security.
KEY POINTS
The EU cyber security strategy
The EU cyber security strategy sets out the EU’s priorities in the area of cybersecurity and aims to build up and strengthen the EU’s overall capability in cybersecurity. The EU cyber security strategy is based on the following 5 pillars:
Preventing and managing cyber incidents
Improving EU cyber defence
Promoting secure and trustworthy ICT products, services and processes
Developing the EU internal market for ICT security
Building international cyber security partnerships
The EU cyber security strategy is implemented through a number of EU policy instruments, including the European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA), Directive (EU) 2016/680 on security of network and information systems and Regulation (EU) 2016/95 on the European Union Agency for Operational Management of Large-scale Technological Events.
ENISA
ENISA is the EU’s cyber security agency. It supports the EU and its Member States in improving EU cyber security.
ENISA’s tasks include:
supporting EU cyber security policy development;
providing EU cyber security expertise and advice;
providing EU cyber security knowledge and information;
supporting EU cyber security cooperation;
providing EU cyber security coordination;
promoting EU cyber security awareness.
The EU cyber security strategy
The EU cyber security strategy sets out the EU’s priorities in the area of cybersecurity and aims to build up and strengthen the EU’s overall capability in cybersecurity. The EU cyber security strategy is based on the following 5 pillars:
Preventing and managing cyber incidents
Improving EU cyber defence
Promoting secure and trustworthy ICT products, services and processes
Developing the EU internal market for ICT security
Building international cyber security partnerships
The EU cyber security strategy is implemented through a number of EU policy instruments, including the European Network and Information Security Agency (ENISA), Directive (EU) 2016/680 on security of network and information systems and Regulation (EU) 2016/95 on the European Union Agency for Operational Management of Large-scale Technological Events.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
Cybersecurity is a growing challenge. The EU needs to ensure that it is well prepared to face it. The EU cyber security strategy sets out the EU’s priorities in the area of cybersecurity and aims to build up and strengthen the EU’s overall capability in cybersecurity.
For further information, please see the European Commission’s website on cybersecurity.
KEY TERMS
* Cybersecurity: the capacity of systems, networks and digital services to resist, at a satisfactory level, cyber threats and attacks.
* Cyber incident: any deliberate or unintentional act that could compromise the security of a system or its data.
* Cyber defence: the capability of a State to protect and defend itself, including its citizens, from cyber threats and attacks.
* ICT: information and communication technologies.

Summary 33:
Regulation (EU) 2018/1882 — Gross National Income at market prices
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the definition of gross national income (GNI) at market prices and the rules for its calculation in accordance with the European System of Accounts 2010 (ESA 2010).
It sets out the rules for the transmission of GNI data and additional information by the EU countries to the European Commission (Eurostat).
It lays down procedures and checks on the calculation of GNI by the EU countries.
KEY POINTS
Gross national income at market prices
GNI is defined in Article 1 of the regulation. It is calculated in accordance with the ESA 2010, which is established by Regulation (EU) No 549/2013. In accordance with point 8.89 of Annex A to Regulation (EU) No 549/2013, GDP means the final result of the production activity of resident producer units. It can be defined in 3 ways:
production approach: GDP is the sum of gross value added of the various institutional sectors or the various industries plus taxes and less subsidies on products (which are not allocated to sectors and industries). It is also the balancing item in the total economy production account;
expenditure approach: GDP is the sum of final uses of goods and services by resident institutional units (final consumption and gross capital formation) plus exports and minus imports of goods and services;
income approach: GDP is the sum of uses in the total economy generation of income account (compensation of employees, taxes on production and imports less subsidies, gross operating surplus and mixed income of the total economy). In accordance with point 8.94 of Annex A to Regulation (EU) No 549/2013, GNI means the total primary income receivable by resident institutional units: compensation of employees, taxes on production and imports less subsidies, property income (receivable less payable), gross operating surplus and gross mixed income. GNI equals GDP minus primary income payable by resident institutional units to non-resident institutional units plus primary income receivable by resident institutional units from the rest of the world.
Transmission of GNI data and additional information
Before 1 October each year, the EU countries must provide the Commission (Eurostat), in the context of national accounting procedures, with figures for GNI aggregates and their components, in accordance with the definitions referred to in Article 1. The transmission of data shall be accompanied by a report on the quality of GNI data. The Commission shall establish, by means of implementing acts, the structure and detailed arrangements of the inventory referred to in Article 3(1) of this Regulation, in accordance with Annex A to Regulation (EU) No 549/2013, as well as the timetable for its updating and transmission. Those implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 8(2) of this Regulation.
Procedures and checks on the calculation of GNI
The Commission shall verify the sources, their uses and the methods in the inventory referred to in Article 3(1). The Commission shall adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 7 to supplement the provision laid down in the first subparagraph of this paragraph by defining the list of issues to be addressed in every verification cycle to ensure the reliability, exhaustiveness and highest possible degree of comparability of GNI data, in line with ESA 2010. The Commission shall establish, by means of implementing acts, specific measures to make GNI data more comparable, reliable and exhaustive, based on the list of issues defined by the Commission in the delegated acts referred to in the second subparagraph of paragraph 2 of this Article. Such implementing acts shall be duly justified and in accordance with ESA 2010. Those implementing acts shall be adopted in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 8(2).
Without prejudice to the inspections provided for in Article 2 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 608/2014, GNI information visits may, where deemed appropriate, be carried out in EU countries by the Commission (Eurostat). The purposes of the information visits referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article shall be the verification of the quality of GNI aggregates and their components and the verification of compliance with ESA 2010. In exercising its right to carry out such information visits, the Commission (Eurostat) shall respect the rules on statistical confidentiality laid down in Chapter V of Regulation (EC) No 223/2009.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 April 2019.
BACKGROUND
GNI is an important analytical tool for the coordination of national economic policies and for various EU policies, as well as for research activities.
For own resources purposes, GNI means an annual GNI at market prices under the methodology set out in Annex A to Regulation (EU) No 549/2013 which established the revised European System of Accounts (ESA 2010).
In accordance with Article 10(1) of Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, and subject to Article 10(2) thereof, Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom was repealed.
KEY TERMS
              
Gross National Income (GNI)
European System of Accounts 2010 (ESA 2010)
European Commission (Eurostat)

Summary 34:
EU type-approval for vehicles and engines
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down the rules for granting EU type-approval to vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units which have been approved in the United Kingdom (UK) and which are placed on the EU market after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom.
KEY POINTS
Scope
This regulation applies to vehicles, systems, components and separate technical units which fall within the scope of Directive 2007/46/EC, Regulation (EU) No 167/2013, Regulation (EU) No 168/2013 or Regulation (EU) 2016/1628 and their types which have been approved by the UK type-approval authority on the basis of those acts or any regulatory act of the Union listed in Annex IV to Directive 2007/46/EC or any regulatory act repealed by those regulatory acts of the Union.
Conditions for the granting of a Union type-approval and its effects
The Union type-approval may be granted on the basis of the same test reports which were used for the UK type-approval. Before granting a Union type-approval, the Union type-approval authority may request the repetition of specific tests. In that case, those tests shall be carried out by a technical service which has been designated and notified by the Member State of the Union type-approval authority in accordance with Directive 2007/46/EC, Regulation (EU) No 167/2013, Regulation (EU) No 168/2013 or Regulation (EU) 2016/1628.
The type approved in accordance with the regulation shall receive an EU type-approval certificate with a number consisting of the distinguishing number of the Member State whose type-approval authority granted the Union type-approval and of the number of the applicable act referred to in Article 2(1). It shall also include the number of the latest amending act containing requirements for type-approval in accordance with which the Union type-approval is granted.
For vehicles, the type-approval certificate and the certificate of conformity shall, under ‘Remarks:’, contain the mention ‘Previously type-approved as’ and refer to the number and the date of the EU type-approval certificate received following the UK type-approval. For systems, components or separate technical units, the type-approval certificate shall contain the mention ‘Previously type-approved and marked as’ and refer to the type-approval mark received following the UK type-approval.
The Union type-approval shall take effect on the day of its granting or on a later date determined therein. The UK type-approval shall become invalid on the day preceding the day on which the Union type-approval takes effect. In any event, it shall become invalid at the latest on the day on which the Union type-approval legislation referred to in Article 2(1) ceases to apply to and in the United Kingdom.
A Union type-approval shall be considered to be an EC type-approval or an EU type-approval within the meaning of Directive 2007/46/EC or any act listed in Annex IV to that Directive, Regulation (EU) No 167/2013, Regulation (EU) No 168/2013 or Regulation (EU) 2016/1628. All provisions of those acts not derogated from in this regulation shall continue to apply.
The Union type-approval authority shall take full responsibility for the obligations stemming from the Union type-approval. Vehicles, systems, components or separate technical units produced on the basis of a UK type-approval which has become invalid as a result of the granting of a Union type-approval may be placed on the market, registered and entered into service in the EU until the Union type-approval legislation referred to in Article 2(1) ceases to apply to and in the United Kingdom.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 3 April 2019.

Summary 36:
European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) (the ‘Instrument’). The Instrument aims to provide financial assistance to EU countries experiencing, or threatened with, a severe economic disturbance due to the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. The financial assistance is intended to support short-time work schemes or similar measures, and, where appropriate, some health-related measures.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 25 March 2020.
KEY POINTS
The Instrument complements national measures taken by EU countries by providing financial assistance to help them cope with the sudden and severe increase in actual and possibly also planned public expenditure intended to mitigate the direct economic, social and health-related effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak.
EU countries may request financial assistance under the Instrument where their actual and possibly also planned public expenditure has suddenly and severely increased as of 1 February 2020 due to national measures directly related to short-time work schemes and similar measures to address the socio-economic effects of the exceptional occurrence caused by the COVID-19 outbreak.
The financial assistance takes the form of a loan granted by the EU to the EU country concerned. The Commission borrows on the capital markets or with financial institutions on behalf of the EU.
The maximum amount of financial assistance is EUR 100 billion for all EU countries.
The Commission consults the EU country concerned before submitting a proposal to the Council. The Council then decides on the amount of the loan, its maximum average maturity, its pricing formula, its maximum number of instalments, its availability period and the other detailed rules needed for the granting of the financial assistance. The Council considers the existing and expected needs of the requesting EU country, as well as requests for financial assistance already submitted or planned to be submitted by other EU countries, while applying the principles of equal treatment, solidarity, proportionality and transparency.
The loan granted under the Instrument is disbursed in instalments.
The borrowing and lending operations under the Instrument are carried out in euros. The characteristics of the loan are agreed in a loan agreement between the beneficiary EU country and the Commission.
The prudential rules applicable to the portfolio of loans include a maximum share of loans granted to the 3 EU countries representing the largest share of the loans granted (60 %), a maximum annual exposure of EUR 50 billion, and a maximum amount of EUR 10 billion due by the EU in a given year.
The Commission establishes the necessary arrangements for the administration of the loans with the European Central Bank. The beneficiary EU country opens a special account with its national central bank for the management of the financial assistance received.
EU countries may contribute to the Instrument by counter-guaranteeing the risk borne by the EU. Contributions from EU countries are provided in the form of irrevocable, unconditional and on-demand guarantees.
The Instrument becomes available once the Commission has informed the European Parliament, the Council, the Economic and Financial Committee and the Employment Committee of the use of financial assistance and the continuation of the exceptional occurrences that justify the application of this Regulation. The period of availability of the Instrument ends on 31 December 2022. The Council may decide to extend the period of availability of the Instrument for an additional period of 6 months.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 25 March 2020.
BACKGROUND
The COVID-19 outbreak has had a massive and disruptive impact on the economic systems of EU countries, caused societal disruptions and increased public expenditure in a growing number of EU countries. The SURE aims to provide financial assistance to EU countries experiencing, or threatened with, a severe economic disturbance due to the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. The financial assistance is intended to support short-time work schemes or similar measures, and, where appropriate, some health-related measures.
For further information, please see the European Commission’s factsheet and press release.

Summary 37:
Recovery and resolution of central counterparties
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down rules and procedures relating to the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) authorised in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 648/2012.
KEY POINTS
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes rules and procedures for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs).
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It requires CCPs to draw up and maintain a recovery plan providing for measures to be taken in the case of both default and non-default events and combinations of both, in order to restore their financial soundness, without any extraordinary public financial support, and allow them to continue to provide critical functions following a significant deterioration of their financial situation or a risk of breaching their capital and prudential requirements under Regulation (EU) No 648/2012.
It requires CCPs to prepare and update their resolution plans, which set out the actions that the resolution authority may take where the CCP meets the conditions for resolution.
It provides for the establishment of a resolution college to carry out the tasks relating to the preparation, planning and application of resolution decisions.
It provides for the adoption by the European Commission of regulatory technical standards (RTS) specifying the information to be included in the recovery and resolution plans of CCPs.
KEY TERMS
Central counterparty (CCP): an entity that interposes itself between buyers and sellers to ensure the performance of their obligations.
KEY FACTS
The regulation establishes rules and procedures for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs).
The regulation requires CCPs to draw up and maintain a recovery plan providing for measures to be taken in the case of both default and non-default events and combinations of both, in order to restore their financial soundness, without any extraordinary public financial support, and allow them to continue to provide critical functions following a significant deterioration of their financial situation or a risk of breaching their capital and prudential requirements under Regulation (EU) No 648/2012.
It requires CCPs to prepare and update their resolution plans, which set out the actions that the resolution authority may take where the CCP meets the conditions for resolution.
It provides for the establishment of a resolution college to carry out the tasks relating to the preparation, planning and application of resolution decisions.
It provides for the adoption by the European Commission of regulatory technical standards (RTS) specifying the information to be included in the recovery and resolution plans of CCPs.
It provides for the application of early intervention powers by the competent authorities, when necessary to prevent or mitigate the adverse effects on financial stability of the application of recovery and resolution measures.
It provides for the application of resolution tools in the event of the failure of a CCP.

Summary 38:
European Year of Rail 2021
The year 2021 will be designated the ‘European Year of Rail’, to encourage and support efforts across the European Union (EU) to increase the share of passengers and freight moving by rail.
WHAT DOES THIS DECISION DO?
It designates the year 2021 the ‘European Year of Rail’.
It sets out the objectives of the European Year, namely to promote rail as a sustainable, innovative, interconnected and intermodal, safe and affordable mode of transport.
KEY POINTS
To achieve the objectives, the European Commission will:
consider initiatives such as a European label for goods and products transported by rail and a rail connectivity index;
support the creation of a European rail network;
support the development of innovative solutions and services for rail passengers;
support the development of a European rail sector;
encourage the use of rail in remote areas and rural regions;
support the development of a rail sector workforce;
support the development of new rail products;
support the development of a European rail tourism market;
support the development of a rail freight market;
support the development of a European rail passenger market;
support the development of a rail sector for people with disabilities;
support the development of a rail sector for young people.
The Commission will also:
coordinate the European Year at Union level;
support the European Year at national level;
cooperate with international organisations;
monitor and evaluate the European Year.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
The decision applies from 1 January 2021 until 31 December 2022.
BACKGROUND
The European Green Deal aims to transform the EU into a fair and prosperous society, with a modern, resource-efficient and competitive economy where there are no net emissions of greenhouse gases in 2050.
The EU aims to achieve climate neutrality by 2050. The transport sector accounts for a quarter of the EU’s greenhouse gas emissions, a share that is still growing. To achieve climate neutrality, a 90 % reduction in transport emissions is needed by 2050.
The European Green Deal implies accelerating the shift to sustainable and smart mobility in order to address those challenges. In particular, a substantial part of the 75 % of inland freight carried today by road should be shifted onto rail and inland waterways.
Rail has a significant role to play as a game changer in achieving the climate neutrality objective by 2050. It is one of the most environmentally friendly and energy-efficient transport modes. Rail is largely electrified and emits far less CO2 than equivalent travel by road or air. It is the only transport mode that has consistently reduced its greenhouse gas emissions and CO2 emissions since 1990. In addition, rail has decreased its energy consumption between 1990 and 2016 and increasingly uses renewable energy sources.
The COVID-19 crisis has hit the transport sector exceptionally hard. Despite operational and financial constraints, the sector has maintained crucial connections both for the transport of people and of essential goods. This has been possible mainly thanks to the employees who have continued working under difficult and uncertain conditions. The strategic role played by rail during the COVID-19 crisis has highlighted that achieving the single European railway area is necessary both for facilitating the supply of essential goods, such as food, medicines and fuel, particularly in exceptional circumstances, and for achieving wider transport policy objectives.
The rail sector is sometimes hampered by outdated business and operational practices, by ageing infrastructure and rolling stock and by noisy wagons. Overcoming those obstacles together with reducing costs, studying Union schemes to supplement national mechanisms for non-discriminatory support for rail operators, and accelerating innovation will allow rail to realise its full potential, while ensuring the functioning of the internal market, increasing rail traffic and further improving the already high safety levels.
The year 2021 will be important for the EU rail policy, since it will represent the first full year where the rules agreed under the Fourth Railway Package will be implemented throughout the EU, namely on the opening of the market of domestic passenger services, on reducing costs and administrative burden for railway undertakings operating across the EU and on providing the European Union Agency for Railways (ERA) with additional tasks that aim to lower technical barriers.
The European Year of Rail will contribute to a pan-European debate on the future of railways.

Summary 39:
European Security and Defence College (ESDC)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DECISION DO?
It establishes the European Security and Defence College (ESDC) and defines its mission, objectives and tasks.
KEY POINTS
The ESDC provides training and education in the field of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CSDP issues.
The ESDC organises and conducts training and education activities in the field of the CSDP in the wider context of the CFSP.
The ESDC consists of a network of civilian and military institutes, colleges, academies, universities, institutions, centres of excellence and other actors dealing with security and defence policy issues within the EU, as well as the European Union Institute for Security Studies (EUISS).
The ESDC works under the overall responsibility of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy.
The ESDC is chaired by a representative of the High Representative.
The ESDC is composed of a Steering Committee, a Board and a Secretariat.
The ESDC is financed through contributions from the general budget of the European Union, contributions from the EU institutions and agencies, and contributions from EU Member States.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
The ESDC was established by Council Joint Action 2005/575/CFSP on 18 July 2005. It was replaced by Council Decision 2013/189/CFSP on 22 April 2013. Finally, Decision 2013/189/CFSP was replaced by Council Decision (CFSP) 2016/2382 on 26 July 2016.
KEY TERMS
              
Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP): the European Union’s policy aimed at improving defence capabilities and developing defence and crisis management capabilities. It provides the EU with a comprehensive approach to security and defence, including the fight against terrorism and organised crime, the management of migration flows and the prevention of conflict and the management of crises.
Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP): the European Union’s policy on external action and security. It provides for the Union to speak with one voice on international issues.

Council Decision (CFSP) 2020/1880 of 23 December 2020 on the establishment of the European Security and Defence College (ESDC) and repealing Council Decision (CFSP) 2016/2382 (OJ C 478, 30.12.2020, pp. 1-7)

Summary 40:
EU rules on water reuse for irrigation
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2020/852 on the use of treated wastewater for irrigation purposes
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down minimum requirements for the safe reuse of treated urban wastewater for agricultural irrigation.
The regulation aims to guarantee that reclaimed water is safe for agricultural irrigation, thereby ensuring a high level of protection of the environment and of human and animal health, promoting the circular economy, supporting adaptation to climate change and contributing to the objectives of the EU’s water framework directive (WFD) by addressing water scarcity and the resulting pressure on water resources.
KEY POINTS
Scope
This regulation applies to reclaimed water used for agricultural irrigation.
The regulation does not cover:
water intended for human consumption;
water intended for animal feeding;
water used for industrial purposes;
water used for energy production;
water used for amenity purposes;
water used for environmental purposes.
Water reuse systems
A water reuse system is any part of a water reuse chain that is designed to treat urban wastewater and to provide reclaimed water to an end-user. It may consist of a number of different stages, including: a collection system; a treatment plant; a distribution network; a storage facility; an end-user.
A water reuse chain is a combination of water reuse systems.
Reclamation facility operator
A reclamation facility operator is a party responsible for the operation of a water reuse system. This may be a single party or a combination of parties.
Reclaimed water quality
The regulation lays down minimum requirements for the water quality of reclaimed water, as well as for the monitoring of water quality.
Reclaimed water intended for agricultural irrigation shall comply with the following:
the minimum requirements for water quality laid down in Annex I to the regulation;
any additional conditions set by the competent authority in the relevant permit.
The reclamation facility operator shall ensure that, at the point of compliance, reclaimed water intended for agricultural irrigation complies with these requirements.
Cooperation between Member States
Before granting a permit, the competent authority shall exchange information on the conditions set out in Article 6(3) of the regulation with the contact point in the Member State in which reclaimed water is intended to be used.
Member States shall respond to requests for assistance without undue delay.
Information and awareness-raising
Member States shall ensure that adequate and up-to-date information on water reuse is available to the public, online or by other means.
Member States shall organise awareness-raising campaigns in order to increase the use of water reuse and to promote the benefits of safe water reuse.
Monitoring of implementation
Member States shall ensure that the Commission, the European Environment Agency and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control have access to the data sets referred to in Article 11(1) of the regulation.
On the basis of the data sets set up by Member States in accordance with Article 11(1), the European Environment Agency, in consultation with Member States, shall draw up, publish and update, on a regular basis or following a request from the Commission, a Union-wide overview.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 7 July 2022.
Member States shall apply the measures provided for in this regulation by 7 July 2022.
REFERENCES
Act
Entry into force
Deadline for implementation in the Member States
Regulation (EU) 2020/852
7.7.2022
7.7.2022
RELATED ACTS
Directive 2000/60/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2000 establishing a framework for the Community action in the field of water policy (WFD) (OJ C 371, 27.12.2018, pp. 1-31).

Summary 41:
attracting highly skilled workers from third countries
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) is trying to attract highly skilled workers from third countries (non-EU countries). To this end, it is setting up a single EU Blue Card for highly skilled workers from third countries. This is to be done by means of a new directive, which lays down the conditions for the admission of such workers and their family members to the EU territory.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes a single EU Blue Card for highly skilled workers from third countries (non-EU countries).
It lays down the conditions for admission and the rights of the holder of an EU Blue Card, as well as those of his or her family members.
It provides for a list of occupations for which the EU Blue Card may be issued.
It sets up a mechanism for the evaluation of the impact of the directive on the labour market and on the economy.
KEY POINTS
Conditions for admission and rights of the holder of an EU Blue Card
To be admitted, the third-country national must meet certain conditions:
have a highly skilled job offer (i.e. a job offer for a job that requires a high level of qualification);
earn a minimum gross annual salary, which may be lower in certain professions in certain Member States;
have a valid travel document;
have sickness insurance;
not pose a threat to public policy, public security or public health.
The holder of an EU Blue Card must have access to the labour market and may take up employment and pursue a self-employed activity, as well as access to education and vocational training.
Family members of an EU Blue Card holder may join him or her in the EU. They are entitled to equal treatment with nationals of the Member State where they reside, as regards employment and occupation, education, vocational training and childcare, taxation and social security.
Conditions for admission and rights of family members
The family members of the EU Blue Card holder must meet the following conditions:
they must be the spouse or life partner of the EU Blue Card holder;
they must be dependent on the EU Blue Card holder;
they must not be subject to a measure prohibiting entry and stay in the EU.
Family members of an EU Blue Card holder may join him or her in the EU. They are entitled to equal treatment with nationals of the Member State where they reside, as regards access to the labour market, access to education and vocational training, taxation and social security.
Conditions for admission and rights of the holder of an EU Blue Card in a second Member State
The holder of an EU Blue Card may move to a second Member State for the purpose of carrying out a business activity or for the purpose of highly qualified employment in that second Member State.
The holder of an EU Blue Card in a second Member State may be accompanied by his or her family members in that second Member State.
The holder of an EU Blue Card and his or her family members are entitled to equal treatment with nationals of the Member State where they reside, as regards access to the labour market, access to education and vocational training, taxation and social security.
Scope of the directive
The directive applies to third-country nationals who apply to be admitted to the territory of an EU country for the purpose of highly qualified employment under the directive.
It applies to third-country nationals who have been admitted to the territory of an EU country for the purpose of highly qualified employment under the directive.
It does not apply to third-country nationals who apply to reside in an EU country as researchers in order to carry out research projects.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 July 2021.
Member States had to incorporate it into national law by 1 July 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
The EU is trying to attract highly skilled workers from third countries. To this end, it is setting up a single EU Blue Card for highly skilled workers from third countries. This is to be done by means of a new directive, which lays down the conditions for the admission of such workers and their family members to the EU territory.
KEY TERMS
              
EU Blue Card
EU Blue Card holder
Family members

Summary 43:
Work-life balance for workers with children or caring responsibilities
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) has adopted a new directive on work-life balance for workers with children or caring responsibilities. The new directive provides for paternity leave, parental leave and carers' leave, as well as flexible working arrangements for workers with children or caring responsibilities.
WHAT DOES THE DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes minimum requirements designed to achieve equality between men and women with regard to labour market opportunities and treatment at work, by facilitating the reconciliation of work and family life for workers who are parents, or carers.
It provides for individual rights related to:
paternity leave, parental leave and carers’ leave;
flexible working arrangements for workers who are parents, or carers.
KEY POINTS
The directive provides for minimum rights in the following areas:
Paternity leave: fathers or equivalent second parents have the right to paternity leave of 10 working days that is to be taken on the occasion of the birth of the child. This right may be subject to a period of work qualification or to a length of service qualification, which shall not exceed 6 months.
Parental leave: each worker has an individual right to parental leave of 4 months that is to be taken before the child reaches a specified age, up to the age of 8, to be specified by each Member State or by collective agreement. The right to parental leave may be subject to a period of work qualification or to a length of service qualification, which shall not exceed 6 months.
Carers’ leave: each worker has the right to carers’ leave of 5 working days per year. This right may be subject to a period of work qualification or to a length of service qualification, which shall not exceed 6 months.
Flexible working arrangements: workers have the right to request that they take parental leave in flexible ways. The duration of such flexible working arrangements may be subject to a reasonable limitation. In the case of successive fixed-term contracts with the same employer, the sum of those contracts shall be taken into account for the purpose of calculating the qualifying period.
WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
The directive applies from 2 August 2022. Member States have until 2 August 2023 to bring into force the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary to comply with the directive.

Summary 44:
combatting fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU’s financial interests
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes minimum rules on criminal offences and sanctions for fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU’s financial interests.
KEY POINTS
This directive applies to all criminal offences covered by the 1995 EU Convention on the protection of the EU’s financial interests. It also covers fraud and other illegal activities that affect the EU’s financial interests.
It establishes minimum rules on criminal offences and sanctions in the area of fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU’s financial interests.
It introduces a definition of fraud affecting the EU’s financial interests that covers the following:
obtaining a financial advantage by deception, by collusion or by any other irregular means;
intentionally undermining or seriously threatening the budgetary discipline of the EU;
intentionally undermining or seriously threatening the budgetary discipline of a Member State or of a third country.
It also covers other criminal offences affecting the EU’s financial interests, such as:
active and passive corruption;
misappropriation;
money laundering.
It provides for sanctions with regard to natural persons, including a maximum penalty of at least 4 years of imprisonment in cases of serious offences.
It establishes the jurisdiction of the Member States for the criminal offences covered by the directive.
It provides for cooperation between the Member States and the European Commission (Eurojust and OLAF) and between the competent authorities of the Member States.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It applies from 6 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
The EU’s budget is one of the main instruments for achieving the EU’s objectives and is based on the principle of sound financial management. The EU budget provides for the common agricultural policy and common fisheries policy, and for investment in growth and jobs.
The EU’s budget is financed by own resources, which are shared by all EU countries. The EU’s budget is managed by the European Commission.
The 1995 EU Convention on the protection of the EU’s financial interests establishes minimum rules on criminal offences and sanctions in the area of fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU’s financial interests.
In 2013, the EU established the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO), which has been operational since 2017. The EPPO is responsible for investigating and prosecuting crimes that cause the greatest damage to the EU’s budget and financial interests, such as VAT fraud, fraud against the European Investment Fund and the European Investment Bank, and corruption.
WHEN DOES THIS DIRECTIVE APPLY?
From 6 July 2018.

Summary 45:
Regulation on interchange fees in card-based transactions
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It regulates the fees that banks charge each other for card payments made by customers.
It sets a maximum level for the fees that banks charge each other for debit card payments.
It also regulates the fees that banks charge for credit card payments.
It prohibits the ‘honour all cards’ rule and the steering practices used by banks to encourage consumers to use one card rather than another.
It also regulates the fees that banks charge each other for credit card payments.
It prohibits the ‘honour all cards’ rule and the steering practices used by banks to encourage consumers to use one card rather than another.
KEY POINTS
Interchange fees
Interchange fees are the fees that banks charge each other for card payments made by customers. They are paid when a customer uses a credit or debit card to pay for goods or services.
These fees are usually applied between the card-acquiring payment service providers and the card-issuing payment service providers belonging to a certain payment card scheme. The acquiring bank is the bank that handles the payment on behalf of the merchant.
The regulation sets a maximum level for the fees that banks charge each other for debit card payments. It also sets a maximum level for the fees that banks charge each other for credit card payments.
Domestic debit card transactions
Until 9 December 2018, Member States may apply a weighted average interchange fee of no more than 0.2 % of the annual average transaction value of all domestic debit card transactions within each payment card scheme.
Business rules
The regulation also regulates the rules that banks use to control how consumers pay for goods and services using a card.
These rules include:
the licensing of payment service providers;
the use of different payment brands or applications on a card-based payment instrument;
the information that must be provided to the payer and payee;
the information that must be provided to the payee about individual card-based payment transactions;
the use of steering practices that encourage consumers to use one card rather than another.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 9 December 2015.
BACKGROUND
In 2007, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a regulation on interchange fees for card-based consumer payments. The proposal was amended in 2009.
The Commission has since been working to reach an agreement with the European Parliament and the Council on the regulation.
For further information, see the Commission’s website.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 1275/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 October 2014 on multiannual EU programmes for economic and social cohesion (horizon 2020) (OJ C 411, 31.12.2014, pp. 2-4)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Staff Working Document SWD(2015) 114 final - Interchange fees in card-based transactions: Commission staff working document (OJ C 197, 27.6.2015, pp. 3-8)
