Summary 46:
European framework for transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings
European framework for transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings
SUMMARY OF:
Decision No 852/2012/EU on establishing a European framework for transparency of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION?
It establishes a European framework (Europass) to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering.
KEY POINTS
The decision provides for a Europass online platform that offers a variety of web-based tools for:
documenting and describing personal information in a variety of formats, including curriculum vitae (CV) templates;
documenting and describing skills and qualifications acquired through working and learning experiences, including through mobility and volunteering;
the assessment of skills and self-assessment of skills;
documenting the learning outcomes of qualifications, including the Europass supplement templates.
The Europass online platform provides available information on:
learning opportunities;
qualifications and qualifications frameworks or systems;
opportunities for validation of non-formal and informal learning;
services offering guidance for transnational learning mobility and career management;
skills intelligence as produced by relevant Union-level activities and agencies within their domains of competence;
information on skills and qualifications that could be relevant to the particular needs of third country nationals arriving or residing in the Union to support their integration.
The Europass online platform and web-based tools:
are accessible to persons with disabilities, in accordance with the accessibility requirements established in relevant Union law;
use open standards to be made available free of charge, for reuse by Member States and other stakeholders on a voluntary basis;
refer to the European Qualifications Framework (EQF) in information on qualifications, descriptions of national education and training systems and other relevant topics, as appropriate and in line with national circumstances;
support and ensure technical interoperability and synergies with other relevant instruments and services offered at Union and, where appropriate, national levels;
are delivered in the official languages of the institutions of the Union;
support authentication services for any digital documents or representations of information on skills and qualifications;
are developed in close cooperation with Member States and other stakeholders.
The templates for the Europass supplements shall be developed and, when necessary, revised by the Commission, in close cooperation and consultation with the Member States and other stakeholders such as the Council of Europe and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation to ensure relevance and usability of the supplements.
The Commission manages the Europass online platform and ensures the effective implementation of the decision. Each Member State is responsible for the implementation of the decision at national level through the relevant national services and without prejudice to national arrangements in terms of implementation and organisation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 23 May 2012.
BACKGROUND
              
Decision No 2241/2004/EC established a framework to address the challenges relating to job seeking, engaging in learning and career management.
The aim of that Decision was to achieve better transparency of qualifications and competences through a portfolio of documents known as ‘Europass’, which individuals can use on a voluntary basis.
It also established national bodies, known as National Europass Centres, in order to implement the Europass framework.
The Europass online platform is currently under construction and will be available in 2023.
For more information, please see the European Commission's website.
KEY TERMS
              
Europass
European framework to support the transparency and understanding of skills and qualifications acquired in formal, non-formal and informal settings, including through practical experiences, mobility and volunteering.

Summary 47:
EU statistics on inland waterways transport
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 165/2014 on EU statistics on inland waterways transport
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes common rules for the production of European statistics concerning inland waterways transport.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to inland waterways transport in the EU. It does not apply to the transport of goods by vessels of less than 50 deadweight tonnes, vessels used principally for the carriage of passengers, vessels used for ferrying purposes, vessels used solely for non-commercial purposes by port administrations and public authorities, vessels used solely for bunkering or storage, and vessels not used for the carriage of goods such as fishery vessels, dredgers, floating workshops, houseboats and pleasure craft.
Data
Member States must transmit data relating to inland waterways transport on their national territory to the European Commission (Eurostat). They must do so as soon as possible and no later than 5 months after the end of the relevant period of observation.
Inland waterways transport is an important part of the EU’s transport networks. The Commission therefore needs statistics on the transport of goods by inland waterways in order to monitor and develop the common transport policy.
Data collection
The Commission must arrange for pilot studies to be conducted on the availability of statistical data relating to passenger transport by inland waterways, including by cross border transport services. The EU contributes to the cost of carrying out those pilot studies in the form of grants awarded to the national statistical institutes and other national authorities.
Quality of data
Member States must take all measures necessary to ensure the quality of the data transmitted. The Commission (Eurostat) must assess the quality of the data transmitted.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 7 December 2016.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation is one of the EU’s statistics regulations which set out common rules for the production of European statistics.

Summary 48:
EU statistics on rail transport
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2018/1842 on the coordination of procedures for the award of public procurement contracts, concessions and licences by Member States and regional or local governments in the European Union
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It sets out common rules for the production of rail transport statistics at European Union (EU) level.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to all railways in the EU.
Each EU country must report statistics which relate to rail transport on its national territory.
Definitions
The regulation defines a number of terms, including:
railway: a line or system of lines designed for the carriage of passengers or goods, or both, by rail vehicles operated by one or more undertakings, on which service is regularly provided;
metro: a railway for the transport of passengers that operates in a dense urban area with high passenger traffic volumes, which uses fully automated or partly automated vehicles and which is usually fully segregated from other road traffic;
tram (streetcar): a passenger road vehicle designed to seat more than nine persons (including the driver), which is connected to electric conductors or powered by diesel engine and which is rail-borne;
light rail: a railway for the transport of passengers that often uses electrically powered rail-borne cars operating singly or in short trains on fixed duo-rail lines;
international transport: rail transport between a place (of loading/embarkation or unloading/disembarkation) located in the reporting country. It may involve transit through a second country;
transit: rail transport through the reporting country between two places (a place of loading/embarkation and a place of unloading/disembarkation) outside the reporting country. Transport operations involving loading/embarkation or unloading/disembarkation of goods/passengers at the border of the reporting country from/onto another mode of transport are not considered as transit;
rail passenger: any person, excluding members of the train crew, who makes a trip by rail. Only the distance on the national territory of the reporting country shall be taken into account;
goods: any material object that can be moved, shipped, carried or transferred from one location to another.
Reporting
EU countries must report statistics based on the data specified in the Annexes to the regulation. The Annexes specify the types of data to be collected, the type of transport, the type of consignment, the type of activity, the type of transport and the type of consignment.
Reporting under Annexes I and II is optional in respect of undertakings falling below the thresholds.
Reporting under Annexes III and IV is compulsory for undertakings covered by Annexes I and II.
Reporting under Annex V is compulsory for all railways in the EU.
Reporting under Annex VIII is compulsory for undertakings falling below the thresholds referred to in Annex VIII.
Reporting under Annexes IX and X is compulsory for all railways in the EU.
EU countries must transmit the statistics to Eurostat.
Eurostat is responsible for the dissemination of the statistics.
EU countries must take all measures necessary to ensure the quality of the data transmitted.
Eurostat will develop and publish methodological recommendations.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 December 2016.
BACKGROUND
              
Rail transport is an important part of the EU's transport networks. The EU's common transport policy aims to provide a coherent transport network, a competitive and environmentally friendly transport system, and safe and healthy transport for its citizens.
EU countries have different railway systems, which means that data on the sector are needed at EU level in order to monitor and develop the common transport policy.
For further information see: Rail transport statistics.
KEY TERMS
              
Railway: a line or system of lines designed for the carriage of passengers or goods, or both, by rail vehicles operated by one or more undertakings, on which service is regularly provided.
Metro: a railway for the transport of passengers that operates in a dense urban area with high passenger traffic volumes, which uses fully automated or partly automated vehicles and which is usually fully segregated from other road traffic.
Tram (streetcar): a passenger road vehicle designed to seat more than nine persons (including the driver), which is connected to electric conductors or powered by diesel engine and which is rail-borne.
Light rail: a railway for the transport of passengers that often uses electrically powered rail-borne cars operating singly or in short trains on fixed duo-rail lines.
International transport: rail transport between a place (of loading/embarkation or unloading/disembarkation) located in the reporting country. It may involve transit through a second country.
Transit: rail transport through the reporting country between two places (a place of loading/embarkation and a place of unloading/disembarkation) outside the reporting country. Transport operations involving loading/embarkation or unloading/disembarkation of goods/passengers at the border of the reporting country from/onto another mode of transport are not considered as transit.
Rail passenger: any person, excluding members of the train crew, who makes a trip by rail. Only the distance on the national territory of the reporting country shall be taken into account.
Goods: any material object that can be moved, shipped, carried or transferred from one location to another.

Summary 49:
visa rules for third-country nationals
SUMMARY
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to provide a better overview of the visa rules for third-country nationals and to ensure their uniform application throughout the European Union (EU).
KEY POINTS
This regulation codifies the visa rules for third-country nationals who wish to enter the EU for stays of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. It provides for a full harmonisation as regards the countries whose nationals are subject to a visa requirement and those whose nationals are exempt from it.
The regulation lists the countries whose nationals are subject to a visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the EU.
The regulation also lists the countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the EU.
The regulation provides for a reciprocity mechanism, which allows the European Commission to temporarily suspend the exemption from the visa requirement for certain categories of nationals of a third country if that country applies a visa requirement for nationals of an EU country.
The regulation also provides for a mechanism for the temporary suspension of the visa exemption for certain categories of nationals of a third country if the EU considers that the visa exemption is being abused.
The regulation also provides for a mechanism for the temporary suspension of the visa exemption for certain categories of nationals of a third country if the EU considers that the visa exemption is being abused.
The regulation repeals Regulation (EC) No 539/2001.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 14 April 2017.
BACKGROUND
The regulation codifies the visa rules for third-country nationals who wish to enter the EU for stays of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. It provides for a full harmonisation as regards the countries whose nationals are subject to a visa requirement and those whose nationals are exempt from it.

The regulation also lists the countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the EU.

The regulation also provides for a mechanism for the temporary suspension of the visa exemption for certain categories of nationals of a third country if the EU considers that the visa exemption is being abused.

Summary 50:
Eurojust — a new phase in the fight against serious crime
Eurojust — a new phase in the fight against serious crime
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 — establishing the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust)
WHAT IS THE REGULATION FOR?
It sets up a European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust), which is to support and coordinate cross-border investigations and prosecutions of serious crimes affecting 2 or more EU countries.
It repeals and replaces Decision 2002/187/JHA.
KEY POINTS
Eurojust’s tasks
Eurojust is to support and coordinate cross-border investigations and prosecutions of serious crimes affecting 2 or more EU countries.
It may also:
assist in investigations and prosecutions of certain crimes, including those committed against the EU’s financial interests;
act on its own initiative to coordinate cases.
To carry out these tasks, it is to:
support and coordinate national authorities and EU agencies;
support the work of the European Judicial Network;
support and coordinate joint investigation teams;
support and coordinate judicial cooperation in criminal matters;
support the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO);
support and coordinate the work of national authorities and EU agencies in the fight against terrorism.
Eurojust’s composition
It is composed of:
a College consisting of a President and 2 Vice-Presidents, elected for a term of 4 years, as well as 22 national members;
an Executive Board, composed of the President and Vice-Presidents, 1 representative of the European Commission and 2 other members of the College.
The national members are to be:
national experts seconded by each EU country, who are to be nationals of that country and have the necessary powers to cooperate with other national members and competent national authorities;
deputies and assistants, who are to assist the national members in the performance of their tasks.
National members and their deputies and assistants are to be bound by an obligation of confidentiality.
Eurojust’s powers
It may:
examine cases referred to it by national authorities, the EPPO or the European Commission;
act on its own initiative to coordinate cases;
cooperate with EU agencies, including Europol, and international organisations;
cooperate with the EPPO, the European Judicial Network and the European Judicial Training Network;
exchange information with the European Judicial Network;
cooperate with the European Judicial Network based on consultation and complementarity;
cooperate with the European Judicial Training Network based on consultation and complementarity;
cooperate with the EPPO based on consultation and complementarity.
It may also:
support the work of the European Judicial Network;
support and coordinate joint investigation teams;
support and coordinate judicial cooperation in criminal matters;
support the EPPO;
support and coordinate the work of national authorities and EU agencies in the fight against terrorism.
The European Commission and national authorities may request its opinion on legislative proposals, policies and strategies.
It may conclude working arrangements with third countries and international organisations.
It may also:
adopt rules of procedure;
adopt an annual work programme;
adopt an annual and multi-annual programming document;
adopt guidelines, policy documents and casework-related analyses.
Eurojust’s budget
The budget of Eurojust is to be adopted by the European Commission on the basis of a draft established by the Administrative Director, acting on a proposal from the Executive Board.
It is to be as accurate and as up-to-date as possible.
It may be adjusted by the European Commission on a proposal from the Executive Board.
It may be supplemented by voluntary contributions from EU countries.
Eurojust’s relations with other bodies
It is to:
support and coordinate joint investigation teams;
cooperate with the European Judicial Network;
cooperate with the European Judicial Training Network;
cooperate with the EPPO;
cooperate with the European Judicial Network based on consultation and complementarity;
cooperate with the European Judicial Training Network based on consultation and complementarity;
cooperate with the EPPO based on consultation and complementarity.
It may also:
support the work of the European Judicial Network;
support and coordinate joint investigation teams;
support and coordinate judicial cooperation in criminal matters;
support the EPPO;
support and coordinate the work of national authorities and EU agencies in the fight against terrorism.
It may conclude working arrangements with third countries and international organisations.
It may also:
adopt rules of procedure;
adopt an annual work programme;
adopt an annual and multi-annual programming document;
adopt guidelines, policy documents and casework-related analyses.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 July 2018.
It replaces Decision 2002/187/JHA from 18 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
Eurojust was established in 2003 under Decision 2002/187/JHA.
It is the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation, which supports and coordinates cross-border investigations and prosecutions of serious crimes affecting 2 or more EU countries.
It replaced the EU Council’s Terrorist Affairs Working Group (TAWG), which was established in 1999.
For more information, see the European Commission’s website on Eurojust.
KEY TERMS
              
National expert
A national expert seconded by an EU country to Eurojust who is to be a national of that country and has the necessary powers to cooperate with other national members and competent national authorities.
MAIN DOCUMENT

Summary 51:
EU action to combat money laundering and terrorist financing
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It aims to combat money laundering and terrorist financing by means of criminal law.
KEY POINTS
It sets minimum rules on criminal offences and sanctions in the area of money laundering.
It establishes a minimum level of penalties for the offences of money laundering and for the offence of aiding and abetting, inciting and attempting an offence of money laundering. It also establishes a minimum level of penalties for the offence of participation in an organised criminal group.
It ensures that certain types of money laundering are also punishable when committed by the perpetrator of the criminal activity that generated the property (‘self-laundering’).
It ensures that legal persons can be held liable for any of the offences of money laundering committed for their benefit by any person, acting either individually or as part of an organ of the legal person and having a leading position within the legal person.
It ensures that legal persons can be held liable where the lack of supervision or control by a person referred to in paragraph 1 of this Article has made possible the commission of any of the offences of money laundering for the benefit of that legal person by a person under its authority.
It ensures that each Member State takes the necessary measures to establish its jurisdiction over the offences of money laundering where:
the offence is committed in whole or in part on its territory;
the offender is one of its nationals.
KEY WORDS: money laundering, terrorist financing, criminal offence, penalty, legal person, confiscation, jurisdiction

Summary 52:
Multiannual plan for bluefin tuna
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a multiannual plan for the recovery of bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean.
KEY POINTS
The plan is designed to achieve a biomass of bluefin tuna corresponding to the maximum sustainable yield by 2022 with at least a 60 % probability of achieving that objective.
It sets out the conservation and management measures necessary to rebuild the bluefin tuna stock and to ensure its sustainable exploitation.
These measures include:
restrictions on fishing within certain areas and time periods;
a new minimum size for bluefin tuna;
measures concerning sport and recreational fishing activities;
farming and fishing capacity measures;
reinforcing the ICCAT scheme of joint international inspection.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2015.
BACKGROUND
              
The bluefin tuna is a highly migratory species that lives in the Mediterranean and the eastern Atlantic Ocean. It is an important fishery resource for the Mediterranean region.
The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) has adopted several recommendations on the recovery of bluefin tuna in the Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic, which are implemented by the Union through Regulation (EC) No 1883/2006.
KEY WORDS
              
bluefin tuna, ICCAT, multiannual plan
REFERENCES

Summary 53:
Shipbuilding Injurious Pricing (SIP) Regulation
Shipbuilding Injurious Pricing (SIP) Regulation
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2016/1039 on protection against injurious pricing of vessels from countries outside the European Union
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It lays down the rules for the European Commission to take measures against injurious pricing of vessels from countries outside the European Union (third countries) and the procedures for the imposition of injurious pricing charges.
KEY POINTS
The regulation provides for an effective means of protection against sales of vessels below their normal value which cause injury to the European Union (EU) industry.
It establishes a procedure for the imposition of an injurious pricing charge on the builder of any injuriously priced vessel whose sale to a buyer other than a buyer of the country in which the vessel originates causes injury.
It defines the principles and definitions of the regulation.
It lays down the conditions for the initiation of an investigation and the procedure for the imposition of an injurious pricing charge.
It establishes the procedure for the imposition of a countermeasure in the form of denial of loading and unloading rights in the EU.
It sets out the procedure for the collection of information and the treatment of confidential information.
It establishes the procedure for the imposition of an injurious pricing charge.
It establishes the procedures for the rejection of complaints or the initiation of proceedings.
The regulation does not preclude the application of any special rules laid down in agreements concluded between the EU and third countries or special measures provided that such action does not run counter to obligations pursuant to the Shipbuilding Agreement.
The regulation repeals Regulation (EC) No 385/96.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 May 2017.
It replaces Regulation (EC) No 385/96.
BACKGROUND
The regulation is part of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (ASCM), which provides that the special characteristics of shipbuilding have made it impractical to apply countervailing and anti-dumping duties.
The Shipbuilding Agreement sets out the basic principles and rules for the application of the ASCM in the shipbuilding sector.
The regulation codifies the Shipbuilding Injurious Pricing (SIP) Code, which constitutes Annex III to the Shipbuilding Agreement, and the Basic Principles of the SIP Code.
The regulation reflects the language of the SIP Code.
For more information, see the European Commission's website on the Shipbuilding Agreement.
KEY TERMS
              
Shipbuilding Injurious Pricing (SIP) Regulation
Shipbuilding Agreement
MAIN DOCUMENT
Commission Regulation (EU) 2016/1039 of 29 June 2016 on protection against injurious pricing of vessels from countries outside the European Union (OJ L 181, 30.6.2016, pp. 3-20)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EC) No 385/96 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 January 1996 on protection against injurious pricing of vessels from countries outside the European Union (OJ L 24, 30.1.1996, pp. 1-12)

Summary 55:
Accessibility of products and services
SUMMARY OF:
Directive (EU) 2019/882 on the accessibility of products and services
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE?
It aims to ensure that products and services available on the EU market are accessible to all, regardless of their abilities.
It lays down accessibility requirements for products and services, including electronic communications services, air, bus, rail and waterborne passenger transport services, and services providing access to audiovisual media services.
KEY POINTS
Accessibility requirements
The directive sets out accessibility requirements for products and services in Annex I. It is up to the Member States to transpose these into national legislation. These national measures must be in force by 28 June 2025.
The directive provides for a transitional period of 5 years, during which services providers may continue to provide their services using products which were lawfully used by them to provide similar services before 28 June 2025.
The directive does not cover:
products that are not intended for sale, rental or other distribution in commerce;
products that are intended for children under 16;
products that are intended for the sole use of institutions or organisations;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in the workplace;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in educational establishments;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in institutions;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in prisons;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in hospitals;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in psychiatric institutions;
products that are intended for the sole use of adults in old people’s homes.
Exemptions for microenterprises
Microenterprises are exempt from the directive’s requirements for products and services, provided they are genuine microenterprises as defined by Recommendation 2003/361/EC. This exemption is subject to certain conditions.
The directive provides for a system of conformity assessment and market surveillance to ensure that products and services are safe for consumers.
The European Commission is empowered to adopt delegated and implementing acts in certain cases.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DIRECTIVE APPLY?
It applies from 28 June 2019. It has to become law in the Member States by 28 June 2025.
BACKGROUND
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UN CRPD) calls on its parties to undertake or promote research and development of, and to promote the availability and use of, new technologies, including information and communications technologies, mobility aids, devices and assistive technologies, suitable for persons with disabilities.
The European Accessibility Act (EAA) is a legislative proposal that aims to ensure that products and services available on the EU market are accessible to all, regardless of their abilities.
The EAA is a key initiative to implement the UN CRPD in the EU. It will be a major step towards improving the lives of people with disabilities in the EU.
KEY TERMS
              
Accessible product: a product that is accessible to, and usable by, as many people as possible, including people with disabilities.
Accessible service: a service that is accessible to, and usable by, as many people as possible, including people with disabilities.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
            
Directive (EU) 2019/882 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 May 2019 on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of organisations and goods and services to consumers and amending Regulation (EU) No 910/2015 (OJ C 189, 24.5.2019, p. 1-39).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
            
Regulation (EU) No 910/2015 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 July 2015 on electronic identification and trust services for electronic transactions in the internal market and repealing Directive 1999/93/EC (OJ L 191, 28.7.2015, pp. 1-32).
Decision No 768/2008/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 July 2008 on a general framework for informing and advising consumers (OJ L 218, 3.9.2008, pp. 82-85).
Directive 2001/95/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 December 2001 on market surveillance and compliance of products (OJ L 15, 21.12.2001, pp. 1-17).
Decision No 165/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 establishing the European Parliament's and Council's Mobility Package (OJ L 157, 30.5.2014, pp. 1-5).
Directive 2008/57/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 June 2008 on the interoperability of the trans-European conventional and high speed rail system (OJ L 191, 23.7.2008, pp. 22-34).
Decision No 1323/2003/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 June 2003 establishing a Community programme on improving natural and technological disaster preparedness and assistance in the Community (OJ L 236, 22.9.2003, pp. 1-4).

Summary 56:
EU rules on conflict minerals
SUMMARY
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
              
It establishes a system for supply chain due diligence for minerals and metals (tin, tantalum, tungsten, gold, their ores and concentrates, as well as nickel, cobalt, manganese, aluminium, platinum, palladium, rhodium and other platinum group metals) to help prevent the financing of armed groups and security forces in resource-rich areas.
KEY POINTS
              
The regulation requires importers of these minerals and metals to identify and assess the risks in their supply chains and to take steps to mitigate them.
Importers must:
identify and assess the risks in their supply chains;
establish a management system to implement due diligence;
carry out risk mitigation efforts;
report on their due diligence policies and practices;
make available third-party audit reports.
The European Commission may recognise schemes that go further than the regulation’s requirements.
The Commission is responsible for ensuring the proper functioning of the system and may adopt delegated acts to establish and amend the volume thresholds of minerals and metals, and to set out the methodology and criteria for assessing due diligence schemes.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
In 2010, the United Nations adopted a resolution on conflict minerals and in 2012, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) published a due diligence guidance for responsible supply chains of minerals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
In 2010, the United Nations adopted a resolution on conflict minerals and in 2012, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) published a due diligence guidance for responsible supply chains of minerals from conflict-affected and high-risk areas.
KEY TERMS
              
Conflict-affected and high-risk areas: areas where armed groups and security forces are involved in the illegal exploitation of minerals or metals.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) 2017/821 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 2017 on trade in certain industrial minerals
REFERENCES
              
The regulation has codified Regulation (EU) No 474/2013.
ACTS DOCKET
              
See the consolidated version.

Summary 58:
EU customs enforcement of intellectual property rights
SUMMARY
The regulation provides for the enforcement of intellectual property rights in the EU customs territory.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out a procedure for the enforcement of intellectual property rights at the EU’s external borders and the conditions under which intellectual property rights holders may request customs authorities to enforce their rights.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to goods subject to customs supervision or control at the EU’s external borders and to goods found on the market, which have been disaggregated and delivered to retailers.
The regulation applies to goods which infringe intellectual property rights, including copyright, designs, trade marks, geographical indications, and trade secrets.
Intellectual property rights holders may request customs authorities to enforce their rights by submitting a written application to the competent customs authorities.
The application must contain the following information:
the intellectual property rights covered by the application;
the goods that are suspected of infringing those rights;
the competent authority entitled to submit the application;
the name and address of the holder of the decision and of the declarant or holder of the goods.
The holder of the decision must fulfil certain obligations, such as:
providing the competent customs authorities with the information necessary to identify the goods;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to contact the holder of the decision;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the intellectual property rights concerned;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the intellectual property rights concerned;
notifying the competent customs authorities of the initiation of proceedings to determine whether an intellectual property right has been infringed;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the competent judicial or administrative authorities entitled to initiate proceedings to determine whether an intellectual property right has been infringed;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the persons or entities entitled to submit an application concerning the alleged infringement of intellectual property rights;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the competent customs authorities entitled to submit an application;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the competent customs authorities entitled to initiate proceedings to determine whether an intellectual property right has been infringed;
providing the competent customs authorities with the information needed to identify the competent customs authorities entitled to initiate proceedings to determine whether an intellectual property right has been infringed;
reimbursing the costs incurred by the competent customs authorities.
The holder of the decision may be deemed to have agreed to the destruction of the goods in certain circumstances.
The regulation does not affect national or EU intellectual property rights law.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2015.
BACKGROUND
The regulation aims to protect intellectual property rights and to prevent the marketing of counterfeit and pirated goods in the EU.
For more information, see the European Commission’s website on customs enforcement of intellectual property rights.
KEY TERMS
Goods: units or sets of goods as defined in the Combined Nomenclature.
Intellectual property rights: rights related to intellectual property as defined in Article 4 of the TRIPS Agreement.
Infringing goods: goods which are suspected of infringing intellectual property rights.
Declarant: any person who is obliged by national legislation to complete and submit customs declarations.
Holder of the decision: the holder of the decision granting the application.
Application: a request submitted by the holder of the decision to the competent customs authorities for the enforcement of intellectual property rights.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 608/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 June 2013 concerning customs enforcement of intellectual property rights (OJ L 181, 13.7.2013, pp. 15-24)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Decision 2014/860/EU of 7 November 2014 establishing the forms for the application and for requesting the extension of the period during which customs authorities are to take action (OJ L 320, 9.12.2014, pp. 22-24)
last update 13.12.2016

WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the European Union (EU) Customs programme 2021-2027 (the programme), which aims to support the customs union and customs authorities working together and acting as one to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the EU from unfair and illegal trade, while facilitating legitimate business activity.

Summary 60:
European Social Fund Plus
The European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) is the European Union's (EU) biggest fund to support people in work, education and training, and to reduce poverty and social exclusion. The ESF+ is part of the EU's long-term budget for the 2021-2027 period.
WHAT DOES THE FUND DO?
It supports the EU's European Pillar of Social Rights, which sets out 20 key principles on equal opportunities and access to the labour market, fair working conditions, social protection and social inclusion. The ESF+ supports the EU's recovery from the COVID-19 crisis and helps to create more and better jobs.
It provides € 432 billion to the EU's 28 Member States, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein for the 2021-2027 period.
KEY FACTS
The ESF+ supports:
the European Pillar of Social Rights
the EU's recovery from the COVID-19 crisis and to create more and better jobs;
people in work, education and training;
to reduce poverty and social exclusion;
young people;
people with disabilities;
the most deprived people;
the social inclusion of third-country nationals;
the social economy;
social innovation;
the green and digital transitions;
the accessibility of social protection systems.
The ESF+ strand under shared management provides support for:
the specific objectives set out in Article 4(1), points (a) to (l) (i.e. employment and labour mobility, education, social inclusion, including contributing to poverty eradication, and promoting the social economy);
the specific additional allocation received by the outermost regions and the NUTS level 2 regions fulfilling the criteria laid down in Article 2 of Protocol No 6 on special provisions for Objective 6 in the framework of the Structural Funds in Finland, Norway and Sweden annexed to the 1994 Act of Accession (Protocol No 6).
The ESF+ strand under shared management supports the following specific objectives:
to promote the European Semester for economic policy coordination and to strengthen the social dimension of the European Semester by supporting the implementation of national reforms;
to improve the functioning of labour markets by supporting the modernisation of labour market institutions, such as the public employment services;
to support the transition from education to work by supporting the modernisation of vocational education and training and by supporting the modernisation of the youth guarantee;
to support youth employment and skills, including through the implementation of schemes under the Youth Guarantee;
to improve the accessibility of social protection systems by supporting the modernisation of social protection systems, in particular through the support of social services and social care;
to support the eradication of poverty by supporting the most deprived persons;
to support the social inclusion of third-country nationals;
to promote the social economy;
to support social innovation;
to support the green and digital transitions;
to support the industrial ecosystems;

Summary 63:
Transparency and registration of interest representatives
Transparency and registration of interest representatives
SUMMARY
The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree to establish a transparency register for interest representatives who seek to influence EU policy-making. The register will list all interest representatives who carry out certain types of activities, such as lobbying, with the objective of influencing the EU legislative process or the decision-making processes of the EU institutions.
WHAT DOES THIS AGREEMENT DO?
It establishes a transparency register for interest representatives who carry out certain types of activities, such as lobbying, with the objective of influencing the EU legislative process or the decision-making processes of the EU institutions.
The register is a joint undertaking by the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission.
It provides a comprehensive overview of interest representatives and their activities in the EU.
It ensures transparency and ethical conduct in the EU decision-making process.
KEY POINTS
The register lists organisations and self-employed individuals who represent the interests of citizens, businesses, professions, trade unions, non-governmental organisations or other groups.
It includes details such as:
the name of the entity;
the interests represented;
the annual costs of the covered activities;
the clients on behalf of whom covered activities are carried out;
the amount of each contribution they received exceeding 10 % of their total budget, if the contributions are above EUR 10 000, and the name of the contributor.
The register covers activities carried out by interest representatives with the objective of influencing the formulation or implementation of policy or legislation, or the decision-making processes of the EU institutions, without prejudice to Article 11(4) of the Treaty on European Union, concerning the European citizens’ initiative, and Article 227 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, concerning the right to petition the European Parliament.
It does not cover:
activities carried out by public authorities of EU countries, as well as by any association or network of such public authorities that acts on their behalf at EU, national or subnational level;
spontaneous meetings, meetings of a purely private or social character and meetings taking place in the context of an administrative procedure established by the TEU or the TFEU.
The register is mandatory for organisations and self-employed individuals engaged in EU policy-making and policy implementation.
The European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission agree to implement the coordinated approach with regard to the activities covered by the register.
The register will be managed by a joint operational structure, the secretariat of the register.
The European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission agree to finance the maintenance, development and promotion of the register.
WHEN DOES THIS AGREEMENT APPLY?
It applies from the date of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.
BACKGROUND
The European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission agree to establish a transparency register for interest representatives who seek to influence EU policy-making.
The register will list all interest representatives who carry out certain types of activities, such as lobbying, with the objective of influencing the EU legislative process or the decision-making processes of the EU institutions.
The register will provide a comprehensive overview of interest representatives and their activities in the EU.
The register will ensure transparency and ethical conduct in the EU decision-making process.
The register will be managed by a joint operational structure, the secretariat of the register.
The register will be financed by the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission.

Summary 65:
European Union recovery instrument
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Union Recovery Instrument (the Instrument) to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis.
It provides for a comprehensive set of measures, including technical and administrative assistance for their implementation.
KEY POINTS
Subject matter and scope
The Instrument is established to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. The measures referred to in the regulation shall be carried out under specific Union programmes and in accordance with the relevant Union acts laying down rules for those programmes whilst fully respecting the objectives of the Instrument.
Financing of the Instrument and allocation of funds
The Instrument is financed up to an amount of EUR 750 000 million in 2018 prices on the basis of the empowerment provided for in Article 5 of the Council Decision on the system of own resources of the European Union and repealing Council Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom (the Own Resources Decision).
For the purposes of implementation under the specific Union programmes, the amount referred to in the first subparagraph shall be adjusted on the basis of a fixed deflator of 2 % per year.
Rules for budgetary implementation
For the purpose of Article 21(5) of the Financial Regulation, EUR 384 400 million in 2018 prices, of the amount referred to in Article 2(1) of this Regulation, shall constitute external assigned revenue to the Union programmes referred to in point (a) of Article 2(2) of this Regulation and EUR 5 600 million in 2018 prices of that amount shall constitute external assigned revenue to the Union programmes referred to in point (c) of Article 2(2) of this Regulation.
EUR 360 000 million in 2018 prices, of the amount referred to in Article 2(1), shall be used for loans to Member States under the Union programmes referred to in point (b) of Article 2(2).
Commitment appropriations covering support to the Union programmes referred to in points (a) and (c) of Article 2(2) shall be made available automatically up to the respective amounts referred to in those points as of the date of entry into force of the Own Resources Decision which provides for the empowerment referred to in Article 2(1) of this Regulation.
Legal commitments giving rise to expenditure for support as referred to in point (a) of Article 2(2), and, where appropriate, in point (c) of Article 2(2), shall be entered into by the Commission or by its executive agencies by 31 December 2023. Legal commitments of at least 60 % of the amount referred to in point (a) of Article 2(2) shall be entered into by 31 December 2022.
Decisions on the granting of the loans referred to in point (b) of Article 2(2) shall be adopted by 31 December 2023. The Union’s budgetary guarantees up to an amount which, in accordance with the relevant provisioning rate set out in the respective basic acts, corresponds to the provisioning for budgetary guarantees referred to in point (c) of Article 2(2), depending on the risk profiles of the supported financing and investment operations, shall be granted only for supporting operations which have been approved by the counterparts by 31 December 2023. The respective budgetary guarantee agreements shall contain provisions requiring that financial operations corresponding to at least 60 % of the amount of those budgetary guarantees are approved by the counterparts by 31 December 2022.
Where provisioning for budgetary guarantees is used for non-repayable support related to the financing and investment operations referred to in point (c) of Article 2(2), the related legal commitments shall be entered into by the Commission by 31 December 2023.
Reporting
By 31 October 2022, the Commission shall submit to the Council a report on the progress achieved in the implementation of the Instrument and the use of the funds allocated in accordance with Article 2(2).
This Regulation shall not be applicable to or in the United Kingdom. References to ‘Member States’ in this Regulation shall not be understood to include the United Kingdom.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 May 2021.
BACKGROUND
The unprecedented measures taken in response to the exceptional situation caused by COVID-19, which is beyond the control of Member States, have caused significant disturbances to economic activity which are reflected in a steep decline in gross domestic product and a significant impact on employment, social conditions, poverty and inequalities. In particular, those measures have disrupted supply chains and production and caused absences from the workplace. In addition, the provision of many services has become very difficult or impossible. At the same time, consumer demand has dropped. Many businesses are experiencing liquidity shortages, and their solvency is at risk, while the financial markets are very volatile. Key sectors like travel and tourism are particularly hard hit.
The crisis caused by COVID-19 has spread quickly in the Union and in third countries. A sharp contraction of growth in the Union is foreseen for 2020. Recovery risks being very uneven in different Member States, increasing the divergence between national economies. The different fiscal abilities of Member States to provide financial support where it is needed most for recovery and the divergence between Member States’ measures endanger the single market as well as social and territorial cohesion.
A comprehensive set of measures is needed for economic recovery. That set of measures requires substantial amounts of public and private investment to set the Union firmly on the path towards a sustainable and resilient recovery, create high-quality jobs, support social inclusion and repair the immediate damage brought by the COVID-19 crisis, whilst supporting the Union’s green and digital priorities.
As this Regulation is an exceptional response to temporary but extreme circumstances, the support provided under it should only be made available for the purposes of addressing the adverse economic consequences of the COVID-19 crisis or the immediate funding needs to avoid a re-emergence of the COVID-19 crisis.
KEY WORDS
Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) – European Union Recovery Instrument (EURI) – Own resources – Financial Regulation.

Summary 66:
amending the Stability and Growth Pact
SUMMARY
Amending the Stability and Growth Pact
SUMMARY
Amending the Stability and Growth Pact
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to strengthen the economic governance of the euro area through the introduction of a new system of sanctions for the preventive and corrective parts of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP).
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out a system of sanctions for enhancing the enforcement of the preventive and corrective parts of the SGP in the euro area.
The preventive part of the SGP includes the multilateral surveillance system as organised by Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 (see summary). The corrective part of the SGP refers to the procedure for the avoidance of Member States’ excessive deficit as regulated by Article 126 TFEU and Regulation (EC) No 1467/97 (see summary).
Sanctions in the preventive part of the SGP
If the Council adopts a decision establishing that a Member State has failed to take action in response to a recommendation from the Commission, the Commission shall recommend that the Council require the Member State in question to lodge an interest-bearing deposit with the Commission amounting to 0.2 % of its GDP in the preceding year.
The Council may decide to reduce or cancel the deposit on the basis of a reasoned request from the Member State concerned. The Commission may also recommend reducing or cancelling the deposit on the basis of exceptional economic circumstances.
If the Council decides that the situation giving rise to the Council recommendation has come to an end, the deposit and the interest accrued thereon shall be returned to the Member State concerned.
Sanctions in the corrective part of the SGP
If the Council decides that a Member State has not taken effective action to correct its excessive deficit, the Commission shall recommend that the Council impose a fine on the Member State amounting to 0.2 % of its GDP in the preceding year. The fine shall be converted into a non-interest-bearing deposit if the Member State has already lodged an interest-bearing deposit with the Commission.
The Commission may also recommend reducing or cancelling the fine on the basis of exceptional economic circumstances or following a reasoned request from the Member State concerned.
If the Council decides to abrogate some or all of its decisions, the non-interest-bearing deposit shall be returned to the Member State concerned.
Sanctions concerning the manipulation of statistics
The Council may decide to impose a fine on a Member State that intentionally or by serious negligence misrepresents deficit and debt data relevant for the application of Articles 121 or 126 TFEU or for the application of the Protocol on the excessive deficit procedure annexed to the TEU and to the TFEU.
The fines shall be effective, dissuasive and proportionate to the nature, seriousness and duration of the misrepresentation. The amount of the fine shall not exceed 0.2 % of GDP of the Member State concerned.
The Commission may conduct investigations necessary to establish the existence of the misrepresentations. It may decide to initiate an investigation when it finds that there are serious indications of the existence of facts liable to constitute such a misrepresentation.
The Commission shall fully respect the rights of defence of the Member State concerned during the investigations.
The Commission may adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 11 concerning:
detailed criteria establishing the amount of the fine;
detailed rules concerning the procedures for the investigations, the associated measures and the reporting on the investigations;
detailed rules of procedure aimed at guaranteeing the rights of the defence, access to the file, legal representation, confidentiality and provisions as to timing and the collection of the fines.
The Court of Justice of the European Union has unlimited jurisdiction to review the decisions of the Council imposing fines under the regulation. It may annul, reduce or increase the fine so imposed.
The sanctions imposed pursuant to Articles 4 to 8 of the regulation are of an administrative nature.
The interest earned by the Commission on deposits lodged in accordance with Article 5 and the fines collected in accordance with Articles 6 and 8 shall constitute other revenue, as referred to in Article 311 TFEU, and shall be assigned to the European Financial Stability Facility. When the Member States whose currency is the euro create another stability mechanism to provide financial assistance in order to safeguard the stability of the euro area as a whole, the interest and the fines shall be assigned to that mechanism.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 13 December 2011.
BACKGROUND
The regulation strengthens the economic governance of the euro area through the introduction of a new system of sanctions for the preventive and corrective parts of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP).
In 2011, the Commission presented a report on the possibility of introducing euro-securities.
For further information see: Report on the possibility of introducing euro-securities (COM(2011) 814 final of 9.11.2011).
KEY TERMS
Preventive part of the SGP: the multilateral surveillance system as organised by Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 (see summary).
Corrective part of the SGP: the procedure for the avoidance of Member States’ excessive deficit as regulated by Article 126 TFEU and Regulation (EC) No 1467/97 (see summary).
RELATED ACTS

Summary 67:
Community statistics on population and housing
SUMMARY
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing.
KEY POINTS
Subject matter
The regulation establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing.
Scope
The regulation covers:
the number and characteristics of the population, including migration and international mobility, and the main demographic, social and economic characteristics of persons, families and households;
data on housing, including housing conditions and the environment, at a national, regional and local level.
Member States shall transmit to the Commission (Eurostat) the required data in electronic form.
The reference year is established in accordance with the regulation. It shall fall in a year specified by the Commission (Eurostat) in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny referred to in Article 8(3) of the regulation.
The Commission (Eurostat) shall adopt a programme of the statistical data and of the metadata to be transmitted to fulfil the requirements of the regulation, in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny referred to in Article 8(3) of the regulation.
Member States shall transmit to the Commission (Eurostat) the validated data and metadata in electronic form within 27 months of the end of the reference year.
Quality assessment
Member States shall provide the Commission (Eurostat) with a report on the quality of the data transmitted. In this context, Member States shall report on the extent to which the chosen data sources and methodology meet the essential features of population and housing censuses as defined in Article 2(i) of the regulation.
Implementation
The Commission (Eurostat) shall assess the quality of the data transmitted.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 June 2009.
BACKGROUND
The regulation establishes common rules for the decennial provision of comprehensive data on population and housing.
It covers:
the number and characteristics of the population, including migration and international mobility, and the main demographic, social and economic characteristics of persons, families and households;
data on housing, including housing conditions and the environment, at a national, regional and local level.
It lays down the conditions for the transmission of the data to the Commission (Eurostat).
It provides for the quality assessment of the transmitted data.
For further information please see the European Commission website.
KEY TERMS
Population
All persons who, according to the definition of usual residents, are living in the geographical area in question.
Housing
A building or part of a building which is used or intended for use as a place of human habitation, whether inhabited or not, and irrespective of whether it is owned by the inhabitants or rented by them.

Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament (7th parliamentary term)
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE RULES OF PROCEDURE?
The European Parliament’s Rules of Procedure set out the procedure to be followed in the work of the European Parliament and its committees and in the work of its political groups.
KEY POINTS
The European Parliament is the assembly elected pursuant to the Treaty on European Union and the Act of 20 September 1976 concerning the election of the members of the European Parliament by direct universal suffrage and national legislation deriving from the Treaties.
Each Member State has a number of seats in the European Parliament according to its population. The number of seats in the European Parliament is fixed at 751.
Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) exercise their mandate freely and independently, and are not bound by any instructions.
The European Parliament is composed of 751 MEPs, elected by direct universal suffrage for a 5-year term.
The European Parliament elects its President and Vice-Presidents for a 2½-year term. The President chairs the European Parliament and its committees, ensures the smooth running of the European Parliament’s work and represents the European Parliament in its relations with the European institutions, the Member States and other bodies and organisations.
The European Parliament’s committees are specialised in specific policy areas, and may be permanent or temporary. They assist the European Parliament in the performance of its activities and may table reports and draft resolutions on issues within their remit.
The European Parliament’s political groups are formed on the basis of political affinity by MEPs who are not bound by any instructions. They are the European Parliament’s main forum for political debate.

Summary 69:
Commission Decision (EU) 2018/1797 on the powers, tasks and organisation of the European Data Protection Supervisor
SUMMARY
The European Commission decided on the powers, tasks and organisation of the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS). The EDPS is an independent body set up by Regulation (EU) 2018/1725, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
WHAT DOES THE DECISION DO?
It defines the tasks and powers of the EDPS, as well as its organisation.
KEY POINTS
The EDPS’s mission is to ensure that the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals with respect to the processing of personal data are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies.
It ensures the application of the GDPR and other EU laws which provide for tasks and powers for the EDPS.
It also promotes the protection of personal data by cooperating with other national supervisory authorities and by monitoring the development of information and communication technologies.
The EDPS has the following powers:
to issue opinions on draft EU legal acts that relate to the protection of personal data;
to conduct investigations and to impose administrative fines;
to issue decisions on complaints;
to issue decisions on the notification of personal data breaches by EU institutions and bodies.
The EDPS is organised as follows:
the European Data Protection Supervisor decides the strategic priorities of the EDPS and adopts the policy documents corresponding to the tasks and powers of the EDPS;
the European Data Protection Supervisor determines the organisational structure of the EDPS secretariat;
the Director of the EDPS secretariat may delegate the exercise of the powers referred to in point 1 to the official responsible for the management of human resources;
the Director of the EDPS secretariat is the reporting officer for the Data Protection Officer, the Local Security Officer, the Local Information Security Officer, the Transparency Officer, the Legal Service Officer, the Ethics Officer and the Internal Control Coordinator for the tasks relating to these functions;
the Management Meeting comprises the European Data Protection Supervisor, the Director and the Heads of Units and Sectors and ensures strategic oversight of the work of the EDPS;
the Director of the EDPS secretariat may adopt the EDPS decisions on the application of the restrictions based on the EDPS internal rules implementing Article 25 of the GDPR;
the Management Meeting comprises the European Data Protection Supervisor, the Director and the Heads of Units and Sectors and ensures strategic oversight of the work of the EDPS;
the Director of the EDPS secretariat may delegate the exercise of the powers concerning financial matters as provided for in Articles 9 and 12;
the European Data Protection Supervisor may delegate to the Director, where appropriate and in accordance with the GDPR, the power to adopt and sign legally binding decisions, the substance of which has already been determined by the European Data Protection Supervisor;
the European Data Protection Supervisor may decide to contribute to the Union’s Framework Programmes and to serve on the advisory committees of research projects;
the European Data Protection Supervisor may refer the matter to the Court of Justice of the European Union, in case of non-compliance by an EU institution with the GDPR, in particular where the EDPS has not been consulted in cases provided for by Article 42(1) of the GDPR and in case of failure to effectively respond to enforcement action taken by the EDPS under Article 58 of the GDPR;
the EDPS may enter into cooperation agreements or service level agreements with other EU institutions, and may participate in inter-institutional calls for tenders resulting in framework contracts with third parties for the provision of support services to the EDPS and the EDPB;
the EDPS may take part upon invitation in an investigation by a supervisory authority or invite a supervisory authority to take part in an investigation in accordance with the legal and procedural rules applicable to the inviting party;
the EDPS may engage in mutual assistance in the investigative and enforcement actions of supervisory authorities of third countries or international organisations;
the EDPS may sign contracts with external service providers in accordance with the procurement rules applicable to the institutions;
the EDPS may further specify the provisions of this Decision by adopting implementing rules and supplementary measures relating to the functioning of the EDPS;
the EDPS may respond to any person addressing it on a matter falling within its competence in one of the official languages of the European Union in the same language used to address it.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2019.
BACKGROUND
              
The European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) is an independent body set up by Regulation (EU) 2018/1725, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
The EDPS’s mission is to ensure that the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals with respect to the processing of personal data are respected by the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies.
KEY TERMS
              
European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS)
Decision (EU) 2018/1797
Regulation (EU) 2018/1725
REFERENCES
              
Decision (EU) 2018/1797 of the Commission of 16 October 2018 on the powers, tasks and organisation of the European Data Protection Supervisor (OJ L 265, 29.10.2018, pp. 3-20).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 November 2017 (OJ L 295, 21.12.2017, pp. 24-54).

Summary 70:
Own resources of the European Union
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS DECISION DO?
It establishes the new own resources of the European Union (EU) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. The decision also introduces a new way of calculating the traditional VAT-based own resource, simplifying it and making it more transparent.
KEY POINTS
The EU has 7 own resources. These are: 3 traditional own resources (revenue from customs duties, sugar levies and agricultural levies),2 VAT-based own resources,1 GNI-based own resource and2 new own resources, based on plastic waste and carbon emissions.
The new own resources aim to support the EU’s priorities, in particular the single market, the European Green Deal, the Digital Single Market and the European Semester, and to support the EU’s policy priorities, in particular the Recovery and Resilience Facility.
The decision also introduces a new way of calculating the traditional VAT-based own resource. This simplifies the calculation of this resource and makes it more transparent.
The decision also introduces a temporary increase in the own resources ceilings for the allocation of the resources necessary for addressing the consequences of the COVID-19 crisis.
The new own resources are introduced at the same time as the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027. The Multiannual Financial Framework is the EU’s long-term budget.
WHEN DOES THIS DECISION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
The Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027 sets out the EU’s financial priorities for the next 7 years, which are to support the recovery from the COVID-19 crisis and to prepare for the future. It also sets out the EU’s financial priorities for the next 7 years, which are to support the recovery from the COVID-19 crisis and to prepare for the future. It introduces 2 new own resources, which will contribute to the financing of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027.
For more information, please see the factsheet on the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027.
KEY TERMS
Own resources: the revenue of the EU budget.

Summary 71:
EU tyre labelling – labelling and labelling requirements
EU tyre labelling – labelling and labelling requirements
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2018/983 on labelling and follow-up requirements for tyres
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It replaces Regulation (EC) No 1222/2009 on the labelling of tyres with respect to fuel efficiency and other essential parameters.
It establishes rules on the labelling of tyres and requirements for the market surveillance of tyres.
KEY POINTS
Scope
This regulation applies to C1 tyres, C2 tyres and C3 tyres that are placed on the market.
It does not apply to:
off-road professional tyres;
tyres designed to be fitted only on vehicles registered for the first time before 1 October 1990;
T-type temporary-use spare tyres;
tyres whose speed rating is less than 80 km/h;
tyres whose nominal rim diameter does not exceed 254 mm or is 635 mm or more;
tyres fitted with additional devices to improve traction properties, such as studded tyres;
tyres designed only to be fitted on vehicles intended exclusively for racing;
second-hand tyres, unless such tyres are imported from a third country.
Tyre labelling
The regulation establishes rules on the labelling of tyres and the requirements for the market surveillance of tyres.
Suppliers must ensure that tyres sold in the European Union (EU) bear the tyre label. The label indicates the tyre's rolling resistance, wet grip and external rolling noise performance, as well as whether the tyre is suitable for severe snow conditions and/or ice grip conditions.
Tyres placed on the market after 1 July 2021 must display the tyre label.
Tyre distributors must ensure that tyres placed on the market are accompanied by the tyre label.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation replaces Regulation (EC) No 1222/2009, which established rules on the labelling of tyres with respect to fuel efficiency and other essential parameters.
The new regulation aims to:
improve road safety;
reduce fuel consumption;
reduce traffic noise;
reduce the environmental impact of road transport;
reduce the environmental impact of road transport by reducing the release of microplastics.
KEY TERMS
              
Tyre label: a label that indicates the tyre's rolling resistance, wet grip and external rolling noise performance, as well as whether the tyre is suitable for severe snow conditions and/or ice grip conditions.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) 2018/983 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 May 2018 on labelling and follow-up requirements for tyres and amending Regulation (EC) No 443/2009 and Regulation (EC) No 517/1989 (OJ L 157, 27.6.2018, pp. 1-12).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
            
Regulation (EC) No 1222/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 on the labelling of tyres with respect to fuel efficiency and other essential parameters (OJ L 342, 22.12.2009, pp. 46-53).
Regulation (EC) No 661/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 July 2009 concerning type-approval requirements for the general safety of motor vehicles, their trailers and systems, components and separate technical units intended therefor (OJ L 200, 31.7.2009, pp. 1-130).

Summary 72:
EU Customs Control Equipment Fund
EU Customs Control Equipment Fund
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the EU Customs Control Equipment Fund (the ‘Instrument’).
It lays down the objectives of the Instrument and the rules for providing financial support for the purchase, maintenance and upgrading of customs control equipment.
KEY POINTS
The Instrument’s general objective is to support the customs union and customs authorities in their mission to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the EU from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity.
The Instrument’s specific objective is to support the purchase, maintenance and upgrading of customs control equipment for the purposes of non-intrusive inspection, indication of hidden objects on humans, radiation detection and nuclide identification, analysis of samples in laboratories, sampling and field analysis of samples, and detection of trace substances.
The financial envelope for the implementation of the Instrument for the period 2021–2027 is EUR 1 006 407 000 in current prices.
The Commission shall implement the Instrument under direct management in accordance with the Financial Regulation.
The Instrument shall be eligible for funding if the following requirements are met:
the action implements the objectives set out in Article 3;
the action supports the purchase, maintenance or upgrading of customs control equipment, including innovative detection technology equipment, that has one of the following customs control purposes:
non-intrusive inspection;
indication of hidden objects on humans;
radiation detection and nuclide identification;
analysis of samples in laboratories;
sampling and field analysis of samples;
detection of trace substances;
indicators to report on the progress of the Instrument towards the achievement of the general and specific objectives set out in Article 3.
The eligible entities are the customs authorities on condition that they provide the information necessary for the assessment of needs referred to in Article 11(4) of this Regulation.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts establishing the work programmes for the implementation of the Instrument. The work programmes shall set out:
for each action, the objectives pursued and the expected results, in accordance with the general and specific objectives set out in Article 3;
for grants, the maximum rate of co-financing referred to in Article 8.
The Commission shall adopt implementing acts establishing the work programmes for the implementation of the Instrument. The work programmes shall aim to achieve the objectives set out in Article 3.
When the action that is supported under the Instrument involves the purchase or upgrade of customs control equipment, the Commission shall set up a coordination mechanism to ensure the interoperability of the customs control equipment purchased with the support of Union programmes and instruments, and therefore its efficient use.
When the action that is supported under the Instrument involves the purchase or upgrade of customs control equipment, the Commission shall set up a coordination mechanism to ensure the interoperability of the customs control equipment purchased with the support of Union programmes and instruments, and therefore its efficient use.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts in accordance with Article 14 to amend Annex II with regard to the indicators where considered necessary, as well as to supplement this Regulation with provisions on the establishment of a monitoring and evaluation framework.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2021.
BACKGROUND
              
The EU Customs Control Equipment Fund (the ‘Instrument’) supports the customs union and customs authorities in their mission to protect the financial and economic interests of the EU and its Member States, to ensure security and safety within the EU and to protect the EU from illegal trade while facilitating legitimate business activity.
The Instrument supports the purchase, maintenance and upgrading of customs control equipment for the purposes of non-intrusive inspection, indication of hidden objects on humans, radiation detection and nuclide identification, analysis of samples in laboratories, sampling and field analysis of samples, and detection of trace substances.
KEYWORDS
              
Customs control equipment, customs control purposes, customs union, financial envelope, work programmes, financial support, grants.
