electricity market reform
SUMMARY
EU countries will gradually introduce changes to their energy markets in order to create a single, EU-wide market for electricity and gas.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It sets out the rules for the EU’s internal energy market for electricity, which will be completed by 2030.
It establishes a single EU-wide energy market for electricity, which is the first step towards a single EU-wide energy market for both electricity and gas.
It sets out the rules to ensure that the internal energy market for electricity is fully operational and efficient.
KEY POINTS
The internal market for electricity will be completed by 2030.
EU countries must ensure that all market participants can enter and exit the market.
EU countries must ensure that all market participants are treated in a fair and transparent manner.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants from the EU and those from third countries.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between public and private companies.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between producers, suppliers, traders and consumers.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants in terms of the type of energy they produce or consume.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants in terms of the type of energy they produce or consume.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants in terms of the type of energy they produce or consume.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants in terms of the type of electricity they produce or consume.
EU countries must ensure that there is no discrimination between market participants in terms of the type of electricity they produce or consume.

European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking
The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking (EuroHPC JU) will provide the EU with the computing power needed to maintain its research and industrial capacities at a leading edge.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the EuroHPC JU, which is a legal entity created under EU law with a legal personality and financial autonomy.
It establishes the legal framework for the EuroHPC JU, which will provide the EU with the computing power needed to maintain its research and industrial capacities at a leading edge.
KEY POINTS
The EuroHPC JU will provide a common strategic vision to design, develop and use the most innovative technologies in high performance computing (HPC) and quantum computing.
It will enable a co-design approach for the acquisition of world-class supercomputers, while safeguarding the security of the supply chain of procured technologies and systems.

Summary 75:
Climate neutrality by 2050
SUMMARY
The EU is committed to achieving climate neutrality by 2050, in line with its commitments under the Paris Agreement on climate change. This means reducing greenhouse gas emissions by sources and increasing greenhouse gas removals by sinks, such as forests, oceans and soils. The EU is also committed to ensuring that its economy and society are resilient to climate change.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out a binding objective of climate neutrality in the EU by 2050. It also sets a binding Union target of a net domestic reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.
KEY POINTS
The EU is committed to achieving climate neutrality by 2050, in line with its commitments under the Paris Agreement on climate change. This means reducing greenhouse gas emissions by sources and increasing greenhouse gas removals by sinks, such as forests, oceans and soils. The EU is also committed to ensuring that its economy and society are resilient to climate change.
The EU’s climate neutrality objective is to achieve a balance between greenhouse gas emissions and removals by 2050, in line with the Paris Agreement. This includes both emissions and removals of greenhouse gases regulated in EU law. This objective applies to all sectors of the economy, including energy, transport, buildings, agriculture, waste and land use. It also applies to the land use, land-use change and forestry sector.
The EU is committed to ensuring that its economy and society are resilient to climate change, by enhancing its adaptive capacity, strengthening its resilience and reducing its vulnerability to climate change. The EU is also committed to maximising the co-benefits of adaptation with other policies and legislation.
The EU is also committed to ensuring that the transition to a climate-neutral economy is socially fair and inclusive, leaving no one behind.
The EU’s 2030 climate target is to reduce its net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55 % compared to 1990 levels. The EU is committed to reviewing this target in the context of the review of its relevant climate and energy legislation, in order to enable it to achieve the climate-neutrality objective set out in this regulation.
The EU is also committed to ensuring that its economy and society are resilient to climate change, by enhancing its adaptive capacity, strengthening its resilience and reducing its vulnerability to climate change. Summary 76:
EU4Health programme — improving human health in the EU
The EU4Health programme aims to improve human health in the EU and to ensure a high level of protection of human health in all Union policies and activities.
WHAT DOES THE PROGRAMME DO?
The programme is established for the period 2021-2027 and has a budget of €2.4 billion.
It aims to improve human health in the EU and to ensure a high level of protection of human health in all Union policies and activities.
The programme supports actions in the following areas:
health promotion, disease prevention and addressing health inequalities;
responding to serious cross-border threats to health;
supporting access to safe and quality healthcare;
strengthening preparedness and response to health emergencies;
supporting international and global health initiatives;
improving health through digital and technological innovations;
improving the monitoring and surveillance of health risks and threats.
KEY TERMS
Health promotion, disease prevention and addressing health inequalities
The programme supports actions in the following areas:
promoting access to health services and related facilities and care for people with disabilities;
strengthening primary care and reinforcing the integration of care, with a view to providing universal health coverage and equal access to good quality healthcare;
promoting access to sexual and reproductive healthcare and supporting integrated and intersectional approaches to prevention, diagnosis, treatment and care;
promoting physical activity and supporting the development of evidence-based policies and programmes to promote healthy lifestyles;
supporting the development of evidence-based policies and programmes to prevent non-communicable diseases and their risk factors;

Summary 77:
Creative Europe Programme 2021-2027
The Creative Europe Programme aims to safeguard and promote cultural diversity and to increase the competitiveness of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector. It is part of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027.
WHAT DOES THE PROGRAMME DO?
It aims to safeguard and promote cultural diversity and to increase the competitiveness of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector.
It supports the following:
cultural and creative sectors to be more innovative and competitive in the global market;
the creation of works of cultural heritage and creativity;
the development of the European audiovisual industry;
the mobility of artists and cultural professionals;
the development of audiences across the EU;
the development of cultural and creative industries in third countries;
the development of cultural and creative industries in the EU’s neighbouring countries.
KEY ACTION AREAS
The programme is divided into three strands:
Culture: safeguarding and promoting cultural diversity, including the protection of cultural heritage, and promoting European values;
Media: promoting the competitiveness of the audiovisual sector;
Cross-sectoral: promoting the interconnections between cultural and creative sectors and supporting the role of culture in promoting the European values of solidarity, diversity and the rule of law.
The programme has a budget of €1.8 billion for 7 years.
KEY FACTS
The programme aims to support the cultural and creative sectors in the EU and its neighbouring countries.
It aims to safeguard and promote cultural diversity and to increase the competitiveness of the cultural and creative sectors, in particular the audiovisual sector.
It supports the following:
cultural and creative sectors to be more innovative and competitive in the global market;
the creation of works of cultural heritage and creativity;
the development of the European audiovisual industry;
the mobility of artists and cultural professionals;
the development of audiences across the EU;
the development of cultural and creative industries in third countries;
the development of cultural and creative industries in the EU’s neighbouring countries.
It covers the following strands:
Culture: safeguarding and promoting cultural diversity, including the protection of cultural heritage, and promoting European values;
Media: promoting the competitiveness of the audiovisual sector;
Cross-sectoral: promoting the interconnections between cultural and creative sectors and supporting the role of culture in promoting the European values of solidarity, diversity and the rule of law.
The programme has a budget of €1.8 billion for 7 years.
KEYWORDS
Culture, cultural diversity, cultural heritage, cultural and creative industries, audiovisual sector.

Summary 78:
Strategic Innovation Agenda 2021-2027 for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) is an EU agency that promotes innovation and entrepreneurship in Europe by supporting the development of new ideas and the creation of innovative products, services and business opportunities. The EIT is an important pillar of the European Union’s research and innovation programme Horizon Europe. The EIT aims to boost the innovation capacity of Europe by supporting the development of new ideas and the creation of innovative products, services and business opportunities. The EIT does this through its Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs), which bring together universities, research institutes, companies and entrepreneurs to develop new ideas and innovative solutions to major global challenges. The EIT also supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the Regional Innovation Scheme (RIS). The EIT supports the KICs in developing and implementing their multiannual strategies, which define their priorities and activities for the period from 2021 to 2027. The EIT is based in Budapest and has a network of 5 co-location centres across the EU.
WHAT DOES THE STRATEGIC INNOVATION AGENDA DO?
It sets out the priority fields and the strategy of the EIT for the period from 2021 to 2027.
It also reflects Regulation (EU) 2021/695, and, in particular, the key role of the EIT as part of Pillar III ‘Innovative Europe’ of Horizon Europe, and its contribution to addressing global and societal challenges, including established targets and commitments to climate objectives and the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to Pillar I ‘Excellent Science’ and Pillar II ‘Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness’ of Horizon Europe.
It builds on the lessons learnt over the previous years of operation of the EIT and the results of a wide consultation process with key stakeholders.
It contributes to tackling global and societal challenges, including the SDGs by following the principles of the Paris Agreement adopted under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (2), and to achieving a net-zero greenhouse gas economy by 2050 at the latest.
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the KICs, including through the involvement of new partners in other sectors, countries and regions, in order to address disparities in innovation capacity and to enhance knowledge and innovation diffusion across the EU.
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the RIS, which is intended to act as a catalyst for innovation and knowledge transfer by providing support for the KICs’ activities and by promoting the development of innovation ecosystems across the EU.
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the integration of the knowledge triangle, integrating higher education activities in the innovation value chain, which is a distinctive feature of the EIT compared to other innovation instruments.
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the promotion of an entrepreneurial culture and the creation of new businesses.
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the promotion of the EIT label, which is awarded to the KICs’ education programmes and which is expected to have a more structuring effect at all levels (individual, programme and institution).
It supports the innovation capacity of Europe through the promotion of the EIT as a one-stop shop for innovation, which facilitates the access of European Innovation Council (EIC) beneficiaries to the KICs’ innovation ecosystems and relevant actors of the knowledge triangle.
KEY FACTS:
Priority fields and strategy
The EIT’s priority fields and strategy for the period from 2021 to 2027 are to:
boost the innovation capacity of Europe by supporting the development of new ideas and the creation of innovative products, services and business opportunities;
support the integration of the knowledge triangle, integrating higher education activities in the innovation value chain, which is a distinctive feature of the EIT compared to other innovation instruments;
support the innovation capacity of Europe through the promotion of an entrepreneurial culture and the creation of new businesses;

Summary 79:
rules on labelling and selling of aromatised wine products
SUMMARY
Rules on labelling and selling of aromatised wine products
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down rules on the labelling and description of aromatised wine products and on the sales denominations of such products.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to all aromatised wine products placed on the market in the EU, whether produced in the EU or in third countries.
Aromatised wine products
Aromatised wine products are products obtained from products of the wine sector that have been flavoured. They may be sweetened or not, and may be flavoured with herbs or spices or fruit. They may be alcoholic or not, and may be flavoured with herbs or spices or fruit. They may be alcoholic or not, and may be sweetened or not.
The regulation defines 12 categories of aromatised wine products, which are set out in Annex II. These are: ‘Aromatised wine’, ‘Bitter aromatised wine’, ‘Egg-based aromatised wine’, ‘Sangria/Sangria’, ‘Clarea’, ‘Zurra’, ‘Bitter lemon’, ‘Glühwein’, ‘Maiwein’, ‘Maitrank’, ‘Aromatizovaný dezert’ and ‘Aromatised wine-product cocktail’.
The regulation lays down the sales denominations for each category of product.
Production processes and methods of analysis for aromatised wine products
The regulation lays down the requirements, restrictions and descriptions of the production processes for aromatised wine products. These are set out in Annex I.
The regulation also lays down the rules for the production, description, presentation and labelling of aromatised wine products with a geographical indication.
Geographical indications
A geographical indication identifies an aromatised wine product as originating in a region, a specific place or a country where a given quality, reputation or other characteristics of that product are essentially attributable to its geographical origin, including its terroir* and human factors.
The conditions for the protection of geographical indications are set out in Chapter IV of the regulation. They include a definition of geographical indication (Article 2(3)), and the conditions for eligibility (Article 10).
A geographical indication may be registered in the EU if it meets the conditions set out in this regulation and if it is not a homonymous* name.
EU geographical indications are listed in an electronic register, which is accessible to the public.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 27 March 2014.
BACKGROUND
              
The EU is a major producer of aromatised wine products, which are important for consumers, producers and the agricultural sector in the EU. By doing so, the measures will safeguard the reputation that the EU’s aromatised wine products have achieved in the internal market and on the world market by continuing to take into account the traditional practices used in the production of aromatised wine products as well as increased demand for consumer protection and information.
KEY TERMS
              
* Terroir: a combination of soil, climate and terrain that gives a product a distinctive character.
* Homonymous: names which have the same or a similar sound or spelling or which may suggest the same region or place of origin.
REFERENCES

Summary 81:
macro-financial assistance for Ukraine
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) is providing macro-financial assistance (MFA) to Ukraine in the form of loans with a view to supporting, in particular, its economic resilience and stability.
WHAT DOES THE DECISION DO?
It authorises the European Commission to make available to Ukraine a maximum of €1.2 billion in MFA.
KEY POINTS
The decision is without prejudice to the powers of the European Parliament and the Council as budgetary authority.
The Commission manages the MFA.
The MFA is provided in the form of loans, with a maximum average maturity of 15 years.
The release of the MFA is subject to the approval of the EU budget by the European Parliament and the Council.
The MFA is made available for a period of 12 months, starting on the first day after the entry into force of the memorandum of understanding (MOU) referred to in Article 3(1).
A precondition for granting the MFA is that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system, and the rule of law, and guarantees respect for human rights.
The Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) monitor the fulfilment of the precondition set out in Article 2(1) throughout the life-cycle of the MFA.
The Commission agrees with the Ukrainian authorities on clearly defined economic policy and financial conditions, focusing on structural reforms and sound public finances, to which the MFA is to be subject.
The Commission regularly monitors the progress in attaining those objectives.
The MFA is disbursed in two equal instalments, each of which consists of a loan.
The Commission decides on the release of each instalment, subject to the fulfilment of the following conditions:
the precondition set out in Article 2(1);
a continuous satisfactory track record of implementing a non-precautionary International Monetary Fund (IMF) credit arrangement;
the satisfactory implementation of the economic policy and financial conditions agreed in the MOU.
The Commission informs the European Parliament and the Council of developments relating to the MFA and provides them with the relevant documents.
The borrowing and lending operations related to the MFA are carried out in euro using the same value date and shall not involve the EU in the transformation of maturities, or expose the EU to any exchange or interest rate risk, or to any other commercial risk.
The MFA is implemented under direct management.
The Commission assesses, by means of an operational assessment, the soundness of Ukraine’s financial arrangements, the administrative procedures, and the internal and external control mechanisms which are relevant to the assistance.
The Commission is assisted by a committee.
The Commission submits to the European Parliament and to the Council a report on the implementation of the decision in the preceding year, including an evaluation of that implementation, by 30 June of each year.
The Commission submits to the European Parliament and to the Council an ex-post evaluation report, assessing the results and efficiency of the completed MFA and the extent to which it has contributed to the aims of the assistance, not later than 2 years after the expiry of the availability period referred to in Article 1(4).
The decision enters into force on the day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
It applies from 24 March 2022.
BACKGROUND
Ukraine has been a partner of the EU since 2014, when it signed an Association Agreement with the EU.
Ukraine is also covered by the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), which is designed to promote prosperity and peace in the EU’s neighbourhood.
Ukraine is facing a challenging economic and security environment, with the COVID-19 pandemic and the ongoing military conflict with Russia.
The MFA aims to support Ukraine’s economic stabilisation and aims to strengthen the immediate resilience of the country.
KEY TERMS
              
MFA: macro-financial assistance.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Decision (EU) 2022/349 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 March 2022 on providing macro-financial assistance to Ukraine (OJ C 156, 31.3.2022, pp. 1-4)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) 2021/947 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 June 2021 establishing the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe, amending and repealing Decision No 466/2014/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Regulation (EU) 2017/1601 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 480/2009 (OJ L 209, 14.6.2021, pp. 1-21).

Summary 82:
swordfish — multiannual recovery plan
SUMMARY
The aim of this Regulation is to implement the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish (Xiphias gladius) in the Mediterranean and Black seas. This recovery plan was adopted by the ICCAT at its 2016 annual meeting in Vilamoura, Portugal.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to ensure that Mediterranean swordfish are fished in a sustainable way, in order to allow the stock to recover.
KEY POINTS
The recovery plan sets out a number of measures for the fishing industry and recreational fisheries.
Fishing effort
A limit is placed on the number of fishing vessels allowed to fish for Mediterranean swordfish, depending on the type of fishing gear used.
The fishing season
A closure period is set, during which no fishing may take place for Mediterranean swordfish. This period is from 1 January to 31 March of each year. In addition, a closure period is set for longline vessels targeting Mediterranean albacore (Thunnus alalunga) from 1 October to 30 November of each year.
Minimum conservation reference size
The minimum conservation reference size for Mediterranean swordfish is 100 cm.
Technical characteristics of the fishing gear
The hook size of the fishing gear used to catch Mediterranean swordfish is limited to 7 cm in height.
Landings and transhipments
Landings and transhipments of Mediterranean swordfish must take place in designated ports, and the vessels carrying them must be authorised to do so.
Inspections
The Commission, or a body designated by it, may assign Union inspectors to the ICCAT scheme for joint international inspection, which is set out in Annex III to this Regulation.
Recreational fisheries
Only ‘rod and line’ vessels may be authorised to catch Mediterranean swordfish in recreational fisheries.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 15 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
Mediterranean swordfish (Xiphias gladius) is a large migratory species that is found in the Mediterranean and Black seas, as well as in the Atlantic Ocean. It is an important commercial species and is also highly prized in recreational fisheries.
Mediterranean swordfish has been overfished over the last 30 years and its current status does not allow it to produce the maximum sustainable yield in the short term. In order to allow the stock to recover, a multiannual recovery plan was adopted by the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) at its 2016 annual meeting in Vilamoura, Portugal.
This Regulation implements this recovery plan into Union law.
For further information, please see the factsheet on the ICCAT recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish.
KEY TERMS
              
Mediterranean swordfish: a species of fish of the Xiphias gladius genus, which is found in the Mediterranean and Black seas, as well as in the Atlantic Ocean.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) 2017/2107 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 November 2017 laying down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Convention area of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT), and amending Council Regulations (EC) No 1936/2001, (EC) No 1984/2003 and (EC) No 520/2007 (OJ L 315, 30.11.2017, pp. 1-23)
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 83:
Multiannual financial framework 2014–2020
SUMMARY
The multiannual financial framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020 (hereinafter referred to as the ‘MFF’) is set out in Regulation (EU) No 966/2012. This regulation determines the ceilings for expenditure and revenue for the general budget of the European Union (EU) for the period 2014-2020.
What is the MFF?
The MFF sets out the ceilings for expenditure and revenue for the general budget of the European Union (EU) for the period 2014-2020. It also provides for a number of specific instruments to ensure the flexibility of the MFF.
The MFF is a seven-year planning and programming tool for the EU. It ensures a stable and predictable framework for the implementation of the EU budget and for the planning of EU policies.
The MFF consists of:
—
a set of expenditure ceilings for each of the headings of the EU budget (smart and inclusive growth, sustainable growth: natural resources, security and citizenship, global Europe and administration);
—
an own-resources ceiling, which limits the total amount of own resources that can be collected from the EU countries.
The MFF also provides for a number of specific instruments to ensure the flexibility of the MFF. These instruments are the Emergency Aid Reserve, the European Union Solidarity Fund, the Flexibility Instrument, the European Globalisation Fund, the Contingency Margin, the specific flexibility to tackle youth unemployment and strengthen research and the global margin for commitments for growth and employment, in particular youth employment.
What is the purpose of the MFF?
The MFF is a seven-year planning and programming tool for the EU. It ensures a stable and predictable framework for the implementation of the EU budget and for the planning of EU policies.
The MFF sets the annual ceilings for expenditure for the different headings of the EU budget. These ceilings are based on the EU’s priorities and objectives. They are used to determine the appropriations for expenditure (commitments and payments) for each of the headings.
The MFF also sets the own-resources ceiling, which limits the total amount of own resources that can be collected from the EU countries.
The MFF also provides for a number of specific instruments to ensure the flexibility of the MFF. These instruments are the Emergency Aid Reserve, the European Union Solidarity Fund, the Flexibility Instrument, the European Globalisation Fund, the Contingency Margin, the specific flexibility to tackle youth unemployment and strengthen research and the global margin for commitments for growth and employment, in particular youth employment.
When does the MFF apply?
The MFF applies from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2020.
Revision of the MFF
The MFF may be revised in compliance with the own-resources ceiling set in Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom.
The Commission may present a proposal for revision of the MFF in the event of unforeseen circumstances that cannot be dealt with within the ceilings established as part of the MFF. It may also present such a proposal in the event of enlargement of the EU, of the revision of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), or of the reunification of Cyprus.
The MFF may also be revised in the event of:
—
an implementation of the budget;
—
measures linking effectiveness of funds to sound economic governance;
—
a revision of the TFEU;
—
an enlargement of the EU;
—
a reunification of Cyprus.

European Maritime and Fisheries Fund 2021-2027
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) for the period 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The EMFF supports the implementation of the common fisheries policy (CFP) and the European maritime policy.
It covers the following priorities:
fostering sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources;
fostering sustainable aquaculture activities and processing and marketing of fishery and aquaculture products, thus contributing to food security in the Union;
strengthening the competitiveness of the Union maritime and fisheries sectors;
promoting the sustainable development of coastal regions and their communities;
promoting a level-playing field for fishery and aquaculture products from the outermost regions;
promoting a level-playing field for the fishery and aquaculture sectors;
promoting clean and healthy seas and oceans;
promoting a blue economy;
promoting international ocean governance.
The EMFF supports the achievement of the following specific objectives:
promoting sustainable fisheries and the restoration and conservation of aquatic biological resources;

promoting a level-playing field for fishery and aquaculture products from the outermost regions;
promoting a level-playing field for the fishery and aquaculture sectors;
promoting clean and healthy seas and oceans;
promoting a blue economy;
promoting international ocean governance;

Summary 85:
EU action to conserve tuna and other species in the Eastern Pacific Ocean
EU action to conserve tuna and other species in the Eastern Pacific Ocean
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2021/5 on the conservation and management of fish stocks in the South-Eastern Pacific Ocean
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes rules to ensure the conservation and management of fish stocks in the South-Eastral Pacific Ocean.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to Union fishing vessels used or intended for use for the purposes of fishing in the area covered under the Convention on the Conservation and Management of Highly Migratory Fish Stocks in the South-East Pacific Ocean (the Convention).
This area is defined as the part of the Pacific Ocean bounded by the following lines:
the 50°S parallel from its intersection with meridian 150°W until the intersection with meridian 130°W;
the 4°S parallel from its intersection with meridian 150°W until the intersection with meridian 130°W.
Conservation and management measures
The regulation establishes the following measures:
closure periods for purse seine vessels for tropical tunas;
prohibition of fishing on data buoys;
measures for the protection of marine species;
scientific observers;
vessel requirements.
Closure periods for purse seine vessels for tropical tunas
The Commission is responsible for the following:
notifying the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) Secretariat of the applicable period of closure by 15 July each year;
informing all interested parties in its tuna industry of the closure;
ensuring that for the entire duration of the closure all purse seine vessels that fly its flag do not fish in the Convention area.
The Commission shall assess and, where applicable, forward the request to the IATTC Secretariat for consideration by the IATTC at the latest one month after the cessation of the cause of the force majeure.
Prohibition of fishing on data buoys
Masters of vessels shall ensure that their vessels do not interact with data buoys in the Convention area.
If fishing gear becomes entangled with a data buoy, the entangled fishing gear shall be removed with as little damage to the data buoy as possible.
Scientific research programmes formally notified to the IATTC may operate Union fishing vessels within one nautical mile of a data buoy, provided that those vessels do not interact with the data buoy or deploy fishing gear.
Union fishing vessels shall report daily information on all active FADs to the Commission at intervals submitted with a time delay of at least 60 days, but with a time interval of not more than 90 days between each report.
The operators of Union fishing vessels shall collect and report any interaction with FADs to Member States.
Protection of marine species
Elasmobranch species
It is prohibited to retain onboard, tranship, land, store, sell or offer for sale any part or whole carcass of:
oceanic whitetip sharks (Carcharhinus longimanus);
porbeagle sharks (Lamna nasus);
great hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna mokarran);
scalloped hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna lewini);
smooth hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna zygaena);
dusky sharks (Sphyrna tiburo);
silky sharks (Carcharhinus falciformis).
In addition, Mobulid rays (mobulids) shall be released alive, unharmed, and in a manner that causes the least harm to the extent practicable.
The Commission shall ensure that the following measures are implemented:
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of whale sharks (Rhincodon typus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of whale sharks (Rhincodon typus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of sea turtles in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of Mobulid rays (mobulids) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of silky sharks (Carcharhinus falciformis) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of great hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna mokarran), scalloped hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna lewini) and smooth hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna zygaena) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of porbeagle sharks (Lamna nasus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of dusky sharks (Sphyrna tiburo) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of oceanic whitetip sharks (Carcharhinus longimanus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of silky sharks (Carcharhinus falciformis) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of great hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna mokarran), scalloped hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna lewini) and smooth hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna zygaena) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of porbeagle sharks (Lamna nasus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of dusky sharks (Sphyrna tiburo) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of oceanic whitetip sharks (Carcharhinus longimanus) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of Mobulid rays (mobulids) in the Convention area;
the prohibition of the retention of, transhipment, landing, storage, sale or offer for sale of whole or parts of sea turtles in the Convention area;

Summary 86:
Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making
SUMMARY
Better law-making is the aim of this Interinstitutional Agreement. The agreement was signed by the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on 13 April 2016. It sets out a number of measures which the three institutions will take to improve the quality of EU legislation.
WHAT DOES THIS AGREEMENT DO?
It sets out a number of measures which the three institutions will take to improve the quality of EU legislation.
KEY POINTS
The three institutions agree to pursue better law-making by means of a series of initiatives and procedures, as set out in this agreement.
In exercising their powers and in compliance with the procedures laid down in the Treaties, and recalling the importance which they attach to the Community method, the three institutions agree to observe general principles of Union law, such as democratic legitimacy, subsidiarity and proportionality, and legal certainty.
They further agree to promote simplicity, clarity and consistency in the drafting of Union legislation and to promote the utmost transparency of the legislative process.
The Commission will engage in a dialogue with the European Parliament and the Council respectively, both before and after the adoption of its annual Work Programme (the Annual Programming – Commission Work Programme and interinstitutional programming).
Following the adoption of the Commission Work Programme and drawing on it, the three institutions will exchange views on initiatives for the coming year and agree on a joint declaration on annual interinstitutional programming (the joint declaration), to be signed by the presidents of the three institutions.
The three institutions will monitor, on a regular basis throughout the year, the implementation of the joint declaration.
To that end, the three institutions will participate in debates on the implementation of the joint declaration in the European Parliament and/or the Council during the spring of the year in question.
The Commission Work Programme will include major legislative and non-legislative proposals for the following year, including repeals, recasts, simplifications and withdrawals.
The Commission will take due account of, and respond to, the co-legislators' positions.
The Commission will regularly report to the European Parliament and to the Council on the implementation of its Work Programme for the year in question.
The three institutions agree on the positive contribution of impact assessments in improving the quality of Union legislation. Impact assessments are a tool to help the three institutions reach well-informed decisions and not a substitute for political decisions within the democratic decision-making process. Impact assessments should cover the existence, scale and consequences of a problem and the question whether or not Union action is needed.
The principles of subsidiarity and proportionality should be fully respected, as should fundamental rights.
Impact assessments should also address, whenever possible, the ‘cost of non-Europe’ and the impact on competitiveness and the administrative burdens of the different options, having particular regard to SMEs (‘Think Small First’), digital aspects and territorial impact.
The Commission will carry out impact assessments of its legislative and non-legislative initiatives, delegated acts and implementing measures which are expected to have significant economic, environmental or social impacts.
The European Parliament and the Council will, when they consider this to be appropriate and necessary for the legislative process, carry out impact assessments in relation to their substantial amendments to the Commission's proposal.
The Commission may, on its own initiative or upon invitation by the European Parliament or the Council, complement its own impact assessment or undertake other analytical work it considers necessary.
The three institutions are responsible for determining how to organise their impact assessment work, including internal organisational resources and quality control.
Public and stakeholder consultation is integral to well-informed decision-making and to improving the quality of law-making.
Without prejudice to the specific arrangements applying to the Commission's proposals under Article 155(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Commission will, before adopting a proposal, conduct public consultations in an open and transparent way, ensuring that the modalities and time-limits of those public consultations allow for the widest possible participation. The Commission will in particular encourage the direct participation of SMEs and other end-users in the consultations. This will include public internet-based consultations.
The results of public and stakeholder consultations shall be communicated without delay to both co-legislators and made public.
Ex-post evaluation of existing legislation
The three institutions confirm the importance of the greatest possible consistency and coherence in organising their work to evaluate the performance of Union legislation, including related public and stakeholder consultations. The Commission's evaluation planning will respect the timing for reports and reviews set out in Union legislation. Where appropriate, such requirements can include measurable indicators as a basis on which to collect evidence of the effects of legislation on the ground. The three institutions shall inform each other in good time before adopting or revising their guidelines concerning their tools for Better Law-Making (public and stakeholder consultations, impact assessments and ex-post evaluations).
The Commission will provide, in relation to each proposal, an explanation and justification to the European Parliament and to the Council regarding its choice of legal basis and type of legal act in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the proposal.
The three institutions agree that the choice of legal basis is a legal determination that must be made on objective grounds which are amenable to judicial review. The Commission shall continue to fully play its institutional role to ensure that the Treaties and the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union are respected.
The three institutions underline the important role played by delegated and implementing acts in Union law. It is the competence of the legislator to decide whether and to what extent to use delegated or implementing acts, within the limits of the Treaties.
The three institutions have agreed on a Common Understanding on Delegated Acts and on the related standard clauses (the Common Understanding), annexed hereto.
In accordance with the Common Understanding and with a view to enhancing transparency and consultation, the Commission commits to gathering, prior to the adoption of delegated acts, all necessary expertise, including through the consultation of Member States' experts and through public consultations.
Experts from the European Parliament and from the Council shall systematically have access to the meetings of Commission expert groups to which Member States' experts are invited and which concern the preparation of delegated acts.
The Commission may be invited to meetings in the European Parliament or the Council in order to have a further exchange of views on the preparation of delegated acts.
The Commission will carry out its role as facilitator by treating the two branches of the legislative authority equally, in full respect of the roles assigned by the Treaties to the three institutions. The three institutions will keep each other regularly informed throughout the legislative process about their work, about on-going negotiations among them and about any stakeholder feedback that they may receive, via appropriate procedures, including dialogue between them.
To that end, in the context of the legislative process, they will facilitate mutual exchange of views and information, including by inviting representatives of the other institutions to informal exchanges of views on a regular basis.
The European Parliament and the Council will, in the interest of efficiency, ensure a better synchronisation of their treatment of legislative proposals.
The three institutions agree to coordinate efforts to accelerate the legislative process while ensuring that the prerogatives of the co-legislators are respected and that the quality of legislation is preserved.
The three institutions acknowledge the importance of ensuring that each Institution can exercise its rights and fulfil its obligations enshrined in the Treaties as interpreted by the Court of Justice of the European Union regarding the negotiation and conclusion of international agreements.
The three institutions



Summary 87:
Citizens’ Initiative Regulation
SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the citizens’ initiative
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the procedure for the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI), a new right that gives European citizens the opportunity to ask the European Commission to propose new EU legislation.
KEY POINTS
Who can organise an ECI?
Citizens of one EU country cannot organise an ECI alone, but must form a committee of at least 7 citizens from 7 different EU countries.
Citizens must be of the age to vote in European Parliament elections.
Organisers may be individuals or organisations, such as political parties or non-governmental organisations (NGOs).
How does the ECI work?
The procedure is in 4 steps:
1. Organisers form a committee and submit the proposed ECI to the European Commission via an online register. The Commission then checks that the ECI meets the legal requirements and decides whether to register it.
2. The Commission registers the ECI if it meets the legal requirements and publishes it on the register.
3. The organisers then collect the necessary number of statements of support from citizens.
4. If the minimum number of statements of support is reached, the Commission examines the ECI and presents its conclusions to the European Parliament and the Council.
The Commission then decides whether to present the ECI to the European Parliament and the Council.
How many signatures are needed?
At least 1 million signatures from at least 1 million citizens from at least 1 quarter of EU countries.
The number of signatures needed is degressively proportional to the population of each EU country. The minimum number of signatures required in each EU country is set out in an annex to the regulation.
WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 May 2011.
BACKGROUND
The European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) was one of the ideas put forward in the White Paper on a new impetus for Europe, the European Commission’s plan to revitalize the EU.
It was then included in the Treaty of Lisbon which entered into force in 2009.
In 2011, the European Commission adopted this regulation, which sets out the procedure for the ECI, including the legal requirements for the ECI and the procedure for its examination by the Commission.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s Citizens’ Initiative website.
KEY TERMS
European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI)
The right for EU citizens to ask the European Commission to propose new EU legislation.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 February 2011 on the citizens’ initiative

EUROSTAT will collect data on pesticides placed on the market in the EU and used in agriculture.
EU countries must transmit the data to the European Commission (Eurostat) every 5 years.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a common framework for the production of EU statistics on the placing on the market and use of pesticides.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to pesticides which are plant protection products, for which substantial experience exists on data collection.
EU countries must collect and transmit to the Commission (Eurostat) data on:
the placing on the market of pesticides;
the quantities of pesticides used in agriculture.
EU countries must also collect data on:
the placing on the market of pesticides containing active substances included in Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009, and
the quantities of pesticides used in agriculture in agricultural holdings.
The Commission (Eurostat) will assess the quality of the data transmitted by EU countries. The appropriate technical format for the transmission of data will be adopted in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny.
The Commission (Eurostat) will publish and disseminate the data collected under this regulation, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 223/2009.
The Commission (Eurostat) will submit a report to the European Parliament and to the Council on the implementation of the regulation. The report will evaluate in particular the quality of the data transmitted, the data collection methods, the burden on businesses, agricultural holdings and national administrations and the usefulness of these statistics in the context of the Thematic Strategy on the Sustainable Use of Pesticides.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 June 2013.
BACKGROUND
The Thematic Strategy on the Sustainable Use of Pesticides aims to achieve a significant overall reduction of risks and the use of pesticides consistent with the necessary crop protection.
KEY TERMS
Pesticides: substances intended to be, or used as, a means for destroying, repelling or preventing pests.

Summary 89:
EU rules on pesticides
EU rules on pesticides
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes rules to ensure a high level of protection for both human and animal health and the environment against harmful effects of pesticides.
KEY POINTS
Active substances
The regulation defines active substances as substances which are deliberately added to plant protection products, including micro-organisms, to perform their intended function in protecting plants from harmful organisms, including weeds.
It provides for the first approval of active substances, which is limited in time to 10 years. The first approval may be renewed for a maximum of 15 years.
The regulation also provides for the approval of safeners and synergists, which are used to enhance the effectiveness of plant protection products, and of adjuvants, which are used to improve the performance of plant protection products.
It provides for the authorisation of plant protection products containing active substances approved under this regulation.
The regulation lays down rules for the authorisation of plant protection products containing active substances which are not approved under this regulation.
Assessment criteria
The regulation provides for a detailed procedure for assessing whether an active substance can be approved. The criteria for approval are the following:
the active substance or its plant protection product must be effective for the intended use and not pose a risk to human or animal health or the environment;
the active substance or its plant protection product must not be subject to restrictions under other EU legislation;
the active substance or its plant protection product must be produced in a manner that ensures its quality and the protection of human and animal health and the environment;
the plant protection product containing the active substance must be labelled and packaged in such a way as to protect human and animal health and the environment.
The procedure is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 4 sections.
First approval
The procedure for the first approval of an active substance is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 4 sections.
The first section concerns the application for the approval of an active substance. The application is submitted to the competent authority of a Member State, with a copy to the other Member States, the European Commission and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).
The second section concerns the assessment of the application for approval. The competent authority of the Member State that received the application (rapporteur Member State) checks the application and sends the complete dossier to the EFSA, which assesses the application and provides an opinion.
The third section concerns the approval of an active substance. The Commission adopts a regulation for the approval of an active substance, based on the opinion of the EFSA and taking into account the draft assessment report by the rapporteur Member State.
The fourth section concerns the review of the approval of an active substance. The regulation providing for the approval of an active substance is reviewed at the latest 15 years after its adoption. The review may be requested by a Member State or the Commission, or initiated by the Commission.
Renewal and review of approval
The procedure for the renewal of the approval of an active substance is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 3 sections.
The first section concerns the application for the renewal of the approval of an active substance. The application is submitted to the competent authority of a Member State, with a copy to the other Member States, the Commission and the EFSA.
The second section concerns the assessment of the application for renewal of the approval of an active substance. The competent authority of the Member State that received the application (rapporteur Member State) checks the application and sends the complete dossier to the EFSA, which assesses the application and provides an opinion.
The third section concerns the renewal of the approval of an active substance. The Commission adopts a regulation for the renewal of the approval of an active substance, based on the opinion of the EFSA and taking into account the draft assessment report by the rapporteur Member State.
Low-risk active substances
The regulation provides for a procedure for the approval of low-risk active substances, which are not predominantly used as plant protection products.
The procedure for the approval of low-risk active substances is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 4 sections.
The first section concerns the application for the approval of a low-risk active substance. The application is submitted to the competent authority of a Member State, with a copy to the other Member States, the Commission and the EFSA.
The second section concerns the assessment of the application for approval of a low-risk active substance. The competent authority of the Member State that received the application (rapporteur Member State) checks the application and sends the complete dossier to the EFSA, which assesses the application and provides an opinion.
The third section concerns the approval of a low-risk active substance. The Commission adopts a regulation for the approval of a low-risk active substance, based on the opinion of the EFSA and taking into account the draft assessment report by the rapporteur Member State.
The fourth section concerns the review of the approval of a low-risk active substance. The regulation providing for the approval of a low-risk active substance is reviewed at the latest 15 years after its adoption. The review may be requested by a Member State or the Commission, or initiated by the Commission.
Safeners and synergists
The regulation provides for a procedure for the approval of safeners and synergists.
The procedure for the approval of safeners and synergists is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 3 sections.
The first section concerns the application for the approval of a safener or a synergist. The application is submitted to the competent authority of a Member State, with a copy to the other Member States, the Commission and the EFSA.
The second section concerns the assessment of the application for approval of a safener or a synergist. The competent authority of the Member State that received the application (rapporteur Member State) checks the application and sends the complete dossier to the EFSA, which assesses the application and provides an opinion.
The third section concerns the approval of a safener or a synergist. The Commission adopts a regulation for the approval of a safener or a synergist, based on the opinion of the EFSA and taking into account the draft assessment report by the rapporteur Member State.
Adjuvants
The regulation provides for a procedure for the authorisation of adjuvants.
The procedure for the authorisation of adjuvants is based on a stepwise process, which is divided into 3 sections.
The first section concerns the application for the authorisation of an adjuvant. The application is submitted to the competent authority of a Member State, with a copy to the other Member States, the Commission and the EFSA.
The second section concerns the assessment of the application for authorisation of an adjuvant. The competent authority of the Member State that received the application (rapporteur Member State) checks the application and sends the complete dossier to the EFSA, which assesses the application and provides an opinion.
The third section concerns the authorisation of an adjuvant. The Commission adopts a regulation for the authorisation of an adjuvant, based on the opinion of the EFSA and taking into account the draft assessment report by the rapporteur Member State.
Authorisation of plant protection products
The regulation provides for a procedure for the authorisation of plant protection products.
The procedure for the author



Summary 90:
Internal Market Information System (IMI)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the Internal Market Information System (IMI) which facilitates administrative cooperation between EU countries.
KEY POINTS
The IMI is a secure online platform that allows EU countries’ competent authorities to exchange information and data. It is available in all official EU languages.
The IMI is available to competent authorities of EU countries as well as the European Commission. It is designed to support the implementation of EU legislation on administrative cooperation in the internal market.
The IMI helps the competent authorities to identify their counterpart in another EU country, to manage the exchange of information and to overcome language barriers. It also allows the competent authorities to overcome language barriers by providing pre-defined and pre-translated workflows.
The Commission is responsible for the IMI’s technical management, the security of the system and the training and technical assistance to the IMI users.
The Commission is also responsible for the appointment of the national IMI coordinators, as well as for the registration of the IMI coordinators and the competent authorities in the IMI.
The IMI may be expanded in the future to new areas, where it can help to ensure effective implementation of a Union act in a cost-efficient, user-friendly way, taking account of technical feasibility and overall impact on IMI.
The IMI was first established in 2011 to facilitate the posting of workers in the internal market.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies since 5 July 2015.
BACKGROUND
The IMI was first established in 2011 to facilitate the posting of workers in the internal market. It was then expanded to support administrative cooperation in other areas of the internal market, such as consumer protection, energy and taxation.
The Commission is planning to expand the IMI to other areas, where it can help to ensure effective implementation of a Union act in a cost-efficient, user-friendly way, taking account of technical feasibility and overall impact on IMI.

Summary 91:
EU fisheries: implementing GFCM recommendations
SUMMARY
The EU implements recommendations from the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) which are designed to protect sensitive habitats and species in the Mediterranean and Black Seas.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down the rules for the application by the EU of the conservation, management, exploitation, monitoring, marketing and enforcement measures for fishery and aquaculture products established by the GFCM.
KEY POINTS
The regulation covers the Mediterranean and Black Seas and the waters connecting them, as defined in the preamble to the GFCM agreement.
It implements 3 recommendations from the GFCM:
a ban on fishing with towed dredges and bottom trawl nets in certain areas to protect sensitive habitats in the Mediterranean;
a ban on fishing with towed dredges and trawl nets at depths beyond 1 000 m;
a closed season for the dolphinfish fisheries using fish aggregating devices from 1 January to 14 August each year.
The EU also implements 2 other recommendations from the GFCM:
a ban on fishing with towed dredges and bottom trawl nets in the deep-sea fisheries restricted area ‘Lophelia reef off Capo Santa Maria di Leuca’;
a ban on the use of towed dredges and trawl nets in the Black Sea.
The EU implements these recommendations through a fishing authorisation system, a register of vessels, port state measures, a register of authorised vessels, a register of vessels, a register of vessels of more than 15 metres in overall length authorised to fish in the GFCM area, and a register of vessels of more than 15 metres in overall length authorised to fish in the GFCM area.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The GFCM agreement provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels which are considered sustainable and at low risk of collapse.

Summary 92:
Regulation (EU) No 1257/2012 on the creation of unitary patent protection
Uniform patent protection within the internal market, or at least a significant part thereof, should feature amongst the legal instruments which undertakings have at their disposal.
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It implements enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection, authorised by Decision 2011/167/EU.
KEY POINTS
The unitary patent protection system is designed to facilitate access to patent protection and to make the patent system less costly and legally secure.
It is designed to cover all the participating Member States.
A European patent granted with the same set of claims in respect of all the participating Member States shall benefit from unitary effect in the participating Member States provided that its unitary effect has been registered in the Register for unitary patent protection.
A European patent with unitary effect shall have a unitary character. It shall provide uniform protection and shall have equal effect in all the participating Member States. It may only be limited, transferred or revoked, or lapse, in respect of all the participating Member States. It may be licensed in respect of the whole or part of the territories of the participating Member States.
The unitary effect of a European patent shall be deemed not to have arisen to the extent that the European patent has been revoked or limited.
A European patent with unitary effect shall take effect in the participating Member States on the date of publication by the EPO of the mention of the grant of the European patent in the European Patent Bulletin.
The participating Member States shall take the necessary measures to ensure that, where the unitary effect of a European patent has been registered and extends to their territory, that European patent is deemed not to have taken effect as a national patent in their territory on the date of publication of the mention of the grant in the European Patent Bulletin.
The rights conferred by a European patent with unitary effect shall not extend to acts concerning a product covered by that patent which are carried out within the participating Member States in which that patent has unitary effect after that product has been placed on the market in the Union by, or with the consent of, the patent proprietor, unless there are legitimate grounds for the patent proprietor to oppose further commercialisation of the product.
A European patent with unitary effect as an object of property shall be treated in its entirety and in all the participating Member States as a national patent of the participating Member State in which that patent has unitary effect and in which, according to the European Patent Register:
—
the applicant had his residence or principal place of business on the date of filing of the application for the European patent; or
—
where point (a) does not apply, the applicant had a place of business on the date of filing of the application for the European patent.
The participating Member States shall ensure compliance with this Regulation in fulfilling their international obligations undertaken in the EPC and shall cooperate to that end. To that end they shall set up a select committee of the Administrative Council of the European Patent Organisation (hereinafter ‘Select Committee’) within the meaning of Article 145 of the EPC.
The Select Committee shall consist of the representatives of the participating Member States and a representative of the Commission as an observer, as well as alternates who will represent them in their absence. The members of the Select Committee may be assisted by advisers or experts.
The participating Member States shall ensure effective legal protection before a competent court of one or several participating Member States against the decisions of the EPO in carrying out the tasks referred to in paragraph 1.
The expenses incurred by the EPO in carrying out the additional tasks given to it, within the meaning of Article 143 of the EPC, by the participating Member States shall be covered by the fees generated by the European patents with unitary effect. Renewal fees for European patents with unitary effect and additional fees for their late payment shall be paid to the European Patent Organisation by the patent proprietor.
A European patent with unitary effect shall lapse if a renewal fee and, where applicable, any additional fee have not been paid in due time.
The level of renewal fees shall be set at a level that:
—
is equivalent to the level of the renewal fee to be paid for the average geographical coverage of current European patents;
—
reflects the renewal rate of current European patents; and
—
reflects the number of requests for unitary effect.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It entered into force on 19 December 2012.
It applies from 1 January 2014 or the date of entry into force of the Agreement on a Unified Patent Court (the ‘Agreement’), whichever is the later.
BACKGROUND
The European Union is home to a single market that facilitates the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. The single market is one of the European Union’s greatest achievements.
The internal market comprises an area without internal frontiers in which the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital is ensured.
KEY TERMS
European patent
A patent granted under the Convention on the Grant of European Patents of 5 October 1973, as revised on 17 December 1991 and on 29 November 2000.
Unitary patent protection
Uniform patent protection within the internal market, or at least a significant part thereof, which is conferred on a European patent with unitary effect.
European patent with unitary effect
A European patent granted with the same set of claims in respect of all the participating Member States which benefits from unitary effect in the participating Member States provided that its unitary effect has been registered in the Register for unitary patent protection.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 1257/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2012 with regard to the creation of unitary patent protection (OJ L 316, 14.11.2013, pp. 12-21)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Decision 2011/167/EU of the Council of 10 March 2011 authorising enhanced cooperation between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Estonia, Ireland, Greece, France, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection (OJ L 76, 22.3.2011, pp. 53-54)
last update 23.04.2015



Summary 93:
EU Observatory on infringements of intellectual property rights
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It entrusts the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) with tasks aimed at facilitating and supporting the activities of national authorities, the private sector and the Union institutions in the fight against infringements of the intellectual property rights covered by Directive 2004/48/EC.
KEY POINTS
The OHIM is entrusted with the following tasks:
improving understanding of the value of intellectual property;
improving understanding of the scope and impact of infringements of intellectual property rights;
enhancing knowledge of best public and private sector practices to protect intellectual property rights;
assisting in raising citizens’ awareness of the impact of infringements of intellectual property rights;
assisting in raising consumers’ awareness of the risks of purchasing counterfeit goods;
improving the protection of intellectual property rights on the internet;
developing, in consultation with the Member States, programmes for the provision of technical assistance to third countries as well as developing and delivering specific training programmes and events for officials from third countries who are involved in the protection of intellectual property rights;
making recommendations to the Commission on issues falling within the scope of this Regulation, on the basis of a request from the Commission;
carrying out similar activities necessary in order to enable the OHIM to fulfil the tasks set out in paragraph 1.
In carrying out the tasks and activities referred to in Articles 2(1) and 2(2), the OHIM shall comply with existing provisions of Union law on data protection.
The OHIM shall at all times ensure that the activities entrusted to it by this Regulation are carried out by making use of its own budgetary means.
The OHIM shall at least once per year invite to meetings of the Observatory representatives from public administrations, bodies and organisations in the Member States dealing with intellectual property rights and representatives from the private sector, for the purpose of their participation in the OHIM’s work under this Regulation.
The OHIM shall publish on its website the names of the representatives attending, the agenda and the minutes of the meetings of the Observatory.
As appropriate, in accordance with national law, including the law governing the processing of personal data, Member States shall, at the request of the OHIM or on their own initiative:
inform the OHIM of their overall policies and strategies on the enforcement of intellectual property rights and any changes thereto;
provide available statistical data on infringements of intellectual property rights;
inform the OHIM of important case-law.
The OHIM shall adopt an annual work programme that appropriately prioritises the activities under this Regulation and for the meetings of the Observatory, in line with the Union’s policies and priorities in the field of protection of intellectual property rights and in cooperation with the representatives referred to in point (a) of Article 4(5) of this Regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 6 June 2012.
BACKGROUND
              
The constant increase in infringements of intellectual property rights constitutes a genuine threat not only to the EU economy, but also, in many cases, to the health and safety of EU consumers. Therefore, effective, immediate and coordinated action at national, European and global levels is needed to successfully combat this phenomenon.
The EU Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights (the Observatory) was established in 2009 to ensure an adequate and sustainable infrastructure for the fulfilment of its tasks. The Observatory was originally named the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy.
The Observatory is a centre of excellence on information and data relating to infringements of intellectual property rights, by benefiting from the OHIM’s expertise, experience and resources.
The tasks of the Observatory include the following:
improving understanding of the value of intellectual property;
improving understanding of the scope and impact of infringements of intellectual property rights;
enhancing knowledge of best public and private sector practices to protect intellectual property rights;
assisting in raising citizens’ awareness of the impact of infringements of intellectual property rights;
assisting in raising consumers’ awareness of the risks of purchasing counterfeit goods;
improving the protection of intellectual property rights on the internet;
developing, in consultation with the Member States, programmes for the provision of technical assistance to third countries as well as developing and delivering specific training programmes and events for officials from third countries who are involved in the protection of intellectual property rights;
making recommendations to the Commission on issues falling within the scope of this Regulation, on the basis of a request from the Commission;
carrying out similar activities necessary in order to enable the OHIM to fulfil the tasks set out in paragraph 1.
The OHIM also works closely with the national authorities to ensure that the relevant information is collected and disseminated.
For more information, please see the OHIM’s website.
KEY TERMS
              
Intellectual property rights: rights that result from intellectual activity in the industrial, scientific, literary or artistic fields. These rights, such as patents, trademarks and copyrights, give protection to works that are the product of creative human endeavour.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) No 626/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 June 2012 establishing the European Union Intellectual Property Office and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2866/95 (OJ L 178, 20.6.2012, pp. 1-8)
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 94:
Safeguarding the EU’s rights in international trade
SUMMARY
The EU has the right to defend its interests under international trade agreements. To this end, the EU may take certain measures against countries that breach international trade rules, which affect the EU’s interests.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It gives the European Commission the right to adopt measures to enforce the EU’s rights under international trade agreements. The Commission may suspend concessions or other obligations in the following situations:
when a third country breaches international trade rules that affect the EU’s interests;
when the treatment accorded to goods from the EU is altered in a way that affects the EU’s interests.
KEY POINTS
The regulation covers goods, services, intellectual property rights and public procurement.
The Commission must determine the appropriate commercial policy measures, which may include the following:
suspension of concessions or other obligations;
a mandatory price penalty on goods or services;
prohibition of the import or export of certain goods;
restrictions on the import of certain services;
restrictions on the export of certain services;
prohibition of the use of certain intellectual property rights.
The Commission must repeal the measures if the third country concerned accords adequate and proportionate compensation to the EU.
The Commission must review the scope and functioning of this regulation no later than 3 years after the first instance of its implementation or no later than 5 years from its date of entry into force, whichever is the earlier.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 18 July 2016.
BACKGROUND
The EU has the right to defend its interests under international trade agreements. To this end, the EU may take certain measures against countries that breach international trade rules, which affect the EU’s interests.
The regulation gives the Commission the right to adopt measures to enforce the EU’s rights under international trade agreements. The Commission may suspend concessions or other obligations in the following situations:
when a third country breaches international trade rules that affect the EU’s interests;
when the treatment accorded to goods from the EU is altered in a way that affects the EU’s interests.
KEY TERMS
              
Safeguard measure: a measure to protect domestic producers from being harmed by an increase in imports of a good.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 1031/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 October 2012 concerning the examination by the Commission of national legislation on the enforcement of intellectual property rights (OJ L 295, 6.11.2012, pp. 1-4)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1032/2012 of 18 October 2012 on the examination of national legislation on the enforcement of intellectual property rights (OJ L 295, 6.11.2012, pp. 5-6)
Commission Decision 2013/469/EU of 17 September 2013 on the examination of national legislation on the enforcement of intellectual property rights (OJ L 249, 18.9.2013, pp. 1-2)
