Summary 95:
EU-Central America Trade Agreement (CAE) – implementing rules
EU-Central America Trade Agreement (CAE) – implementing rules
SUMMARY
The EU-Central America Trade Agreement (CAE) aims to strengthen political and economic relations between the EU and Central America. The agreement sets up a free trade area, but also includes rules on trade defence measures and the environment and social aspects of trade.
The CAE provides for a bilateral safeguard clause and a stabilisation mechanism for bananas, which are implemented through this regulation.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules and procedures for the implementation of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the CAE.
KEY POINTS
The bilateral safeguard clause
The bilateral safeguard clause may be applied where imports of a product originating in Central America are imported into the EU in such increased quantities, in absolute terms or relative to Union production, and under such conditions as to cause, or threaten to cause, serious injury to the EU industry.
The safeguard measures may take one of the following forms:
—
a suspension of a further reduction of the rate of customs duty on the product concerned provided for in the Tariff Elimination Schedule;
—
an increase in the rate of customs duty on the product concerned to a level which does not exceed the lesser of:
—
the most-favoured-nation (MFN) applied rate of customs duty on the product in effect at the time the measure is taken; or
—
the MFN applied rate of customs duty on the product in effect on the day immediately preceding the date of entry into force of the Agreement.
The Commission must monitor the evolution of import statistics of bananas from Central American countries and may decide to adopt prior surveillance measures in regard to imports from a Central American country where:
—
the trend in imports of a product is such that it could lead to one of the situations referred to in Articles 2 and 4; or
—
there is a surge of imports of bananas concentrated in one or several Member States, or in one or several of the EU’s outermost regions.
The Commission may adopt prior surveillance measures in accordance with the advisory procedure referred to in Article 14(2) of this regulation.
The Commission may adopt provisional safeguard measures in accordance with the advisory procedure referred to in Article 14(4) of this regulation in cases of imperative grounds of urgency, including the case referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 7 of this regulation.
The Commission may adopt definitive safeguard measures in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 14(3) of this regulation where the facts as finally established show that the conditions set out in Article 2(1) of this regulation are met.
The Commission may adopt prior surveillance measures in accordance with the advisory procedure referred to in Article 14(2) of this regulation where there is a surge of imports of bananas concentrated in one or several Member States, or in one or several of the EU’s outermost regions.
The Commission may adopt provisional safeguard measures in accordance with the advisory procedure referred to in Article 14(4) of this regulation in cases of imperative grounds of urgency, including the case referred to in paragraph 2 of Article 7 of this regulation.
The Commission may adopt definitive safeguard measures in accordance with the examination procedure referred to in Article 14(3) of this regulation where the facts as finally established show that the conditions set out in Article 2(1) of this regulation are met.
The duration and review of safeguard measures
A safeguard measure may be imposed only for such period of time as may be necessary to prevent or remedy the serious injury to the EU industry and to facilitate adjustment. That period may not exceed 2 years, unless it is extended under paragraph 3.
A safeguard measure may be imposed only for such period of time as may be necessary to prevent or remedy the serious deterioration in the economic situation of one or several of the EU’s outermost regions, as referred to in Article 349 TFEU. That period may not exceed 2 years, unless it is extended under paragraph 3.
The initial period of duration of a safeguard measure may be extended by up to 2 years provided that the safeguard measure continues to be necessary to prevent or remedy serious injury to the EU industry and that there is evidence that the EU industry is adjusting.
The total duration of a safeguard measure may not exceed 4 years, including any provisional safeguard measure.
No safeguard measure may be applied to the import of a product that has previously been subject to such a measure, unless a period of time equal to half of that during which the safeguard measure was applied for the immediately preceding period has elapsed.
The stabilisation mechanism for bananas
A separate annual trigger import volume is set for imports of products falling under heading 0803 00 19 of the Combined Nomenclature (fresh bananas, excluding plantains) and listed under category ‘ST’ in the Tariff Elimination Schedule.
The importation of the products referred to in paragraph 1 at the preferential customs duty rate shall be subject to the presentation of an export certificate issued by the competent authority of the Republic of the Central American country from which the products are exported.
Where the Commission decides to suspend the preferential customs duty applicable, it may apply the lesser of the base rate of customs duty or the MFN rate of duty that in application at the time such action is taken.
The measures referred to in paragraphs 2 and 4 shall be applicable only during the period ending on 31 December 2019.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from the date of application of the Agreement.
BACKGROUND
The EU-Central America Trade Agreement (CAE) aims to strengthen political and economic relations between the EU and Central America. The agreement sets up a free trade area, but also includes rules on trade defence measures and the environment and social aspects of trade.
The CAE provides for a bilateral safeguard clause and a stabilisation mechanism for bananas, which are implemented through this regulation.
For further information, please see the factsheet on the EU-Central America Free Trade Agreement.
KEY TERMS
Bilateral safeguard clause: a clause that allows the EU to impose a safeguard measure on imports from Central America.
Safeguard measure: a measure taken by the EU to prevent or remedy the serious injury to the EU industry or to prevent or remedy the serious deterioration in the economic situation of one or several of the EU’s outermost regions.
Stabilisation mechanism for bananas: a mechanism that allows the EU to suspend the preferential customs duty applicable to bananas from Central America.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 20/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 January 2013 implementing the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the Agreement establishing an Association between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Central America, of the other part (OJ L 22, 24.1.2013, pp. 27-36)
Joint Declaration (OJ L 22, 24.1.2013, pp. 13-14)

Summary 96:
A Regulation on a European Enforcement Order for bank accounts
A Regulation on a European Enforcement Order for bank accounts
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a new European procedure for the preservation of funds held in bank accounts in cross-border cases. It allows, in cross-border cases, for the preservation, in an efficient and speedy way, of funds held in bank accounts in order to secure a creditor’s claim against a debtor.
KEY POINTS
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION COVER?
The Regulation applies to bank accounts. It does not cover accounts which are immune from seizure under the law of the Member State in which the account is maintained nor to accounts maintained in connection with the operation of any system as defined in point (a) of Article 2 of Directive 98/26/EC.
The Regulation applies to cross-border cases only and defines what constitutes a cross-border case in this particular context. For the purposes of this Regulation, a cross-border case is considered to exist when the court dealing with the application for the Preservation Order is located in one Member State and the bank account concerned by the Order is maintained in another Member State.
The Regulation applies to:
a creditor who has a claim against a debtor who has a bank account in another Member State and
the debtor who has a bank account in another Member State.
The Regulation does not apply to claims against a debtor in relation to whom bankruptcy proceedings, proceedings for the winding-up of insolvent companies or other legal persons, judicial arrangements, compositions, or analogous proceedings have been opened.
WHEN DOES IT APPLY?
The Regulation applies from 10 August 2015.
BACKGROUND
In 2006, the Commission launched a consultation on the need for a uniform European procedure for the preservation of bank accounts and the possible features of such a procedure.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 10 August 2015.

Summary 97:
rules for border surveillance at sea
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) and its Member States are working to prevent unauthorised border crossings, to counter cross-border criminality and to apprehend or take other measures against those persons who have crossed the border in an irregular manner.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down rules for border surveillance operations at sea by Member States in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex).
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to border surveillance operations at sea conducted by Member States at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by Frontex.
The purpose of border surveillance is to prevent unauthorised border crossings, to counter cross-border criminality and to apprehend or take other measures against those persons who have crossed the border in an irregular manner.
When coordinating border surveillance operations at sea, Frontex must comply with relevant EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (‘the Charter’) and other relevant international instruments.
When coordinating border surveillance operations at sea, Frontex must fulfil its tasks in full compliance with relevant EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (‘the Charter’), and relevant international law, in particular that referred to in recital 8.
When coordinating border surveillance operations at sea, Frontex must fulfil its tasks in full compliance with relevant EU law, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (‘the Charter’), and relevant international law, in particular that referred to in recital 8.
The regulation does not apply to border surveillance operations carried out by Member States at their internal borders or at their land borders with third countries.
Member States must ensure that all measures taken for the purpose of a border surveillance operation are conducted in a way that, in all instances, ensures the safety of the persons intercepted or rescued, the safety of the participating units or that of third parties.
Member States and Frontex must ensure that all measures taken for the purpose of a border surveillance operation are conducted in a way that, in all instances, ensures the safety of the persons intercepted or rescued, the safety of the participating units or that of third parties.
When considering the possibility of disembarkation in a third country, in the context of planning a border surveillance operation, the host Member State, in coordination with participating Member States and Frontex, takes into account the general situation in that third country.
Member States and Frontex must ensure that intercepted or rescued persons are not disembarked, forced to enter, conducted to or otherwise handed over to the authorities of a third country when the host Member State or the participating Member States are aware or ought to be aware that that third country engages in practices as described in Article 4(1).
Member States and Frontex must ensure that throughout a border surveillance operation, the participating units address the special needs of children, including unaccompanied minors, victims of trafficking in human beings, persons in need of urgent medical assistance, disabled persons, persons in need of international protection and other persons in a particularly vulnerable situation.
The regulation applies from 20 July 2018.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
The purpose of border surveillance is to prevent unauthorised border crossings, to counter cross-border criminality and to apprehend or take other measures against those persons who have crossed the border in an irregular manner.
Border surveillance activities are carried out by Member States at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Frontex).
KEY TERMS
              
Sea operation: a coordinated border surveillance operation at sea by Member States at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by Frontex.

Summary 98:
general rules on the management and control of the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Internal Security Fund
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down general rules for the implementation of the European Commission’s Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and the Internal Security Fund (ISF). It sets out the principles of assistance and the responsibilities of the Commission and the EU countries in ensuring the application of these principles.
KEY POINTS
The AMIF and ISF support actions which pursue the objectives of the EU, as set out in the relevant regulations, and result in added value for the EU. The Commission and the EU countries must ensure that the support provided under these funds is consistent with the relevant activities, policies and priorities of the EU and is complementary to other EU instruments.
The Commission and the EU countries must carry out their respective roles in relation to this regulation and the relevant regulations with the aim of reducing the administrative burden for beneficiaries, the EU countries and the Commission, taking into account the principle of proportionality.
The EU countries must organise a partnership with relevant authorities and bodies to perform the role set out in the regulation. The partnership may vary at different stages of the programme.
The Commission and the EU countries must carry out a dialogue at the level of senior officials, taking into account the relevant indicative timeframes laid down in the regulation, to define the objectives of the national programmes.
The EU countries must submit a national programme, which describes how they intend to achieve the objectives of the relevant regulation, to the Commission.
The Commission must ensure that the support provided under the AMIF and the ISF is consistent with the relevant activities, policies and priorities of the EU and is complementary to other EU instruments.
The EU countries must ensure that their management and control systems for national programmes are set up in accordance with this regulation and that these systems function effectively.
The EU countries must designate a responsible authority to manage and control expenditure under the national programmes. The Commission must approve the designation of the responsible authority within 3 months of receiving the formal request.
The EU countries must ensure that the support provided under the national programmes is non-profit-making and does not receive any funding from other sources covered by the EU budget.

European Fund for Asylum, Migration and Integration
The European Fund for Asylum, Migration and Integration (AMIF) is the European Union's (EU) largest financial instrument in the area of migration and asylum. It supports EU countries in managing migration flows and in implementing, strengthening and developing the Common European Asylum System (CEAS) and the Common European Asylum Policy (CEAP).
WHAT DOES THE FUND DO?
The AMIF supports EU countries in managing migration flows and in implementing, strengthening and developing the CEAS and the CEAP.
It supports EU countries in developing, monitoring and evaluating their asylum policies, as well as supporting new approaches concerning access to asylum procedures in a safer manner.
The AMIF supports EU countries in developing, monitoring and evaluating their integration policies, as well as supporting new approaches in integration, including in the area of access to employment, education and housing.
The AMIF supports EU countries in developing, monitoring and evaluating their return policies, as well as supporting new approaches in return, including in the area of access to voluntary return.
KEY FACTS
The AMIF provides support to EU countries in the following areas:
asylum and international protection;
legal migration and integration;

Summary 100:
Instrument for financial support for internal security
The Instrument for financial support for internal security is established as part of the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for the period from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2020. The ISF comprises two separate instruments: the Instrument for financial support for internal security and the Instrument for financial support for external borders and visa.
ACT
Regulation (EU) No 105/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2012 establishing an Instrument for the implementation of the Internal Security Fund for the period 2014-2020
REFERENCES
Official Codex
C 98, 7.4.2013, p. 1-14
Consolidated Codex
C 201, 7.8.2013, p. 1-14
RELATED ACTS
Regulation (EU) No 515/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2014 establishing as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for external borders and visa and repealing Decision No 574/2007/EC
Decision No 574/2007/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 June 2007 establishing the Specific Programme for Public Security and State Borders and repealing Decision No 1750/2000/EC
Decision No 1750/2000/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 July 2000 establishing the Specific Programme for preventive research, preparedness and response.
BACKGROUND
The European Union (EU) faces a number of security challenges, such as international crime, terrorism, organised crime, illegal immigration, trafficking of human beings and cybercrime. The Internal Security Strategy for the European Union (ISS) adopted in 2011 sets out the common principles and guidelines to tackle these challenges.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes the Instrument for financial support for internal security as part of the Internal Security Fund (ISF) for the period from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2020. The ISF comprises two separate instruments: the Instrument for financial support for internal security and the Instrument for financial support for external borders and visa.
The Instrument for financial support for internal security is intended to contribute to ensuring a high level of security in the EU.
KEY POINTS
The general objective of the Instrument is to contribute to ensuring a high level of security in the EU. It also contributes to the financing of technical assistance at the initiative of the Member States and the Commission.
The Instrument supports actions in the following areas:
—
strengthening coordination and cooperation between law enforcement authorities,
—
preventing and combating crime,
—
protecting people and critical infrastructure against security-related incidents,
—
enhancing the capacity of Member States and the EU to manage effectively security-related risks and crises.
The Commission and the Member States, together with the European External Action Service, ensure coordination as regards actions in and in relation to third countries, as set out in Article 3(5) of Regulation (EU) No 514/2014.
The Instrument provides financial assistance to address urgent and specific needs in the event of an emergency situation, as defined in point (j) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 105/2013.
The annual budgetary appropriations for the Instrument are established by the Commission, in accordance with Article 18 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU.
The Commission and the Member States, together with the European External Action Service, ensure coordination as regards actions in and in relation to third countries, as set out in Article 3(5) of Regulation (EU) No 514/2014.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated and implementing acts to determine the conditions for eligibility for support under the Instrument and to set up a list of common indicators for the measurement of the specific objectives, as well as the conditions for eligibility for support under the Instrument.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 21 May 2014.
BACKGROUND
Internal Security Strategy for the European Union
Internal Security Fund
KEY TERMS
Instrument for financial support for internal security
Internal Security Fund
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 105/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2012 establishing an Instrument for the implementation of the Internal Security Fund for the period 2014-2020

Summary 101:
EU framework for the adoption of certain measures in respect of the fisheries-related activities and policies of third countries
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1231/2010 — framework for the adoption of certain measures in respect of the fisheries-related activities and policies of third countries
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes a framework for the adoption of certain measures regarding the fisheries-related activities and policies of third countries in order to ensure the long-term conservation of stocks of common interest to the European Union (EU) and those third countries.
KEY POINTS
The regulation defines:
‘fishery management measure’ as a measure taken by a country in order to ensure the long-term conservation of a fish stock;
‘stock’ as a population of fish or other marine organisms, including plants, belonging to the same or different species or belonging to different species of the same genera or subgenera;
‘stock of common interest’ as a fish stock which is subject to fisheries activities of the Union and of one or more third countries;
‘country allowing non-sustainable fishing’ as a country which has not complied with the condition that it has adopted and implemented fishery management measures to ensure that the stock of common interest is maintained within safe biological limits.
The regulation also sets out the conditions under which a country may be considered to be a country allowing non-sustainable fishing and the type of measures that may be taken with regard to countries allowing non-sustainable fishing.
It sets out the procedures for the adoption of measures in respect of countries allowing non-sustainable fishing, the period of application of those measures and the procedures for the adoption of the measures themselves.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It has applied since 30 December 2010.
BACKGROUND
The regulation is part of the EU’s fisheries policy. It complements other measures such as Regulation (EC) No 1005/2008 which establishes a Community system to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.
KEY TERMS
Fishery management measure
Stock
Stock of common interest
Country allowing non-sustainable fishing
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 30 December 2010.
BACKGROUND
              
For further information, please see the European Commission’s website on the conservation of fish stocks.
REFERENCES

(OJ L 315, 17.12.2010, pp. 1-8)

Summary 102:
Investment agreements between EU countries and third countries: transitional regime
Investment agreements between EU countries and third countries: transitional regime
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1219/2012 on the coordination of procedures for the award of public procurement contracts and concessions
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to set out the rules on the status of bilateral investment agreements (BIAs) concluded by EU countries with non-EU countries.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to all BIAs concluded by EU countries with non-EU countries. It does not cover agreements concluded between EU countries.
BIAs
A BIA is an agreement between an EU country and a non-EU country that contains provisions on investment protection. This regulation covers only those provisions of BIAs dealing with investment protection.
BIAs that EU countries sign before 1 December 2009 or before the date of their accession to the EU, whichever is later, may be maintained in force or enter into force, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and this regulation.
EU countries may be authorised to amend or conclude BIAs with non-EU countries, provided that they comply with certain conditions.
EU countries must take the necessary measures to eliminate any incompatibilities with EU law contained in BIAs concluded between them and non-EU countries.
The European Commission may assess BIAs notified by EU countries under this regulation to evaluate whether one or more of their provisions constitute a serious obstacle to the negotiation or conclusion by the EU of BIAs with non-EU countries.
The Commission may request additional information from the EU country concerned to carry out its assessment.
If the Commission establishes that one or more of the provisions of a BIA constitute a serious obstacle to the negotiation or conclusion by the EU of BIAs with non-EU countries, the Commission and the EU country concerned must enter into consultations.
The Commission may, within 60 days of the end of the consultations, indicate the appropriate measures to be taken by the EU country concerned in order to remove the obstacles.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It entered into force on 10 December 2012.
KEY TERMS
              
Bilateral investment agreement (BIA): an agreement with a non-EU country that contains provisions on investment protection.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Commission Regulation (EU) No 1219/2012 of 12 December 2012 on the coordination of procedures for the award of public procurement contracts and concessions by Member States and utilisation of the procedures for the award of contracts and concessions by entities governed by public law (OJ L 335, 14.12.2012, pp. 35-43).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Decision 2014/487/EU of 11 June 2014 on the maintenance in force of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States of the one part, and Switzerland and its Principality of Liechtenstein of the other part, on the reciprocal promotion and protection of investments (OJ L 190, 19.6.2014, pp. 3-4).
Commission Decision 2014/486/EU of 11 June 2014 on the maintenance in force of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States of the one part, and Canada of the other part, on the reciprocal promotion and protection of investments (OJ L 190, 19.6.2014, pp. 1-2).
last update 20.06.2016



Summary 103:
EU trade preferences for developing countries
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) offers special trade preferences to developing countries. These preferences are designed to support their economic development and help them to fight poverty.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the conditions under which developing countries can benefit from the EU’s special trade preferences.
KEY POINTS
The special trade preferences are based on the following arrangements:
the generalised system of preferences (GSP) for developing countries;
the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+) for developing countries that are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change;
the special arrangement for the least developed countries (LDC);
the special arrangement for the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) states.
The special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+) is granted to a country if it meets the following conditions:
the country has made a request to that effect;
the country has ratified and effectively implements a minimum number of relevant international conventions on human and labour rights, environmental protection and good governance;
the country has ratified and effectively implements the relevant conventions’ reporting obligations and conclusions and recommendations of the relevant monitoring bodies;
the country has effectively implemented its binding undertakings as referred to in the relevant conventions;
the country has not formulated any reservation which is prohibited by any of the relevant conventions or which is incompatible with the object and purpose of that convention.
The special arrangement for the least developed countries (LDC) is granted to a country if it meets the following conditions:
the country has made a request to that effect;
the country is a least-developed country according to the United Nations classification;
the country’s per capita income is below the threshold set by the World Bank;
the country’s level of diversification is low, as measured by the vulnerability threshold;
the country’s economy is not able to sustain the higher level of diversification that the scheme would allow.
The special arrangement for the ACP states is granted to a country if it meets the following conditions:
the country has made a request to that effect;
the country is an ACP country;
the country is not eligible for the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+).
The generalised system of preferences (GSP) is granted to a country if it meets the following conditions:
the country has made a request to that effect;
the country is not eligible for the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+).
The regulation applies to all products except for agricultural products listed in Annex I.
The scheme is based on the following principles:
graduation, which means that if a country meets the conditions to be eligible for the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), it will benefit from the additional tariff preferences. Graduation will take effect 5 years after the date of application of the special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+);
temporary withdrawal of the arrangements from certain countries, in cases where the country concerned has not fulfilled its binding undertakings as referred to in the relevant conventions or has formulated a reservation which is prohibited by any of the relevant conventions or which is incompatible with the object and purpose of that convention;
safeguard measures, in cases where the scheme may have a negative impact on the production of certain products in the EU.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2014.
BACKGROUND
The EU’s trade preferences for developing countries are intended to support their economic development and help them to fight poverty.
The special incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+) is a new arrangement which has been designed to support the development of the world’s most vulnerable countries in the face of climate change.
The special arrangement for the least developed countries (LDC) is designed to support the world’s poorest countries in their efforts to improve their economies.
The special arrangement for the ACP states is a continuation of the arrangements set out in the ACP-EU Partnership Agreement.
The generalised system of preferences (GSP) is a long-standing arrangement which has been in place since 1971.
For further information, please see the European Commission’s website on trade preferences.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 applying the scheme of generalised tariff preferences (OJ L 314, 17.12.2012, pp. 1-26).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 February 2011 establishing a common Union asylum system (OJ L 60, 2.3.2011, pp. 1-27).
Regulation (EC) No 732/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 July 2008 applying the scheme of generalised tariff preferences (OJ L 218, 3.9.2008, pp. 3-23).
last update 13.09.2016



Summary 104:
EU firearms export controls
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) has adopted a new regulation to control the export of firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition. This regulation is designed to implement the United Nations Protocol against the Illicit Manufacturing of and Trafficking in Firearms, their Parts and Components and Ammunition, supplementing the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organised Crime.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the conditions under which firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition may be exported from the EU.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to:
firearms and their essential components, including their essential components’ parts and components;
ammunition;
the parts and components of firearms and ammunition;
the essential components of parts and components of firearms and ammunition;
the essential components of essential components of firearms and ammunition;
the essential components of essential components of firearms and ammunition.
It does not apply to:
firearms, their parts and essential components or ammunition that are intended specifically for military purposes;
antique firearms and their replicas, provided that antique firearms do not include firearms manufactured after 1899;
firearms and ammunition intended for hunting or sports purposes, provided that the exporter has a valid European firearms pass;
firearms, their parts and essential components or ammunition intended for exhibitions without sale, provided that the exporter has a valid European firearms pass.
The regulation establishes:
the list of firearms, their parts and essential components and ammunition for which an export authorisation is required;
the conditions for granting export authorisations;
the administrative cooperation procedures for competent authorities.
KEY TERMS
Firearms: any portable firearm designed or adapted to be held and fired by the hand, designed or adapted to discharge, or capable of discharging, a projectile by the action of an explosive;
Parts and essential components: any component or assembly of components which is essential to the functioning of a firearm;
Ammunition: the complete round or the components thereof, including cartridge cases, primers, propellant powder, bullets or projectiles, that are used in firearms;
Export: any supply or transfer of goods from the customs territory of the EU to a third country;
Import: any supply or transfer of goods from a third country to the customs territory of the EU;
Transit: any supply or transfer of goods from one third country to another third country through the customs territory of the EU.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 April 2014.
BACKGROUND
The EU has adopted a number of measures to control the illicit trade in firearms, including the UN Protocol against the Illicit Manufacturing of and Trafficking in Firearms, their Parts and Components and Ammunition, supplementing the UN Convention against Transnational Organised Crime.
The regulation is designed to implement this UN protocol.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s press release on the regulation.

Summary 105:
European Border Surveillance System (EUROSUR)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets up a European border surveillance system (EUROSUR), which is a framework for the exchange of information and the cooperation of national authorities with a responsibility for external border surveillance in order to improve the detection, prevention and combating of illegal immigration and cross-border crime, as well as the protection and saving of migrants’ lives.
KEY POINTS
The EUROSUR framework consists of the following components:
national coordination centres (NCCs);
national situational pictures (NSPs);
a communication network;
a European situational picture;
a common pre-frontier intelligence picture;
a common application of surveillance tools.
Each EU country has to designate, operate and maintain a national coordination centre (NCC), which coordinates, and exchanges information among, all authorities with a responsibility for external border surveillance at national level, as well as with the other national coordination centres and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex).
The NCCs have to operate 24 hours a day and 7 days a week.
The Agency has to:
establish and maintain a communication network for EUROSUR;
establish and maintain a European situational picture;
establish and maintain a common pre-frontier intelligence picture;
coordinate the common application of surveillance tools.
The Agency has to ensure that the communication network is interoperable with any other relevant communication and information system managed by the Agency.
The NCCs have to exchange, process and store non-classified sensitive and classified information in the communication network in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004.
The national situational pictures (NSPs), the European situational picture and the common pre-frontier intelligence picture consist of the following layers:
an events layer;
an operational layer;
an analysis layer.
The operational layer of the national situational picture consists of the following sub-layers:
a sub-layer on own assets, which contains information on the position, status and type of own assets and on the authorities involved;
a sub-layer on environmental information, which contains or gives access to information on terrain and weather conditions at the external borders of the EU country concerned.
The information on own assets in the operational layer of the European situational picture is classified as RESTREINT UE/EU RESTRICTED.
The Agency has to provide the information referred to in Article 12(1) by combining and analysing data which may be collected from the following systems, sensors and platforms:
ship reporting systems in accordance with their respective legal bases;
satellite imagery;
sensors mounted on any vehicle, vessel or other craft.
The Agency may refuse a request from a national coordination centre for technical, financial or operational reasons.
The Agency may use on its own initiative the surveillance tools referred to in paragraph 2 for collecting information which is relevant for the common pre-frontier intelligence picture.
The Agency has to ensure that, to the extent possible, the EUROSUR framework is based on internationally agreed standards.
When incidents occur at the external borders, the EU countries have to attribute an impact level to the external borders concerned and to take the reaction corresponding to the impact level concerned.
The Agency has to visualise the impact levels attributed to the external borders in the European situational picture.
The Agency has to, together with the EU countries concerned, evaluate the attribution of impact levels and the corresponding measures taken at national and EU level in its risk analysis reports.
The EU countries may charge regional, local, functional or other authorities which are in a position to take operational decisions, with ensuring situational awareness and reaction capability in their respective areas of competence, including the tasks and competences referred to in points (c), (e) and (f) of Article 5(3).
The Agency has to establish and maintain a common application of surveillance tools in order to collect information which is relevant for the common pre-frontier intelligence picture.
The Agency has to use the information collected from the following sources:
national situational pictures, to the extent required by this Regulation;
the Agency;
the Commission, providing strategic information on border control, including shortcomings in the carrying-out of external border control;
Union delegations and offices;
other relevant Union bodies, offices and agencies and international organisations as referred to in Article 18;
other sources.
The Agency has to notify the national coordination centres of any incident in the pre-frontier area.
The Agency may refuse a request from a national coordination centre for technical, financial or operational reasons.
The Agency may use on its own initiative the surveillance tools referred to in paragraph 2 for collecting information which is relevant for the common pre-frontier intelligence picture.
The Agency has to, together with the EU countries concerned, evaluate the attribution of impact levels and the corresponding measures taken at national and EU level in its risk analysis reports.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 2 December 2013.
BACKGROUND
EUROSUR was set up in order to improve the detection, prevention and combating of illegal immigration and cross-border crime, as well as the protection and saving of migrants’ lives.
For more information, please see the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex) website.
KEY TERMS
              
National coordination centre (NCC): a national coordination centre is a national authority designated by an EU country which coordinates, and exchanges information among, all authorities with a responsibility for external border surveillance at national level, as well as with the other national coordination centres and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (Frontex).

Summary 107:
European quality schemes for agricultural products and foodstuffs
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out a number of schemes for the identification and protection of quality agricultural products and foodstuffs.
KEY POINTS
The regulation establishes 2 schemes for designations of origin and geographical indications and 1 scheme for traditional specialities guaranteed.
The regulation also establishes 1 scheme for optional quality terms, including an optional quality term for mountain products.
Designations of origin and geographical indications
Designations of origin and geographical indications are names that identify a product:
originating in a specific place, region or country;
whose given quality, reputation or other characteristic is essentially attributable to its geographical origin; and
at least one of the production steps of which take place in the defined geographical area.
A name may not be registered as a designation of origin or geographical indication where it conflicts with a name of a plant variety or an animal breed.
Designations of origin and geographical indications may not become generic.
Traditional specialities guaranteed
A traditional speciality guaranteed is a name that describes a specific product or foodstuff that:
results from a mode of production, processing or composition corresponding to traditional practice for that product or foodstuff; or
is produced from raw materials or ingredients that are those traditionally used.
The use of a traditional speciality guaranteed is optional on the labelling of products produced outside the EU.
Optional quality terms
An optional quality term may be used to describe a product or a foodstuff that:
relates to a characteristic of one or more categories of products, or to a farming or processing attribute which applies in specific areas;
adds value to the product as compared to products of a similar type; and
has a European dimension.
Optional quality terms may be used to describe products intended for human consumption listed in Annex I to the Treaty in respect of which:
both the raw materials and the feedstuffs for farm animals come essentially from mountain areas;
in the case of processed products, the processing also takes place in mountain areas.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 14 January 2014.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation establishes a number of schemes for the identification and protection of quality agricultural products and foodstuffs.
It repeals Regulation (EC) No 510/2006 and Regulation (EC) No 509/2006.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on the EU quality schemes for agricultural products and foodstuffs.
REFERENCES
              
Article 30 repeals Regulation (EC) No 510/2006 with effect from 14 January 2014.
Article 31 repeals Regulation (EC) No 509/2006 with effect from 14 January 2014.
Regulation (EU) No 1154/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 October 2014 establishing conditions for EU support for the designation of geographical indications of agricultural products and foodstuffs (OJ L 314, 20.11.2014, pp. 1-39).
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 108:
double hulls for oil tankers
SUMMARY
EU legislation aims to ensure that oil tankers entering into ports and offshore terminals or anchoring in an area under the jurisdiction of Member States comply with the double hull design requirements of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL 73/78).
WHAT INFORMATION DOES THIS REGULATION PROVIDE?
It lays down an accelerated phasing-in scheme for the application of the double-hull or equivalent design requirements of MARPOL 73/78 to single-hull oil tankers.
It bans the transport of heavy grade oil in single-hull oil tankers.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all oil tankers of 5 000 tonnes deadweight and above:
flying the flag of an EU country;
entering or leaving a port or offshore terminal or anchoring in an area under the jurisdiction of an EU country.
For the purposes of this regulation, an ‘oil tanker’ means any ship constructed or retrofitted to carry oil in bulk as cargo and includes, inter alia, oil tankers, combination carriers and product carriers.
The regulation does not apply to any warship, naval auxiliary or other ship, owned or operated by a State and used, for the time being, only on government non-commercial service. The Member States undertake to respect this provision as far as is reasonable and practicable.
No oil tanker shall be allowed to operate under the flag of an EU country, nor shall any oil tanker, irrespective of its flag, be allowed to enter into ports or offshore terminals under the jurisdiction of an EU country unless such tanker is a double-hull oil tanker.
No oil tanker carrying heavy grade oil shall be allowed to fly the flag of an EU country unless such tanker is a double-hull oil tanker.
No oil tanker carrying heavy grade oil, irrespective of its flag, shall be allowed to enter or leave ports or offshore terminals or to anchor in areas under the jurisdiction of an EU country, unless such tanker is a double-hull oil tanker.
No oil tanker, irrespective of its flag, shall be allowed to enter or leave ports or offshore terminals or to anchor in areas under the jurisdiction of an EU country unless such tanker complies with the condition assessment scheme (CAS) referred to in the regulation.
For the purposes of the regulation, the CAS adopted by the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) in 2003 shall apply.
After the anniversary of the date of delivery of the ship in 2015, the following shall no longer be allowed:
the continued operation, in accordance with Regulation 20.5 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78, of Category 2 and Category 3 oil tankers under the flag of an EU country;
the entry into the ports or offshore terminals under the jurisdiction of an EU country of other Category 2 and Category 3 oil tankers, irrespective of the fact that they continue to operate under the flag of a third country in accordance with Regulation 20.5 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78.
Each EU country shall inform the IMO of its decision to deny entry to oil tankers, pursuant to Article 7 of this regulation, operating in accordance with Regulation 20.5 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78 into the ports or offshore terminals under its jurisdiction, on the basis of Regulation 20.8.2 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78.
Each EU country shall notify the IMO if it allows, suspends, withdraws or declines the operation of a Category 1 or a Category 2 oil tanker entitled to fly its flag, in accordance with Article 5 of this regulation, on the basis of Regulation 20.8.1 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 20 July 2012.
BACKGROUND
              
The EU is concerned about shipping accidents involving oil tankers and the associated pollution of its coastlines and harm to its fauna and flora and other marine resources.
The EU is also concerned about the safety of its citizens and the environment and has therefore adopted a number of measures to ensure that its waters are clean and safe.
For further information, please see the European Commission’s website on the prevention of oil pollution.
KEY TERMS
              
Double-hull oil tanker: a ship constructed or retrofitted to carry oil in bulk as cargo with a double hull design, or an equivalent design, in accordance with Regulation 19 of Annex I to MARPOL 73/78.
Heavy grade oil: any petroleum distillate having a flashpoint of 60 °C or less as determined by the standard test prescribed in the International Standards Organisation (ISO) standard 700:1981.

Summary 110:
Regulation on the freedom of movement for workers within the EU
SUMMARY
This Regulation establishes a legal framework for the free movement of workers within the European Union (EU). It states that any national of an EU country has the right to take up an activity as an employed person and to pursue such activity in the territory of another EU country. This right is granted under the same conditions as the nationals of that country. In addition, this Regulation sets out the conditions for the integration of the worker’s family into the host country.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a legal framework for the free movement of workers within the European Union (EU) and the conditions for the integration of the worker’s family into the host country.
It also states that any national of an EU country has the right to take up an activity as an employed person and to pursue such activity in the territory of another EU country. This right is granted under the same conditions as the nationals of that country.
KEY POINTS
The right to pursue an activity as an employed person is granted without discrimination by permanent, seasonal and frontier workers and by those who pursue their activities for the purpose of providing services.
The right of freedom of movement, in order that it may be exercised, by objective standards, in freedom and dignity, requires that equality of treatment be ensured in fact and in law in respect of all matters relating to the actual pursuit of activities as employed persons and to eligibility for housing, and also that obstacles to the mobility of workers be eliminated, in particular as regards the conditions for the integration of the worker’s family into the host country.
The principle of non-discrimination between workers in the EU means that all nationals of EU countries have the same priority as regards employment as is enjoyed by national workers.
The machinery for vacancy clearance, in particular by means of direct cooperation between the central employment services and also between the regional services, as well as by coordination of the exchange of information, ensures in a general way a clearer picture of the labour market.
Workers wishing to move should also be regularly informed of living and working conditions.
Close links exist between freedom of movement for workers, employment and vocational training, particularly where the latter aims at putting workers in a position to take up concrete offers of employment from other regions of the EU. Such links make it necessary that the problems arising in this connection should no longer be studied in isolation but viewed as interdependent, account also being taken of the problems of employment at the regional level. It is therefore necessary to direct the efforts of Member States toward coordinating their employment policies.
The right of all workers in the Member States to pursue the activity of their choice within the EU should be affirmed.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It has applied since 8 November 1968.
BACKGROUND
The free movement of workers is one of the pillars of the European Union (EU). It is one of the fundamental rights of citizens of the EU, which allows them to work in any EU country. The free movement of workers constitutes a fundamental right of workers and their families.
For further information, please see the European Commission's website on the free movement of workers.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EEC) No 1617/68 of the Council of 13 June 1968 on free movement of workers within the Community (OJ C 241, 29.8.2015, pp. 1-6).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Communication from the Commission: Free movement of workers (COM(2010) 518 final, 7.9.2010).
Communication from the Commission: Towards a Single European Labour Market (COM(2012) 752 final, 26.11.2012).

Summary 111:
Regulation (EC) No 995/2010 on the export of certain dangerous chemicals
Regulation (EC) No 995/2010 lays down rules on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer, on the reporting of information related to those substances and on the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances.
SUMMARY
Regulation (EC) No 995/2010 lays down rules on the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer, on the reporting of information related to those substances and on the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It defines the subject matter and scope of the regulation.
It lays down rules on:
the production, import, export, placing on the market, use, recovery, recycling, reclamation and destruction of substances that deplete the ozone layer;
the reporting of information related to those substances;
the import, export, placing on the market and use of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances.
KEY POINTS
The regulation prohibits the placing on the market and the use of controlled substances, except:
for laboratory and analytical uses;
as feedstock;
for essential uses by the chemical industry;
for the maintenance or servicing of refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment.
The regulation allows the placing on the market and the use of hydrochlorofluorocarbons for the maintenance or servicing of refrigeration and air-conditioning equipment only if:
they are contained in equipment that is in good working order;
they are in hermetically sealed systems, which are labelled as such and contain less than 6 kg of hydrochlorofluorocarbons;
they are used in equipment with a fluid charge of 30 kg or more of hydrochlorofluorocarbons, which are checked for leakage at least once every 6 months;
they are used in equipment with a fluid charge of 300 kg or more of hydrochlorofluorocarbons, which are checked for leakage at least once every 3 months;
any detected leakage is repaired as soon as possible and in any event within 14 days.
The regulation allows the placing on the market and the use of methyl bromide for quarantine and for pre-shipment applications for treatment of goods for export only if:
the placing on the market and use of methyl bromide are allowed respectively under national legislation in accordance with Directive 91/414/EEC (pesticides) and Directive 98/8/EC (plant protection products);
the placing on the market and use of methyl bromide are authorised by the competent authority of the Member State in which the production or the placing on the market or use takes place.
The regulation allows the placing on the market and the use of methyl bromide for the treatment of stored grain and other commodities only if:
the placing on the market and use of methyl bromide are allowed respectively under national legislation in accordance with Directive 91/414/EEC (pesticides) and Directive 98/8/EC (plant protection products);
the placing on the market and use of methyl bromide are authorised by the competent authority of the Member State in which the production or the placing on the market or use takes place;
the placing on the market and use of methyl bromide are subject to conditions for the placing on the market and further distribution of methyl bromide for essential laboratory and analytical uses.
The regulation prohibits the import and export of controlled substances or of products and equipment containing or relying on those substances, except:
personal effects;
transit through the customs territory of the Community or imports under the temporary storage, customs warehousing or free zone procedure as referred to in Regulation (EC) No 450/2008 (provided that they remain in the customs territory of the Community no longer than 45 days and that they are not subsequently presented for release for free circulation in the Community, destroyed or processed);
quantitative limits;
for essential laboratory and analytical uses.
The regulation prohibits the placing on the market and the use of products and equipment containing or relying on controlled substances, except:
for their maintenance or servicing;
for essential laboratory and analytical uses;
for essential uses by the chemical industry;
for the maintenance or servicing of refrigeration, air-conditioning and heat pump equipment.
The regulation allows the placing on the market and the use of products and equipment containing or relying on hydrochlorofluorocarbons only if:
they are used for the maintenance or servicing of existing refrigeration, air-conditioning and heat pump equipment provided that they have been recovered from such equipment and may only be used by the undertaking which carried out or mandated the recovery;
they are used for the maintenance or servicing of refrigeration, air-conditioning and heat pump equipment provided that they have been recovered from such equipment and may only be used by the undertaking which carried out or mandated the recovery;
they are used for the maintenance or servicing of refrigeration, air-conditioning and heat pump equipment provided that they have been recovered from such equipment and may only be used by the undertaking which carried out or mandated the recovery;

Summary 112:
setting up a European Environment Agency
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 101/2011 establishing the European Environment Agency and the European Environmental Observation and Information Network
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes the European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Environmental Observation and Information Network (EIONET) and sets out the tasks of the EEA.
KEY POINTS
Tasks
The EEA provides the European Union (EU) and EU countries with reliable, impartial and timely information on the environment. It also supports them in the development of environmental policies and measures, and in the evaluation of their effects.
The EEA carries out its tasks in close cooperation with existing national and international facilities.
The EEA’s main areas of activity are:
—
the quality of the environment
—
the pressures on the environment
—
the sensitivity of the environment
—
sustainable development.
The EEA also cooperates with other EU institutions and bodies in the area of the environment and with other bodies, including the European Monitoring and Assessment Programme (EMEP) and the European Network for the Implementation and Enforcement of Environmental Law (IMPEL).
In the EU, the EEA works closely with the European Commission and the EU countries.
In the wider European region, it cooperates with other countries that share the same environmental concerns and have similar environmental policies.
The EEA cooperates with other international organisations, such as the United Nations, the World Meteorological Organisation and the International Atomic Energy Agency.
The EEA also cooperates with the European Space Agency.
The EEA has legal personality and is a body of the EU.
It is managed by a Management Board composed of representatives of the EU countries and the Commission. The European Parliament also designates 2 scientific personalities particularly qualified in the field of environmental protection.
The EEA’s Executive Director is appointed by the Management Board on a proposal from the Commission for a period of 5 years, which may be renewed.
The EEA’s budget is drawn up for each financial year, which corresponds to the calendar year. The EEA’s revenue and expenditure are in balance.
The EEA cooperates with other EU institutions and bodies in the area of the environment and with other bodies, including the European Monitoring and Assessment Programme (EMEP) and the European Network for the Implementation and Enforcement of Environmental Law (IMPEL).
The EEA cooperates with other international organisations, such as the United Nations, the World Meteorological Organisation and the International Atomic Energy Agency.
The EEA also cooperates with the European Space Agency.
The EEA is open to countries which are not members of the EU but which share the concern of the EU and its countries for the objectives of the EEA under agreements concluded between them and the EU following the procedure in Article 216 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
The EEA has its headquarters in Copenhagen, Denmark.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 20 May 2011.
BACKGROUND
              
The EEA was established in 1990 to provide the EU and its countries with reliable, impartial and timely information on the environment.
For more information, see:
The EEA on the EEA website
KEY TERMS
              
European Environmental Observation and Information Network (EIONET).
MAIN DOCUMENT
              
Regulation (EU) No 101/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 April 2011 establishing the European Environment Agency and the European Environmental Observation and Information Network — Decision No 534/2011/EU of the European Parliament of the Council of 5 April 2011 establishing the European Environment Agency and the European Environmental Observation and Information Network — Decision No 534/2011/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 June 2011 on the greenhouse gas monitoring mechanism and repealing Regulation (EC) No 601/2009 (OJ C 198, 18.7.2015, pp. 1-21).

Summary 113:
EU eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the conditions for organisations to participate in the EU’s eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS), a voluntary instrument that allows them to demonstrate their commitment to environmental protection.
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out the conditions for organisations to participate in the EU’s eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS), a voluntary instrument that allows them to demonstrate their commitment to environmental protection.
The regulation applies to organisations which carry out activities that have a significant environmental impact, regardless of their size or sector.
Organisations may register with the competent authorities in their respective EU countries.
Registration requires them to:
develop an environmental policy;
carry out an initial environmental review;
develop and implement an environmental management system;
establish environmental objectives and targets;
comply with applicable legal requirements relating to the environment;
publish an environmental statement;
implement an internal environmental audit;
have their environmental statement validated by an accredited environmental verifier.
Registered organisations are entitled to use the EMAS logo and the ‘EMAS registered’ wording.
EU countries are encouraged to reduce the administrative burden of registered organisations by way of deregulation or regulatory relief.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2015.
BACKGROUND
The EU’s eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS) is a voluntary instrument that allows organisations to demonstrate their commitment to environmental protection. It is a practical tool that can be used to improve environmental performance and competitiveness.
It was established by Regulation (EC) No 761/2001.
In 2013, the European Commission launched a review of EMAS. The Commission’s main conclusions were that EMAS is a good instrument for improving environmental performance and competitiveness. It should be made available to all organisations, in and outside the EU, whose activities have an environmental impact.
In 2015, the Commission adopted a new regulation on EMAS to ensure that it is more accessible and easier to use. The regulation was amended in 2017.

Summary 114:
rules for the description, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes rules for the description, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all spirit drinks, including those produced for export.
Spirit drinks are classified into categories according to the definitions set out in Annex II of the regulation.
For geographical indications, the regulation provides for the registration of geographical indications in Annex III.
The regulation sets out the technical definitions and requirements for the production of spirit drinks, including the definition of ‘ethanol of agricultural origin’ and the ‘addition of alcohol’.
The regulation provides for the use of the terms ‘spirit drink’ and ‘liqueur’ on the description, presentation and labelling of foodstuffs.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 24 April 2009.
BACKGROUND
              
The European Union produces a wide range of spirit drinks, including wine spirits, fruit spirits, grain spirits and liqueurs. In order to ensure the quality of these products, the regulation lays down the rules for the description, presentation and labelling of spirit drinks.
KEY TERMS
              
Spirit drink: a distillate, i.e. an alcoholic product obtained by distillation, and/or a compound product obtained by mixing such distillates, to which sugar or other sweetening products may have been added, and which has a minimum alcoholic strength by volume of 15 % vol.
Liqueur: a spirit drink to which sugar or other sweetening products have been added.

Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 110/2008 have been incorporated into the basic text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only.

Summary 115:
aviation security — common basic standards
SUMMARY
The purpose of this Regulation is to prevent acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation that jeopardise the security of civil aviation. This is achieved by establishing common rules and common basic standards on aviation security as well as mechanisms for monitoring compliance.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out common basic standards on aviation security, which are minimum standards. It also establishes mechanisms for monitoring compliance with the common basic standards.
KEY POINTS
The common basic standards include:
—
screening of passengers and baggage;
—
screening of cargo and mail;
—
screening of persons other than passengers and items carried;
—
access control;
—
surveillance, patrols and other physical controls;
—
aircraft security checks;
—
protection of aircraft;
—
security training.
These common basic standards apply to all airports in the EU that are not exclusively used for military purposes and to all operators, including air carriers, providing services at these airports.
The common basic standards do not apply to Gibraltar airport. The airport of Gibraltar is understood to be without prejudice to the respective legal positions of the Kingdom of Spain and the United Kingdom with regard to the dispute over sovereignty over the territory in which the airport is situated.
The common basic standards do not apply to airports and operators in Cyprus, except for those in the territory of the Republic of Cyprus that are controlled by the Government of Cyprus.

Summary 116:
Restrictive measures in view of the situation in Venezuela
Restrictive measures in view of the situation in Venezuela
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) 2020/1999 on the measures prohibiting the export of certain goods and services, and the transfer of currency and funds, and restricting the provision of certain services for the purposes of preventing human rights violations and abuses and serious violations of international humanitarian law in Venezuela
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to prevent, restrict or stop the export of certain goods and services, and the transfer of currency and funds, and restrict the provision of certain services for the purposes of preventing human rights violations and abuses and serious violations of international humanitarian law in Venezuela.
KEY POINTS
The regulation implements Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999, which was adopted by the Council on 8 August 2020 in support of the EU's political commitment to a peaceful, democratic, stable and prosperous Venezuela.
The regulation applies to the following:
within the territory of the EU, including its airspace;
on board any aircraft or vessel under the jurisdiction of an EU country;
to any natural person inside or outside the EU who is a national of an EU country;
to any legal person, entity or body, inside or outside the EU, which is incorporated or constituted under the law of an EU country;
to any legal person, entity or body in respect of any business done in whole or in part within the EU.
It does not apply to:
the international organisations and their officials;
humanitarian aid and humanitarian personnel;
goods intended exclusively for medical use;
goods intended exclusively for food;
goods intended exclusively for the needs of religious communities.
It also does not apply to goods which come from third countries and are exported directly to the United Nations or the Red Cross and are intended exclusively for humanitarian aid.
The regulation provides for the freezing of funds and economic resources of, and the prohibition to make funds and economic resources available to, natural or legal persons, entities or bodies responsible for, providing support to or otherwise involved in serious human rights violations or abuses, as well as those associated with the natural and legal persons, entities and bodies covered.
It specifies that:
the freezing of funds and economic resources or the refusal to make funds or economic resources available, carried out in good faith on the basis that such action is in accordance with the regulation, shall not give rise to liability of any kind on the part of the natural or legal person or entity or body implementing it, or its directors or employees, unless it is proved that the funds and economic resources were frozen or withheld as a result of negligence;
no claims in connection with any contract or transaction the performance of which has been affected, directly or indirectly, in whole or in part, by the measures imposed under this Regulation, including claims for indemnity or any other claim of this type, such as a claim for compensation or a claim under a guarantee, in particular a claim for extension or payment of a bond or of a guarantee or indemnity, in particular a financial guarantee or financial indemnity, shall be satisfied, if they are made by:
natural or legal persons, entities or bodies listed in Annex I;
any natural or legal person, entity or body acting through or on behalf of one of the natural or legal persons, entities or bodies referred to in point (a).
The regulation provides for a number of exemptions, including:
authorisation by the competent authorities of the EU countries to release certain frozen funds or economic resources, or the making available of certain funds or economic resources, under such conditions as they deem appropriate, after having determined that the provision of such funds or economic resources is necessary for humanitarian purposes, such as delivering or facilitating the delivery of assistance, including medical supplies, food, or the transfer of humanitarian workers and related assistance or for evacuations;
authorisation by the competent authorities of the EU countries to release certain frozen funds or economic resources, or the making available of certain funds or economic resources, under such conditions as they deem appropriate, after having determined that the provision of such funds or economic resources is necessary for the payment of reasonable professional fees or reimbursement of expenses, such as legal and/or accounting fees, incurred in connection with litigation in environmental, public health, gender, human rights and child rights cases.
The regulation provides for the possibility for the EU countries to apply administrative penalties to any natural or legal persons, entities or bodies that breach the regulation.
The regulation provides for the possibility for the EU countries to apply administrative penalties to any natural or legal persons, entities or bodies that breach the regulation.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 16 August 2020.
BACKGROUND
The EU has a number of instruments at its disposal to respond to serious human rights violations and abuses and serious violations of international humanitarian law. These include the possibility to impose restrictive measures, such as travel bans and asset freezes.
For further information, please see the European Commission's factsheet on restrictive measures in response to the situation in Venezuela.
KEY TERMS
              
Export: the supply, sale, transfer, shipment, or other movement from one country to another of goods and services.
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
              
It applies from 9 August 2020.
BACKGROUND
The EU has a number of instruments at its disposal to respond to serious human rights violations and abuses and serious violations of international humanitarian law. These include the possibility to impose restrictive measures, such as travel bans and asset freezes.
For further information, please see the European Commission's factsheet on restrictive measures in response to the situation in Venezuela.
KEY TERMS
              
Decision: a decision of the Council of the European Union.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) 2020/1999 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 8 August 2020 on the measures prohibiting the export of certain goods and services, and the transfer of currency and funds, and restricting the provision of certain services for the purposes of preventing human rights violations and abuses and serious violations of international humanitarian law in Venezuela and repealing Regulation (EU) No 204/2016 (OJ L 232I, 23.8.2020, p. 1-4)

Summary 117:
EU military operation EUNAVFOR MED IRINI
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) has launched a new military operation in the Mediterranean to help prevent the illegal export of arms from Libya. The mission, named EUNAVFOR MED IRINI, will also contribute to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, to capacity building and training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy, and to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE OPERATION?
The EU military operation aims to contribute to preventing the illegal export of arms from Libya by using aerial, satellite and maritime assets.
It will also contribute to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, to capacity building and training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy, and to the disruption of the human smuggling and trafficking networks.
KEY POINTS
The operation is named EUNAVFOR MED IRINI. Its tasks are:
to contribute to preventing the illegal export of arms from Libya by using aerial, satellite and maritime assets;
to contribute to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya;
to contribute to the development of the capacities and to the training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy in law enforcement tasks at sea;
to contribute to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks.
The operation will be launched for a period of 6 months, from 31 March 2020 until 31 March 2021. It may be extended for further periods.
The operation will be based in Rome, Italy.
The operation is authorised by the Council of the European Union, which will exercise political control and strategic direction over the mission.
The EU Operation Commander of EUNAVFOR MED IRINI is appointed for a period of 6 months, from 31 March 2020 until 31 March 2021. The position may be renewed.
The operation will be supported by the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the European Defence Agency (EDA).
The operation is authorised to use the European Union Satellite Centre (SATCEN) and the European Union Intelligence and Situation Centre (INTCEN) for gathering information.
The operation will be coordinated with other EU missions in the region.
WHEN DOES THE OPERATION START?
It will start on 31 March 2020.
BACKGROUND
The EU has launched a new military operation in the Mediterranean to help prevent the illegal export of arms from Libya. The mission, named EUNAVFOR MED IRINI, will also contribute to the implementation of UN measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, to capacity building and training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy, and to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks.
The operation will be based in Rome, Italy. It will be coordinated with other EU missions in the region.
KEY TERMS
Operation: EUNAVFOR MED IRINI
Council: European Union Council of Ministers
EU Operation Commander: Rear Admiral Fabio AGOSTINI
FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY?
It applies from 31 March 2020.
