Summary 118:
Fighting against false documents
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) is facing an increasing number of false documents and identity fraud. The FADO system (Fight Against Document Fraud) was created in 1998 to help police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities in the EU to fight against these forms of fraud.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It updates the FADO system, which is a European database of information on authentic documents and methods of falsification. It is intended to contribute to the fight against document fraud and identity fraud.
KEY POINTS
The FADO system contains information on:
travel, identity, residence and civil status documents, driving licences and vehicle licences issued by EU countries or by the EU;
false versions of such documents;
other related official documents, in particular those used in support of applications for official documents, issued by EU countries or by third parties, such as third countries, territorial entities, international organisations and other entities subject to international law;
false versions of such documents and other related official documents.
The FADO system may contain other useful information, such as:
handbooks;
contact lists;
recommendations on effective ways of detecting specific methods of falsification;
valid travel documents and their recognition by EU countries.
EU countries and the EU must transmit without delay the information on the documents referred to in the first paragraph to the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (the Agency).
EU countries may transmit to the Agency the information on the documents referred to in the second and third paragraphs.
Third parties, such as third countries, territorial entities, international organisations and other entities subject to international law, may transmit to the Agency the information on the documents referred to in the second and third paragraphs.
The Agency must ensure the proper and reliable functioning of the FADO system and provide support to the competent EU authorities in the detection of false documents.
The FADO system provides users with different levels of access to information. The Commission and the Agency, to the extent necessary for the performance of their tasks, and the competent EU authorities, such as police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities, have secure access to the FADO system on a need-to-know basis. The following actors may obtain access to information stored in the FADO system in a limited manner:
the EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies;
third parties, such as third countries, territorial entities, international organisations and other entities subject to international law;
private entities, such as airlines and other carriers.
The Commission adopts delegated acts in order to establish measures granting access to information stored in the FADO system to the actors listed above.
EU countries determine which authorities competent in the area of document fraud and other relevant national authorities are to have access to the FADO system, including the level of access with which they are to be provided, and notify the Commission and the Agency thereof.
The Agency must apply Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 of the European Parliament and of the Council when processing personal data under this regulation. It must ensure that technical and organisational measures, such as pseudonymisation, are in place in order to ensure that personal data are only processed to the extent strictly necessary for the purpose of operating the FADO system.
The Commission adopts implementing acts in order to:
establish the technical architecture of the FADO system;
establish the technical specifications for entering and storing information in the FADO system in accordance with high standards;
establish the procedures for controlling and verifying the information contained in the FADO system;
determine the date of the effective implementation of the FADO system by the Agency.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 26 April 2020.
BACKGROUND
The FADO system was created in 1998 to help police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities in the EU to fight against these forms of fraud.
The FADO system contributes to maintaining a high level of security within the EU by supporting police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities of the EU countries in the fight against document fraud, in particular at the external borders. Given that the detection of false documents is also important for citizens, organisations and businesses, the General Secretariat of the Council also made authentic documents available in a Public Register of Authentic Travel and Identity Documents Online, known as PRADO.

Summary 119:
EU rules on the regulation of professions
SUMMARY
EU countries can regulate professions in different ways. This Directive aims to ensure that these rules are proportionate and transparent, and to prevent barriers to the taking-up and pursuit of certain employed or self-employed activities.
WHAT DOES THIS DIRECTIVE DO?
It establishes rules for the assessment of the proportionality of new or amended legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions restricting access to or the pursuit of regulated professions.
KEY POINTS
The directive applies to any legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions of EU countries restricting access to a regulated profession or its pursuit, or one of its modes of pursuit, including the use of professional titles and the professional activities allowed under such title.
The directive lays down rules on the assessment of the proportionality of new, or amended existing, legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions restricting access to, or the pursuit of, regulated professions.
The directive sets out the criteria for assessing the proportionality of such provisions, namely:
non-discrimination
justification on grounds of public interest objectives
suitability
necessity
necessity
The directive also provides for:
a non-discrimination obligation, which means that such provisions may not be directly or indirectly discriminatory on the basis of nationality or residence
an obligation for EU countries to carry out an assessment of proportionality before introducing new, or amending existing, legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions restricting access to, or the pursuit of, regulated professions
an obligation for EU countries to ensure that an effective remedy is available with regard to the matters covered by this directive, in accordance with procedures laid down in national law
an obligation for EU countries to ensure that the legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions restricting access to, or the pursuit of, regulated professions that they introduce, and that the amendments that they make to existing provisions, are suitable for securing the attainment of the objective pursued and do not go beyond what is necessary to attain that objective
an obligation for EU countries to ensure that the legislative, regulatory or administrative provisions restricting access to, or the pursuit of, regulated professions that they introduce, and that the amendments that they make to existing provisions, are justified by public interest objectives, such as those within the meaning of the TFEU, namely public policy, public security and public health, or by overriding reasons in the public interest, recognised as such in the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union
an obligation for EU countries to ensure that such provisions are suitable for securing the attainment of the objective pursued and do not go beyond what is necessary to attain that objective
an obligation for EU countries to ensure that such provisions are necessary in order to achieve the objective pursued

contribute to the fulfilment of other relevant descriptors contained in Annex I to Directive 2008/56/EC in proportion to the role played by fisheries in their fulfilment;

contribute to the achievement of the objectives set out in Article 3 of this Regulation;

EU fishing authorisations for the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation

It lays down rules for the reporting of data by EU countries.
It lays down rules for the inspection of third country fishing vessels in ports designated by EU countries.
It lays down rules for the inclusion of vessels flying the flag of an EU country in the SPRFMO IUU vessel list.

Summary 122:
controls on cash entering and leaving the EU
SUMMARY
Cash is a commodity that can be used to launder the proceeds of crime or to finance terrorism. The EU is currently tightening controls on cash entering and leaving its territory.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It introduces a system of rules to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing by regulating cash movements across the EU’s external borders.
KEY POINTS
Cash
Cash means:
currency (notes and coins);
bearer-negotiable instruments;
commodities used as highly-liquid stores of value (e.g. gold, silver, precious metals and gems);
prepaid cards.
Obligation to declare
Carriers who carry cash of a value of EUR 10 000 or more shall declare that cash to the competent authorities of the Member State through which they are entering or leaving the EU and make it available for control. The details shall be provided in writing or electronically, using the EU Cash Declaration Form (EU-CDF).
Obligation to disclose
The competent authorities may detain the cash until the sender or the recipient, or a representative thereof, makes the disclosure declaration. The disclosure declaration shall provide details about the following:
the declarant, including full name, contact details, including address, date and place of birth, nationality and passport details;
the cash, including its type, its quantity and value, its economic provenance and intended use;
the sender and, where available, the intended recipient of the cash, including full name, contact details, including address and date of birth.
Controls
The competent authorities shall have the power to carry out controls on natural persons, their luggage and their means of transport, in accordance with the conditions laid down in national law. The controls shall be based primarily on risk analysis, with the purpose of identifying and evaluating the risks and developing the necessary countermeasures, and shall be performed within a common risk management framework in accordance with the criteria established by the Commission and the FIUs under Directive (EU) 2015/849.
Sub-threshold amounts suspected to be related to criminal activity
Where the competent authorities find that unaccompanied cash below the threshold is entering or leaving the EU and that there are indications that the cash is related to criminal activity, they shall record that information and the details listed in Article 4(2).
Temporary detention of cash by competent authorities
The competent authorities may temporarily detain cash by means of an administrative decision in accordance with the conditions laid down in national law where:
the obligation to declare accompanied cash under Article 3 or the obligation to disclose unaccompanied cash under Article 4 has not been fulfilled; or
there are indications that the cash, irrespective of the amount, is related to criminal activity.
The period of temporary detention shall be strictly limited under national law to the time required for competent authorities to determine whether the circumstances of the case warrant further detention. The period of temporary detention shall not exceed 30 days.
Provision of information to the FIU
The competent authorities shall transmit the information obtained under Article 3 or 4, where there are indications that the cash is related to criminal activity, to the FIU of the Member State in question. The FIU shall exchange such information with the relevant FIUs of the other Member States in accordance with Article 53(1) of Directive (EU) 2015/849.
The competent authorities shall transmit the following information to the competent authorities of all the other Member States:
ex officio declarations composed under Article 5(3);
information obtained under Article 6;
declarations obtained under Article 3 or 4, where there are indications that the cash is related to criminal activity;
anonymised risk information and risk analysis results.
The information shall be transmitted as soon as possible, and in any event no later than 15 working days after the date on which that information was obtained.
Personal data protection and retention periods
The processing of personal data on the basis of this Regulation shall take place only for the purposes of the prevention and fight against criminal activities. The personal data shall be erased upon the expiry of a period of 5 years.
Penalties
Member States shall impose effective, proportionate and dissuasive penalties on natural and legal persons in breach of the obligations to declare or disclose cash.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 2 December 2018.
BACKGROUND
The EU is tightening controls on cash entering and leaving its territory in order to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. This is part of the wider effort to counter criminal activities such as drug trafficking, human trafficking, fraud and corruption.
KEY TERMS
* Cash: currency (notes and coins), bearer-negotiable instruments, commodities used as highly-liquid stores of value (e.g. gold, silver, precious metals and gems), prepaid cards.
* Carrier: any natural person entering or leaving the EU carrying cash on their person, in their luggage or in their means of transport.
* Unaccompanied cash: cash making up part of a consignment without a carrier.

Summary 123:
EU strategy for long-term decarbonisation of the EU economy
EU countries are set to present, by 31 December 2018, their long-term decarbonisation strategies, in the context of the EU strategy for long-term decarbonisation of the EU economy. These strategies will help the EU achieve its 2030 and 2050 climate and energy goals, and support the transition to a low-carbon economy.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the EU’s long-term strategy for decarbonisation of the economy, in line with the Paris Agreement on climate change. It sets out the EU’s climate and energy objectives for 2030 and 2050 and establishes a governance framework to ensure that they are achieved.
KEY POINTS
The regulation establishes a governance framework for the implementation of the EU’s long-term decarbonisation strategy.
It introduces a new planning and reporting process at national and EU levels for the energy and climate sectors. It introduces a new governance framework for the implementation of the EU’s long-term decarbonisation strategy.
The new governance framework is based on the following 5 pillars:
energy security;
the internal energy market;
energy efficiency;
decarbonisation; and
research, innovation and competitiveness.
EU countries must present their integrated national energy and climate plans (planning) by 31 December 2018. The plans will cover the period from 2021 to 2030, and include:
an overview of the current situation and projections for the 5 pillars of the strategy;
an outline of policies and measures to be implemented;
an assessment of the macroeconomic, environmental, health, social and skills impact of the policies and measures;
a description of regional cooperation;
an indication of the level of power interconnections between EU countries;
a description of relevant circumstances affecting the renewable energy and energy efficiency sectors, and, if relevant, a national indicative objective to reduce the number of households in energy poverty.
The Commission will assess the draft plans and may issue country-specific recommendations to EU countries, if needed.
The first plans will cover the period from 2021 to 2030, but EU countries may include longer-term objectives, including a national 2050 objective, where appropriate.
The Commission will assess the implementation of the plans, and issue recommendations to EU countries, if necessary.
EU countries must report on the implementation of their plans every 2 years, and on their greenhouse gas inventories and projections every year.
The Commission will issue recommendations to EU countries, if necessary, in the following areas:
energy security;
the internal energy market;
energy efficiency;
decarbonisation; and
research, innovation and competitiveness.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 9 December 2018.
BACKGROUND
The Paris Agreement on climate change was signed in 2015 and ratified by the European Union and its Member States in 2016. It commits the EU to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 % by 2030 compared to 1990 levels.
The EU is also committed to reducing its energy consumption by 20 % by 2020 compared to 2005 levels and to increasing the share of renewable energy in its final energy consumption to 27 % by 2030.
In 2016, the European Commission presented its Energy Union strategy, which includes 5 pillars: energy security, the internal energy market, energy efficiency, decarbonisation and research, innovation and competitiveness. The Commission also presented its long-term vision for a low-carbon economy, which includes a scenario for the EU to achieve net zero GHG emissions by 2050.
KEY WORDS
Long-term decarbonisation strategy, Paris Agreement, Energy Union.

Summary 124:
Regulation (EU) No 494/2013 on persistent organic pollutants (POPs)
Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) are chemicals that have a wide range of negative effects on humans and the environment. They are found in the air, water and soil and can accumulate in the food chain. They can be transported long distances through the air and water. The European Union (EU) has banned or restricted the use of 21 substances on its territory as a result of the Stockholm Convention, an international treaty designed to protect human health and the environment from POPs. The EU Regulation (EU) No 494/2013 on POPs updates the previous legislation (Regulation (EC) No 850/2004) in the light of scientific and technical progress.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a common legal framework within which to take measures designed to eliminate the manufacturing, placing on the market and use of intentionally manufactured POPs and to prevent their unintentional production.
It also establishes rules for the management of waste containing POPs, as well as for the prevention of their release from certain industrial processes.

Summary 125:
plastic and marine litter
SUMMARY
The European Commission is presenting a new strategy to tackle marine litter and plastic pollution. The strategy, which includes a number of measures, aims to significantly reduce the consumption of single-use plastic items such as plastic bottles, plastic cups, plastic straws and cotton buds.
WHAT DOES THIS STRATEGY DO?
It aims to significantly reduce marine litter and microplastics in the European Union (EU) by 2025. It does this by banning a number of single-use plastic products and by introducing measures to reduce the consumption of plastic items.
The EU strategy is part of the European Commission’s broader strategy for a circular economy.
KEY POINTS
The strategy consists of 3 main parts:
a ban on the 10 single-use plastic items most frequently found on EU beaches and seas;
measures to reduce the consumption of plastic;
an extended producer responsibility scheme for fishing gear containing plastic.
The 10 single-use plastic items covered by the ban are:
cotton buds;
plastic-stemmed cotton buds;
stirrers;
sugar sticks;
food containers;
single-use plastic plates;
single-use plastic cutlery;
drinking straws;
sticker and label backing paper;
cotton buds and plastic-stemmed cotton buds.
The ban applies to the EU market from 2021.
The EU will also work with EU countries to ensure that these items are not available free of charge from the food and drink sector.
The EU will also work with EU countries to ensure that these items are not available free of charge from the food and drink sector.
EU countries will have to ensure that the items covered by the ban are not placed on the EU market from 2021.
EU countries will also have to reduce the consumption of the 10 single-use plastic items most frequently found on EU beaches and seas, as well as other plastic items, by 2025.
EU countries will have to ensure that producers of certain single-use plastic products cover the costs of waste collection and the treatment of the waste, including the costs of waste collection systems, infrastructure and its operation, and the subsequent transport and treatment of that waste.
EU countries will also have to ensure that producers of fishing gear containing plastic cover the costs of waste collection for that fishing gear that is discarded in public collection systems, including the infrastructure and its operation, and the subsequent transport and treatment of that waste.
The European Commission will adopt a series of rules by 2021 to ensure that producers of the items covered by the ban bear the costs of cleaning up litter and of awareness raising measures.
The Commission will also establish a series of rules by 2022 to ensure that producers of certain single-use plastic products cover the costs of waste collection for those products that are discarded in public collection systems, including the infrastructure and its operation, and the subsequent transport and treatment of that waste.
The Commission will also establish a series of rules by 2022 to ensure that producers of fishing gear containing plastic cover the costs of waste collection for that fishing gear that is discarded in public collection systems, including the infrastructure and its operation, and the subsequent transport and treatment of that waste.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2022 to ensure that the items covered by the ban bear a conspicuous, clearly legible and indelible marking on their packaging or on the product itself.
EU countries will be required to ensure that the items covered by the ban bear a conspicuous, clearly legible and indelible marking on their packaging or on the product itself.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2022 to ensure that the items covered by the ban are not placed on the EU market unless they have a reusable alternative available.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2022 to ensure that producers of the items covered by the ban provide reusable alternatives to those items.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2023 to ensure that EU countries set targets for the collection of fishing gear containing plastic for recycling.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2023 to ensure that producers of fishing gear containing plastic set targets for the collection of fishing gear containing plastic for recycling.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2024 to ensure that producers of certain single-use plastic products set targets for the collection of the items covered by the ban for recycling and reuse.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2024 to ensure that EU countries set targets for the collection of the items covered by the ban for recycling and reuse.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2025 to ensure that producers of certain single-use plastic products set targets for the reduction of the items covered by the ban on the EU market.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2025 to ensure that EU countries set targets for the reduction of the items covered by the ban on the EU market.
The Commission will establish a series of rules by 2025 to ensure that EU countries set targets for the reduction of the consumption of the items covered by the ban, as well as other plastic items.
FROM WHEN DO THE MEASURES APPLY?
The EU strategy applies from 3 July 2018.
BACKGROUND
The EU strategy is part of the European Commission’s broader strategy for a circular economy.
The EU strategy aims to significantly reduce marine litter and microplastics in the European Union (EU) by 2025. It does this by banning a number of single-use plastic items such as plastic bottles, plastic cups, plastic straws and cotton buds.
The EU strategy is also part of the Commission’s Action Plan for Soil Protection, which was presented in 2015.
The EU strategy is part of the Commission’s efforts to combat marine litter and microplastics in the EU.
For further information, please see: Marine litter and microplastics
KEY TERMS
              
Single-use plastic product: a product made of plastic designed to be used to a maximum once or for a short period of time before being thrown away or recycled.
Fishing gear containing plastic: fishing gear or equipment which contains plastic.

Summary 127:
Regulation (EU) 2017/1725 on the export and import of accessible format copies of works and other subject matter
SUMMARY
Accessible format copies of books and other printed material which are protected by copyright and related rights are an essential means for persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled to access culture and information. The Marrakesh Treaty, which the European Union ratified in 2014, provides for exceptions and limitations to copyright and related rights for the making and dissemination of copies, in accessible formats, of certain works and other subject matter, and for the cross-border exchange of those copies. The Marrakesh Treaty also provides for exceptions and limitations to copyright and related rights for the making and dissemination of copies, in accessible formats, of certain works and other subject matter, and for the cross-border exchange of those copies. This Regulation aims to ensure that accessible format copies of books, including e-books, journals, newspapers, magazines and other kinds of writing, notation, including sheet music, and other printed material, including in audio form, which have been made in any Member State in accordance with the national provisions adopted pursuant to Directive (EU) 2017/1564 can be distributed, communicated, or made available, to a beneficiary person or authorised entity, as referred to in the Marrakesh Treaty, in third countries that are parties to the Marrakesh Treaty. Accessible formats include, for example, Braille, large print, adapted e-books, audio books and radio broadcasts.
KEY POINTS
What does the Regulation provide for?
An authorised entity established in a Member State may distribute, communicate or make available to beneficiary persons as one of its primary activities, institutional obligations or as part of its public-interest missions, an accessible format copy of a work or other subject matter made in accordance with the national legislation adopted pursuant to Directive (EU) 2017/1564.
A beneficiary person or an authorised entity established in a Member State may import or otherwise obtain or access and thereafter use, in accordance with the national legislation adopted pursuant to Directive (EU) 2017/1564, an accessible format copy of a work or other subject matter that has been distributed, communicated or made available to beneficiary persons or to authorised entities, by an authorised entity in a third country that is a party to the Marrakesh Treaty.
An authorised entity established in a Member State shall establish and follow the practices referred to in the first subparagraph in full respect of the rules applicable to the processing of personal data of beneficiary persons referred to in Article 6.
The processing of personal data carried out within the framework of this Regulation shall be carried out in compliance with Directives 95/46/EC and 2002/58/EC.
The Commission shall carry out an evaluation of this Regulation by 11 October 2023, and present the main findings in a report to the European Parliament, the Council and the European Economic and Social Committee, accompanied, where appropriate, by proposals for amending this Regulation.
REFERENCES
Act
Entry into force
Deadline for implementation in the Member States
Official publication
Regulation (EU) 2017/1725
11.12.2017

L 267, 15.12.2017, pp. 1-4

SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?

Summary 129:
Safer in vitro diagnostic medical devices – new EU rules
Safer in vitro diagnostic medical devices – new EU rules
SUMMARY
The European Union (EU) has set new rules to ensure that in vitro diagnostic (IVD) medical devices, such as blood tests, are safe and work properly. These new rules, which will apply from 2022, will ensure a high level of health protection for patients and users of IVDs across the EU.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the requirements for the placing on the market and putting into service of in vitro diagnostic medical devices and their accessories within the EU.
The regulation applies to devices which are used in vitro, that is outside the body, for the diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment or investigation of the functions of human beings or animals.
It lays down the general safety and performance requirements for such devices and the conformity assessment procedures.
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out the requirements for the placing on the market and putting into service of in vitro diagnostic medical devices and their accessories within the EU.
The regulation applies to devices which are used in vitro, that is outside the body, for the diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment or investigation of the functions of human beings or animals.
It lays down the general safety and performance requirements for such devices and the conformity assessment procedures.
The regulation introduces a new system for the unique device identification of in vitro diagnostic medical devices, including the assignment of a basic unique device identification (UDI) to each device, and the establishment of a central database for the storage of that information.
It introduces a new system for the traceability of IVDs by means of the UDI system and the establishment of a central database for the storage of that information.
It sets out the requirements for the registration of manufacturers and importers and for the designation and monitoring of notified bodies.
The regulation also lays down rules for the performance of clinical performance studies of IVDs and the post-market surveillance of IVDs.
It sets out the requirements for the registration of manufacturers and importers and for the designation and monitoring of notified bodies.
The regulation also lays down rules for the performance of clinical performance studies of IVDs and the post-market surveillance of IVDs.
The regulation is applicable as of 26 May 2020.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 26 May 2020.
BACKGROUND
The regulation replaces Directive 98/79/EC on in vitro diagnostic medical devices.
In vitro diagnostic medical devices are used in vitro, that is outside the body, for the diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment or investigation of the functions of human beings or animals.
These devices are used in a wide range of sectors, including clinical laboratories, hospitals, health centres, doctors’ offices, pharmacies and veterinary practices.
For more information, please see the European Commission's website on in vitro diagnostic medical devices.
KEY TERMS
* In vitro diagnostic medical device: a device intended for professional use in vitro and made available for such use to test materials derived from the human body and examine the chemical and biological reactions of the human body.
* Unique device identification: a system for the identification of medical devices through a unique device identifier (UDI) that is encoded in a barcode or RFID tag, or other means of identification.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) 2017/746 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 April 2017 on in vitro diagnostic medical devices and repealing Council Directive 98/79/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 722/2004 (OJ C 272, 25.8.2017, pp. 121-156).
Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2017/746 have been incorporated into the basic text.

Summary 130:
EU rules on the making available on the market of appliances and fittings for gas-fired appliances
SUMMARY
Gas-fired appliances and fittings
EU countries have agreed on rules for the making available on the market of appliances and fittings for gas-fired appliances. These rules aim to ensure that appliances and fittings placed on the market in the EU are safe for consumers and the environment and comply with the requirements of the gas quality in the EU countries.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down the rules on the making available on the market of appliances and fittings for gas-fired appliances. It sets out the essential requirements that appliances and fittings must meet. It lays down the obligations of manufacturers, importers and distributors and sets up a system of conformity assessment procedures.
KEY POINTS
Scope
This regulation applies to appliances and fittings for burning gaseous fuels.
It does not apply to appliances and fittings which are intended to be used for military purposes, for space travel or for vehicles or aircraft, or which are intended for use on board ships or aircraft.
Essential requirements
The essential requirements set out in Annex I to this regulation cover a wide range of aspects, including:
—
safety,
—
environmental protection,
—
rational use of energy,
—
health and safety of persons.
Obligations of manufacturers
Manufacturers must ensure that their appliances and fittings comply with the essential requirements set out in Annex I to this regulation and that the technical documentation for the conformity assessment procedures is drawn up. They must also keep a register of complaints and non-conforming appliances and fittings and take corrective action in the event of non-compliance. They must ensure that appliances and fittings are accompanied by instructions and safety information and that they keep a copy of the EU declaration of conformity for 10 years after the appliance or the fitting has been placed on the market.
Obligations of importers
Importers must ensure that appliances and fittings placed on the market comply with the essential requirements set out in Annex I to this regulation and that the technical documentation for the conformity assessment procedures is drawn up. They must also keep a register of complaints and non-conforming appliances and fittings and take corrective action in the event of non-compliance. They must ensure that appliances and fittings are accompanied by instructions and safety information and that they keep a copy of the EU declaration of conformity for 10 years after the appliance or the fitting has been placed on the market.
Obligations of distributors
Distributors must ensure that appliances and fittings which they make available on the market comply with the essential requirements set out in Annex I to this regulation and that the technical documentation for the conformity assessment procedures is drawn up. They must also keep a register of complaints and non-conforming appliances and fittings and take corrective action in the event of non-compliance. They must ensure that appliances and fittings are accompanied by instructions and safety information and that they keep a copy of the EU declaration of conformity for 10 years after the appliance or the fitting has been placed on the market.
Conformity assessment procedures
The conformity assessment procedures set out in Annex III to this regulation are:
—
EU-type examination,
—
conformity to type based on internal production control,
—
conformity to type based on internal production control plus supervised product checks at random intervals,
—
conformity to type based on quality system,
—
conformity based on unit verification.
FROM WHEN DO THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 21 April 2018.
REFERENCES
Act
Entry into force
Deadline for implementation in the Member States
Official Journal
Directive 2014/30/EU
21.4.2014
19.7.2016
OJ L 96, 29.3.2014, pp. 43-63
RELATED ACTS
Directive 2009/142/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 relating to appliances burning gaseous fuels (OJ L 330, 16.12.2009, pp. 1-10).
KEY TERMS
              
Appliance: an appliance is a device, including its fittings, designed and manufactured primarily for the controlled burning of gaseous fuel in order to produce heat or power. It includes all parts of the appliance, whether new or second-hand, intended to be or likely to be attached, fitted, or incorporated in the appliance.
Fitting: a fitting is a device intended to be attached, fitted, or incorporated in an appliance. It includes all parts of the fitting, whether new or second-hand, intended to be or likely to be attached, fitted, or incorporated in the fitting.
MAIN DOCUMENTS

Summary 131:
EU rules on the cross-border transport of euro cash
SUMMARY
EU countries must allow companies to transport euro cash by road between EU countries. The cash must be transported in armoured vehicles and be accompanied by at least two CIT security staff. The vehicles must be equipped with a global navigation system and with appropriate communication tools to allow contact to be made at any time with the control centre of the CIT company operating the vehicles and with the competent national authorities.
EU countries must also allow the use of intelligent banknote neutralisation systems (IBNS) to destroy or stain banknotes that have been accessed by unauthorised persons.
EU countries may allow companies to transport euro cash by road using unarmoured vehicles equipped with IBNS. However, this option is not available for the transport of euro coins.
EU countries may decide to introduce temporary security measures going beyond those provided for in this Regulation in the event of an urgent problem affecting significantly the security of CIT operations.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes rules to ensure the security of the transport of euro cash by road between EU countries. It does not cover the transport of coins.
KEY POINTS
Cross-border transport of euro cash
Cross-border transport of euro cash by road must be carried out during the daytime.
EU countries may allow the transport of euro cash by road between EU countries using unarmoured vehicles equipped with IBNS. However, this option is not available for the transport of euro coins.
EU countries may decide to introduce temporary security measures going beyond those provided for in this Regulation in the event of an urgent problem affecting significantly the security of CIT operations.
Cross-border CIT licences
A company wishing to undertake cross-border transport of euro cash by road must apply for a cross-border CIT licence from the granting authority in its EU country of origin.
The cross-border CIT licence allows the company to carry out cross-border transport of euro cash under the terms of this Regulation.
The licence must be valid for at least 5 years and may be renewed for a further period of 5 years.
EU countries must keep a register of all the companies to which they have delivered a cross-border CIT licence and must immediately inform the Commission about its content.
Security requirements for CIT vehicles
CIT vehicles must be equipped with a global navigation system.
They must be equipped with appropriate communication tools to allow contact to be made at any time with the control centre of the CIT company operating the vehicles and with the competent national authorities.
The vehicles must be equipped with an intelligent banknote neutralisation system (IBNS) and must be accompanied by at least 2 CIT security staff.
EU countries must allow the use of IBNS for the transport of euro cash.
EU countries may decide to allow the use of IBNS for the transport of coins. However, this option is not available for the transport of coins between EU countries using unarmoured vehicles.
CIT security staff
CIT security staff must be employed by the CIT company and must be subject to a specific training module. The training must be carried out in the EU country of origin and must include the following items:
—
basic legal and security training,
—
specific training on the transport of euro cash,
—
specific training on the transport of euro cash in the host and transit Member States,
—
specific training on the use of IBNS,
—
specific training on the use of IBNS in the host and transit Member States,
—
language training as necessary to fulfil the language requirements set out in the regulation.
The training must also include the following items:
—
preventive and remedial measures in the areas of stress management and third party violence,
—
risk assessment at work,
—
user A1 and B1 language skills as defined in the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages.
EU countries must ensure that CIT security staff are covered by a valid professional weapons licence or authorisation. The licence or authorisation must be issued by the competent national authority in the EU country of origin. It must allow CIT security staff to carry weapons in the EU country of origin and in the host and transit Member States.
EU countries may recognise the professional weapons licence or authorisation of another EU country, where those EU countries allow CIT security staff to be armed.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 30 November 2012.
BACKGROUND
              
The single currency means that euro cash can be moved between EU countries. However, it is very difficult to carry out the professional cross-border transport of euro cash by road between EU countries.
This regulation aims to ensure the security of the transport of euro cash by road between EU countries.
For further information, please see the European Commission's website on the regulation.
KEY TERMS
              
CIT security staff: a person employed by a CIT company and carrying out the transport of euro cash by road between EU countries.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) No 909/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 October 2012 on the cross-border transport of euro cash between Member States and to, from and within third countries (OJ L 287, 18.10.2012, pp. 000-000).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
            
Commission Decision 2012/760/EU of 31 October 2012 on the technical rules on the standards applicable to the armouring of CIT vehicles and to bulletproof vests referred to in Articles 16, 17, 18 and 20 of Regulation (EU) No 909/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the cross-border transport of euro cash between Member States and to, from and within third countries (OJ L 314, 15.12.2012, pp. 19-21).
last update 19.01.2017



Summary 132:
rules on food information to consumers
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes rules on food information to consumers, including labelling and advertising, in order to help them make informed choices and to prevent misleading practices.
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out principles governing mandatory food information, such as the identity and composition of a food, its characteristics or the use of the product.
It also establishes the responsibilities of food business operators, including the obligation to ensure compliance with food information law and to check that the requirements are met.
Food business operators must provide consumers with mandatory information on certain products, including the name of the product, the list of ingredients and the nutrition declaration.
In addition, they may provide voluntary information, such as a warning or advice, a health claim or an indication of the place of origin or provenance of a food.
The regulation provides for specific rules on nutrition labelling, including the possibility to provide information on a per portion basis.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 December 2016, except for the rules on nutrition labelling which apply from 13 December 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The European Union (EU) has a single market where consumers can buy and sell goods and services freely. However, consumers are faced with a wide variety of food products and it is important that they are able to make informed choices. In order to help them, the regulation sets out the principles, responsibilities and obligations governing food information, including labelling and advertising.

Summary 133:
rules on the issuance of euro coins
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1278/2012 on euro coins
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It introduces binding rules for the issuance of euro coins.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all euro coins intended for circulation, which have the status of legal tender in all euro area Member States, and to collector coins, which have the status of legal tender only in the Member State of issuance.
Circulation coins
Circulation coins may be put into circulation at face value or above face value, but only if the special quality of the coin, the special packaging or any additional services provided justify the higher price.
The total number of circulation coins put into circulation for each individual issue may not exceed the higher of the following two ceilings:
0.1% of the total number of 2-euro coins put into circulation by all euro area Member States;
1% of the total number of 1- and 2-euro coins put into circulation by all euro area Member States.
Commemorative coins
Each euro area Member State may only issue 2 commemorative coins per year, except where:
commemorative coins are collectively issued by all euro area Member States; or
a commemorative coin is issued on the occasion of a temporary vacancy or a provisional occupation of the function of Head of State.
The total number of commemorative coins put into circulation for each individual issue may not exceed the higher of the following two ceilings:
0.1% of the total number of 2-euro coins put into circulation by all euro area Member States;
1% of the total number of 1- and 2-euro coins put into circulation by all euro area Member States.
Collector coins
Collector coins may be put on the market at or above face value.
The issuances of collector coins are accounted for on an aggregated basis in the volume of coin issuance to be approved by the European Central Bank.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The issuance of euro coins is currently governed by Council Regulation (EC) No 974/98 and Council Regulation (EC) No 975/98. However, the lack of mandatory provisions for the issuance of euro coins may result in different practices among euro area Member States and does not achieve a sufficiently integrated framework for the single currency.
The regulation is part of a package of measures to reform the monetary system of the European Union.
It introduces binding rules for the issuance of euro coins and sets limits on the issuance of commemorative coins and collector coins.
REFERENCES
              
Regulation (EU) No 1278/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 December 2012 on euro coins and banknotes (OJ L 339, 18.12.2012, pp. 36-39)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
              
Council Regulation (EC) No 974/98 of 3 May 1998 on the introduction of the euro (OJ L 139, 11.5.1998, pp. 1-4)
Council Regulation (EC) No 975/98 of 3 May 1998 on denominations and technical specifications of euro coins intended for circulation (OJ L 139, 11.5.1998, pp. 5-8)
Council Regulation (EU) No 1210/2010 of 15 December 2010 concerning authentication of euro coins and handling of euro coins unfit for circulation (OJ L 338, 17.12.2010, pp. 36-42)

Summary 135:
European demographic statistics
European demographic statistics
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 1265/2012 on European demographic statistics
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes a common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events*.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The regulation applies to data on:
population and on vital events*; and
total population* for specific Union purposes.
It does not apply to data on migration and international protection.
Definitions
For the purposes of the regulation, the following definitions apply:
‘Demographic statistics’: statistical data on population and vital events;
‘Population’: the number of persons in a specific geographical area at a specific time;
‘Vital events’: live births and deaths;
‘Usual residence’: the place where a person usually lives and sleeps;
‘Total population’: the total number of persons in a specific geographical area at a specific time.
Data
The regulation requires Member States to provide the European Commission (Eurostat) with data on their population and on their vital events for the previous year.
The data provided by Member States must cover the following variables:
population by age, sex and region of residence;
live births by sex, month of occurrence, live birth-order, mother’s age, mother’s year of birth, mother’s country of birth, mother’s country of citizenship and mother’s region of residence;
deaths by age, sex, year of birth, region of residence, country of birth, country of citizenship and month of occurrence.
The data provided must be based on the same population definition as the data referred to in point (a).
Member States must also provide the Commission with data on their total population at national level.
Frequency and reference time
Each year, Member States must provide the Commission (Eurostat) with data on their population and on their vital events for the previous year, and with data on their total population at national level.
The reference time for population data is the end of the reference period (midnight of 31 December). The first reference time is in 2013 and the last reference time is in 2027.
The reference period for vital events data is the calendar year in which the events occurred. The first reference period is 2013 and the last reference period is 2027.
Data sources
The data must be based on the data sources chosen by the Member State in accordance with national law and practice. Scientifically-based and well-documented statistical estimation methods must be used, where appropriate.
Quality
Member States must ensure the quality of the data transmitted.
For the purposes of the regulation, the quality criteria referred to in Article 12(1) of Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 apply to the data to be transmitted.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It entered into force on 20 January 2013 and applies from 1 January 2013. It ceases to apply on 31 August 2028.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation is part of the European Statistical System. It establishes a common legal framework for the development, production and dissemination of European statistics on population and vital events.
KEY TERMS
              
Population
The number of persons in a specific geographical area at a specific time.
Vital events
Live births and deaths.
Total population
The total number of persons in a specific geographical area at a specific time.
MAIN DOCUMENT
              
Regulation (EU) No 1265/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 November 2012 establishing a common European demographic statistics (OJ L 328, 14.12.2012, pp. 5-11)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EC) No 223/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 March 2009 on European statistics and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1101/2008 (OJ L 97, 12.4.2009, pp. 1-10)
Regulation (EC) No 862/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 on Community statistics on migration and international protection and repealing Council Regulation (EEC) No 311/76 on the compilation of statistics on foreign workers (OJ L 199, 31.7.2007, pp. 23-33)
Regulation (EC) No 763/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 9 July 2008 on population and housing censuses (OJ L 218, 13.8.2008, pp. 14-19)

Summary 136:
Labelling and marketing textile products
SUMMARY
Textile products (clothing, fabrics, household linen, etc.) may be sold in the EU only if they are clearly labelled or marked with their fibre composition.
The legislation on the labelling of textile products is being revised. The new rules will apply from 1 July 2013.
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS LEGISLATION DO?
It lays down rules concerning the use of textile fibre names and related labelling and marking of fibre composition of textile products, rules concerning the labelling or marking of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin, and rules concerning the determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis of binary and ternary textile fibre mixtures, with a view to improving the functioning of the internal market and to providing accurate information to consumers.
KEY POINTS
Textile fibre names and labelling
The legislation sets out the names of the fibres used in textile products, such as cotton, linen, silk, wool, synthetic fibres, etc. It also lays down rules concerning the labelling or marking of the fibre composition of textile products.
Labelling of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin
The legislation provides for the labelling or marking of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin, such as leather, fur, hair, feathers, etc.
Determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis
The legislation sets out the rules concerning the determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis of binary and ternary textile fibre mixtures.
FROM WHEN DO THE RULES APPLY?

BACKGROUND
The EU legislation on the labelling of textile products has been revised to simplify and clarify the rules on the use of textile fibre names and related labelling and marking of fibre composition of textile products, and to improve the functioning of the internal market.
The legislation also provides for the labelling or marking of textile products containing non-textile parts of animal origin and for the determination of the fibre composition of textile products by quantitative analysis of binary and ternary textile fibre mixtures.

Summary 137:
European Maritime and Fisheries Fund
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 508/2014 establishing ‘Horizon 2020 – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2014-2020)’
Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 — fixing multiannual financial assistance for the European territorial cohesion fund (2014-2020)
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to establish the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) for the period 2014-2020.
KEY POINTS
The EMFF is part of the European Union’s (EU) cohesion policy. It is one of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds) set up to reduce disparities between EU regions and improve the standard of living and employment prospects of EU citizens.
The EMFF supports the development of the EU’s maritime and fisheries sector and the achievement of the objectives of the common fisheries policy (CFP).
The EMFF has 3 objectives:
to promote competitive, environmentally sustainable, economically viable and socially responsible fisheries and aquaculture;
to foster the implementation of the CFP;
to foster a balanced and inclusive territorial development of fisheries and aquaculture areas.
The EMFF is financed through the EU’s annual budget.
The EU’s financial assistance under the EMFF is disbursed in accordance with the principle of shared management. The EU and the EU countries jointly manage the EMFF. The EU’s contribution to the EMFF is €7.1 billion over the 2014-2020 period.
The EU’s contribution to the EMFF is subject to a performance-based management system, which is based on the results achieved in the fisheries sector and the maritime economy. The EU’s contribution to the EMFF is paid out in annual instalments. The Commission pays the EMFF to the EU countries which in turn pay the EMFF to the beneficiaries.
The EMFF supports the following measures:
competitiveness of the fisheries and aquaculture sectors;
fostering the implementation of the CFP;
sustainable development of fisheries and aquaculture areas;
the EU’s Integrated Maritime Policy;
the European Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund.
The EU countries may decide to disburse the EMFF themselves, in accordance with the principle of shared management, or to manage it entirely themselves. The EU countries must submit operational programmes for the EMFF by 31 December 2014.
The EMFF supports the following measures:
competitiveness of the fisheries and aquaculture sectors;
fostering the implementation of the CFP;
sustainable development of fisheries and aquaculture areas;
the EU’s Integrated Maritime Policy;
the European Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund.

Summary 138:
rules on providing information to investors
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules for providing investors with key information about investment products, such as investment funds, structured deposits, insurance-based investment products and life insurance products.
KEY POINTS
WHAT TYPES OF INVESTMENT PRODUCTS DOES THIS REGULATION COVER?
The regulation covers all investment products that are marketed to retail investors, but not individual and occupational pension products that provide an income in retirement.
WHAT ARE THE RULES FOR PROVIDING INVESTMENT PRODUCTS TO INVESTORS?
Before an investment product is made available to investors, the product manufacturer must draw up a key information document (KID) and publish it on its website.
The KID must be accurate, fair, clear and not misleading. It may contain cross-references to other documents, such as a prospectus, but only where the cross-reference is related to the information required to be included in the KID.
The KID must contain the following information:
the name of the investment product;
a comprehension alert, which must be included where the product is difficult to understand;
whether the product is simple or complex;
whether the product is risky and how;
the product’s cost, including all fees and charges;
what happens if the investment product manufacturer goes bankrupt;
how long the investor should hold the product and whether the investor can take money out early;
whether the product has any environmental or social objectives;
any additional information that is relevant to the investor.
The KID must be written in plain and simple language, using clear headings and a standard format.
The KID must be provided to the investor in one of the following ways:
on paper;
by electronic means, such as email or text message;
on the manufacturer’s website.
The KID may be provided by a financial adviser or bank.
The KID must be provided free of charge.
The KID must be published on the manufacturer’s website and be available for at least 12 months.
The KID must be updated if the product is updated.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 December 2016.
BACKGROUND
The regulation is part of the European Commission’s action plan for the financial services industry. The aim is to restore investor confidence in the financial markets, in particular following the financial crisis of 2007-2008.
The regulation sets out the rules for providing investors with key information about investment products, such as investment funds, structured deposits, insurance-based investment products and life insurance products.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 30 December 2016.

Summary 139:
Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the single resolution mechanism (SRM) for banks in the euro area.
KEY POINTS
The SRM is a centralised system of resolution authorities that can resolve failing banks across the euro area. It is part of the banking union, which also includes the single supervisory mechanism (SSM) and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM).
The SRM is designed to ensure that failing banks can be resolved in an orderly manner and without endangering the financial system. It can help to avoid the need for public money to be used to bail out failing banks and can help to protect taxpayers from the cost of bank failures.
The SRM includes a single resolution board (SRB) which can act to resolve failing banks and a single resolution fund (SRF) which can provide financial support to failing banks.
The SRM applies to banks in the euro area and to non-euro area countries that are part of the SSM.
The SRM is supported by the SRF, which is funded by contributions from banks in the euro area and in non-euro area countries that are part of the SSM. It is designed to ensure that the SRF can provide financial support to failing banks across the euro area.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2015.
BACKGROUND
The SRM is part of the banking union which also includes the SSM and the ESM. It is designed to ensure that failing banks can be resolved in an orderly manner and without endangering the financial system.
The SRM is designed to ensure that failing banks can be resolved in an orderly manner and without endangering the financial system. It can help to avoid the need for public money to be used to bail out failing banks and can help to protect taxpayers from the cost of bank failures.
The SRM includes a single resolution board (SRB) which can act to resolve failing banks and a single resolution fund (SRF) which can provide financial support to failing banks.
The SRM applies to banks in the euro area and to non-euro area countries that are part of the SSM.
The SRM is supported by the SRF, which is funded by contributions from banks in the euro area and in non-euro area countries that are part of the SSM. It is designed to ensure that the SRF can provide financial support to failing banks across the euro area.
KEY TERMS
              
Single resolution mechanism (SRM): a centralised system of resolution authorities that can resolve failing banks across the euro area.
Single resolution board (SRB): a centralised system of resolution authorities that can resolve failing banks across the euro area.
Single resolution fund (SRF): a centralised system of resolution authorities that can resolve failing banks across the euro area.

Summary 141:
Cross-border insolvency proceedings — new rules
Cross-border insolvency proceedings — new rules
SUMMARY
The new rules on insolvency proceedings aim at providing a harmonised legal framework for the proper administration of cross-border insolvency proceedings, and for the restructuring and winding-up of companies in difficulty.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules on insolvency proceedings and the conditions for the coordination of the measures to be taken in respect of the assets and affairs of debtors who carry on an economic activity in several EU countries.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to insolvency proceedings, which meet the conditions set out in it, irrespective of whether the debtor is a natural person or a legal person, a trader or an individual.
It lays down the rules on the opening, coordination, cooperation and communication of insolvency proceedings, including the rules on the choice of court, the applicable law, the cooperation of the courts and the rights of creditors.
It provides for the possibility of coordinating the administration of the realisation or use of the debtor's assets and affairs and for the possibility of restructuring the debtor's business.
It introduces a procedure for the coordination of the insolvency proceedings of members of a group of companies.
It also lays down rules on the cooperation, communication and coordination in the framework of the insolvency of members of a group of companies.
The regulation does not apply to proceedings which concern:
insurance undertakings;
credit institutions;
investment firms and other firms, institutions and undertakings to the extent that they are covered by Directive 2001/24/EC; or
collective investment undertakings.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 26 June 2017.
BACKGROUND
The regulation is part of the Commission's plan to create a single market for businesses in difficulty.
In 2012, the Commission published a communication on a new approach to business failure and insolvency, which aimed at better protecting the rights of creditors and investors in the EU.
In 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a regulation on insolvency proceedings. The new rules on insolvency proceedings aim at providing a harmonised legal framework for the proper administration of cross-border insolvency proceedings, and for the restructuring and winding-up of companies in difficulty.
The regulation was adopted in 2015 and it entered into force on 26 June 2017.
KEY TERMS
* Centre of the debtor’s main interests: the place where the debtor carries on the principal part of its business activity.
* Insolvency proceedings: the proceedings, whether or not initiated by the debtor, which are opened in order to deal with the estate of a debtor who is insolvent or who is likely to become insolvent.
* Insolvency practitioner: the person responsible for the administration of the estate of the debtor, or of the property of the debtor in possession, or of the property of the debtor in a procedure of reorganisation.
* Insolvency register: the register in which information concerning insolvency proceedings is published.

Summary 142:
Liability of carriers in respect of accidents and injury to passengers
SUMMARY
The purpose of this Regulation is to ensure that passengers travelling by sea are properly compensated in the event of an accident. It does not cover passengers travelling on domestic sea routes within a single Member State.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
              
It lays down the conditions under which carriers are liable for accidents and injuries to passengers and the level of compensation to be paid to them.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all international maritime transport services between the Member States and non-EU countries and to all domestic sea-going voyages.
It incorporates and makes binding parts of the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Guidelines for the implementation of the Athens Convention relating to the carriage of passengers and their luggage by sea, 1974.
The regulation applies to all domestic sea-going voyages if the ship on which the passenger travels is a passenger ship of Classes A and B under Directive 98/18/EC (see summary) or a passenger ship of Class C under Directive 2009/16/EC (see summary).
Compensation for death and personal injury
The carrier is liable for death and personal injury to a passenger caused by a shipping incident. The limit of liability is 250,000 units of account (SPECIAL DRAWING RIGHT) per passenger per carriage.
Compensation for loss of or damage to luggage
The carrier is liable for loss of or damage to luggage other than cabin luggage. The limit of liability is 1,200 units of account per passenger per carriage.
Compensation for mobility equipment or other specific equipment used by a passenger with reduced mobility
The carrier is liable for loss of, or damage to, mobility equipment or other specific equipment used by a passenger with reduced mobility. The compensation shall correspond to the replacement value of the equipment concerned or, where applicable, to the costs relating to repairs.
Compensation for loss of or damage to vehicles
The carrier is liable for loss of, or damage to, vehicles. The compensation shall correspond to the replacement value of the vehicle concerned or, where applicable, to the costs relating to repairs.
Compensation for loss of or damage to money, securities and valuables
The carrier is liable for loss of, or damage to, money, securities and valuables. The compensation shall correspond to the replacement value of the items concerned or, where applicable, to the costs relating to repairs.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of life or personal injury to a passenger caused by any of the risks referred to in paragraph 2.2 of the IMO Guidelines if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to luggage if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to mobility equipment or other specific equipment used by a passenger with reduced mobility if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to vehicles if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to money, securities and valuables if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to cabin luggage if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The limit of liability is 250,000 units of account per passenger per carriage.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to luggage other than cabin luggage if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The limit of liability is 1,200 units of account per passenger per carriage.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to vehicles if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The limit of liability is 4,200 units of account per passenger per carriage.
The carrier may limit his liability in respect of claims for loss of or damage to money, securities and valuables if the performance of the carriage or part thereof has been entrusted to a performing carrier.
The limit of liability is 3,375 units of account per passenger per carriage.
Information for passengers
The carrier and the performing carrier must provide passengers with information on their rights under this regulation before departure.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation applies to all international maritime transport services between the Member States and non-EU countries and to all domestic sea-going voyages.
For further information, please see the European Commission's website on maritime safety.
KEY TERMS
              
Carriage: the transportation of passengers and/or their luggage on board a ship.
Carriers: the ship-owner or bareboat charterer, the manager, and the operator.
Performing carrier: a carrier who has entrusted the performance of the carriage or part thereof to another carrier.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EU) No 59/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 March 2012 on a European Roadmap for a Single European Transport Area – Towards a strong and efficient transport system for Europe and amending Framework Regulation (EC) No 1366/2006 and Regulations (EC) No 1016/2006 and (EU) No 181/2011 (Outh 2012 L 12, 17.1.2012, pp. 1-22)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
