Summary 144:
rules on access to the road haulage and bus and coach markets
SUMMARY
EU countries are responsible for ensuring that road haulage and bus and coach operators meet certain conditions in order to be allowed to carry out these activities. This is to ensure a high level of road safety and to prevent abuse and fraud. The EU sets out the conditions in the form of common rules and lays down the penalties for infringements of these rules.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the conditions for admission to the occupation of road transport operator and the conditions for monitoring and controlling the sector.
It defines the conditions for admission to the occupation of road transport operator, which consist of:
an effective and stable establishment in a Member State;
good repute of the undertaking and its transport managers;
appropriate financial standing;
appropriate professional competence.
It lays down the conditions for monitoring and controlling the sector, which consist of:
authorisation of the undertaking;
annual checks by the competent authorities;
procedures for the suspension or withdrawal of authorisation;
the possibility of a declaration of unfitness of a transport manager;
exemption from examination for certain categories of persons;
exemption from the requirement of financial standing for certain categories of undertakings;
simplification of the administrative procedures;
administrative cooperation between Member States.
KEY POINTS
Conditions for admission to the occupation of road transport operator
The conditions for admission to the occupation of road transport operator are:
an effective and stable establishment in a Member State;
good repute of the undertaking and its transport managers;
appropriate financial standing;
appropriate professional competence.
Effective and stable establishment in a Member State
An undertaking must have an effective and stable establishment in a Member State. This means that it must have a registered office in a Member State and a permanent address there where its management and supervision are carried out. In addition, it must have a registered address in a Member State and a contact address in a Member State. A registered address is an address where the undertaking is officially registered and a contact address is an address where it can be contacted.
Good repute
An undertaking must be of good repute. It must not have been convicted of a serious infringement of Community rules within the previous 5 years. The competent authorities must verify that the undertaking and its transport managers are of good repute. A conviction or penalty incurred by a transport manager or a road transport undertaking in one or more Member States for the most serious infringements of Community rules should result in the loss of good repute. A transport manager is a person who is responsible for the management of a road transport undertaking.
Appropriate financial standing
An undertaking must have appropriate financial standing. This means that it must be able to meet its financial obligations in the course of the annual accounting year. The minimum amount of the financial standing is €250,000. The amount may be reduced for certain categories of undertakings. The competent authorities determine the conditions for an undertaking to satisfy the requirement of financial standing.
Appropriate professional competence
An undertaking must have appropriate professional competence. The minimum level of knowledge of the applicant is set out in Annex I to the Regulation. The minimum duration of the examinations is 3 hours for each of the 3 subjects. The duration of the examinations may be longer for certain categories of undertakings.
Conditions for monitoring and controlling the sector
The Regulation sets out the conditions for monitoring and controlling the sector. These consist of:
authorisation of the undertaking;
annual checks by the competent authorities;
procedures for the suspension or withdrawal of authorisation;
the possibility of a declaration of unfitness of a transport manager;
exemption from examination for certain categories of persons;
exemption from the requirement of financial standing for certain categories of undertakings;
simplification of the administrative procedures;
administrative cooperation between Member States.
Authorisation of the undertaking
An undertaking which complies with the requirements laid down in Article 3 of the Regulation may, upon application, be authorised to engage in the occupation of road transport operator.
Annual checks by the competent authorities
The competent authorities must monitor whether undertakings which they have authorised to engage in the occupation of road transport operator continue to fulfil the requirements laid down in Article 3 of the Regulation. They must check whether the conditions of good repute and financial standing are met. They may also check whether the condition of professional competence is met. In order to do this, they may carry out spot checks. They must check whether the conditions of good repute and financial standing are met. They may also check whether the condition of professional competence is met. In order to do this, they may carry out spot checks.
Procedures for the suspension or withdrawal of authorisation
The competent authorities may suspend or withdraw an authorisation granted to an undertaking if it no longer fulfils the conditions set out in Article 3 of the Regulation. They may also suspend or withdraw an authorisation if it has been suspended or withdrawn in another Member State. The competent authorities must inform the undertaking of the reasons for the suspension or withdrawal of the authorisation and of the measures to be taken for the authorisation to be reinstated.
Declaration of unfitness of a transport manager
The competent authorities may declare a transport manager unfit if he or she has been convicted of a serious infringement of Community rules or if he or she has been convicted of an infringement of Community rules which constitutes a very serious breach of the obligation to act with due care and attention.
Exemption from examination
Persons who provide proof that they have continuously managed a road haulage undertaking or a road passenger transport undertaking in one or more Member States for the period of 10 years before 4 December 2009 may be exempt from the examinations referred to in Article 8(1) of the Regulation.
Exemption from the requirement of financial standing
Undertakings which are established in the regions covered by Article 2(4) of the Regulation may be exempt from the requirement of financial standing.
Simplification of the administrative procedures
The competent authorities must take the necessary measures to simplify the administrative procedures for the application for authorisation and the procedures for the suspension or withdrawal of authorisation. They must also ensure that the requirements laid down in Article 3 of the Regulation are applied more effectively and more uniformly.
Administrative cooperation between Member States
Each Member State must keep a national electronic register of road transport undertakings which have been authorised by a competent authority designated by it to engage in the occupation of road transport operator. The register must contain at least the following data:
the name and legal form of the undertaking;
the address of its establishment;
the names of the transport managers designated to meet the conditions as to good repute and professional competence or, as appropriate, the name of a legal representative;
the type of authorisation, the number of vehicles it covers and, where appropriate, the serial number of the Community licence and of the certified copies;
the annual accounts of the undertaking;
the date of the authorisation;
the date of the expiry of the authorisation;
the date of the withdrawal of the authorisation;
the date of the suspension of the authorisation;
the date of the declaration of unfitness of a transport manager;
the date of the withdrawal of the declaration of unfitness of a transport manager;
the date of the withdrawal of the declaration of unfitness of a transport manager;
the date of the notification of a serious infringement;
the date of the withdrawal of the notification

Summary 146:
EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work
EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a common framework for the systematic production of Community statistics on public health and health and safety at work.
KEY POINTS
The statistics cover:
health status and health determinants (e.g. health insurance coverage, health care services, self-assessed health, chronic diseases);
health care (e.g. health care facilities, health care human resources, health care utilisation, health care expenditure and financing);
causes of death (e.g. death rates, mortality, infant mortality, neonatal mortality, maternal mortality, stillbirths, leading causes of death);
accidents at work (e.g. fatal accidents at work, accidents at work resulting in more than 3 days of absence from work, workplace accidents, injuries, severity, characteristics of the workplace);
occupational diseases and other work-related health problems and illnesses (e.g. recognised cases of occupational disease and deaths due to occupational disease, work-related health problems and illnesses).
The statistical data are provided by the Member States to the European Commission (Eurostat) on a voluntary basis.
The statistical methodologies and data collections to be developed for the compilation of statistics on public health and health and safety at work at Community level shall take into consideration the need for coordination, whenever relevant, with the activities of international organisations in the field, with a view to ensuring international comparability of statistics and consistency of data collections as well as avoiding duplication of effort and of deliveries of data by Member States.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
From 15 May 2009.
BACKGROUND
The production of specific Community statistics is governed by Regulation (EC) No 322/97 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 February 1997 on Community Statistics.
For further information please see the Eurostat website.

Summary 147:
Community statistics on job vacancies
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a set of rules for the production of Community statistics on job vacancies.
KEY POINTS
The Commission (Eurostat) will produce quarterly data on job vacancies in the European Union (EU) and in each of the EU countries.
The data will cover all economic activities except those of households as employers and the activities of extraterritorial organisations and bodies. Agriculture, forestry and fishing activities will be optional.
The data will be broken down by economic activity in accordance with the NACE classification (Nomenclature statistique des activités économiques dans la Communauté européenne) in force at section level.
The data will distinguish between vacancies for fixed-term and permanent jobs.
The reference dates for the data will be determined by the Commission (Eurostat).
The data will be provided using business surveys. Other sources, such as administrative data, may be used provided that they are appropriate in terms of quality.
The data will be transmitted to the Commission (Eurostat) in a format and within transmission deadlines to be determined by the Commission (Eurostat).
The Commission (Eurostat) will assess the quality of the data transmitted.
The Commission (Eurostat) will set out the appropriate framework for the establishment of a series of feasibility studies.
The Commission (Eurostat) will adopt implementing measures in accordance with the regulatory procedure with scrutiny referred to in Article 9(2).
The Commission (Eurostat) will publish the statistics on its website on a quarterly basis.
The first reference quarter will be the first quarter of 2011.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 24 June 2010.
BACKGROUND
The Action Plan on EMU Statistical Requirements, which was endorsed by the Council on 29 September 2000, and subsequent progress reports on the implementation of that plan, identified as a priority the development of a legal basis covering job vacancy statistics.
The Employment Committee established by Council Decision 2000/98/EC (4) endorses the need for an indicator for job vacancies in order to monitor the European Employment Strategy laid down in Council Decision 2005/600/EC of 12 July 2005 on Guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States (5).
Decision No 1672/2006/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 October 2006 establishing a Community Programme for Employment and Social Solidarity — Progress (6), provides for the financing of the relevant actions, including, as specified therein, improving the understanding of the employment situation and prospects, in particular through analysis and studies and the development of statistics and common indicators within the framework of the European Employment Strategy.
KEY WORDS
              
Job vacancy, NACE, Eurostat, Regulation, Council.

Summary 148:
Hydrogen systems and components: safety requirements
The European Union (EU) is working towards developing a hydrogen economy in order to reduce its dependence on oil and to improve the environment.
The aim of this Regulation is to establish requirements for the type-approval of motor vehicles with regard to hydrogen propulsion and for the type-approval of hydrogen components and hydrogen systems.
It also establishes requirements for the installation of such components and systems.
KEY POINTS
The Regulation applies to:
hydrogen-powered vehicles of categories M and N, as defined in Annex II to Directive 2007/46/EC, including impact protection and the electric safety of such vehicles;
hydrogen components, including check valves and non-return valves, pressure relief devices, heat exchangers and excess flow systems;
hydrogen systems, including the vehicle interface system, the excess flow system, the overpressure protection system and the heat exchanger failure detection system.
The Regulation lays down the following requirements:
hydrogen components and systems must function in a correct and safe way and reliably withstand electrical, mechanical, thermal and chemical operating conditions without leaking or visibly deforming;
hydrogen systems are protected against over-pressurisation;
the materials used for those parts of hydrogen components and systems that are in contact with hydrogen must be resistant to hydrogen embrittlement;
hydrogen containers designed to use liquid hydrogen must be tested in accordance with the test procedures set out in Annex II;
hydrogen components, other than containers, designed to use liquid hydrogen must be tested in accordance with the test procedures set out in Annex III;
hydrogen containers designed to use compressed (gaseous) hydrogen must be classified in accordance with point 1 of Annex IV;
hydrogen components, other than containers, designed to use compressed (gaseous) hydrogen must be tested in accordance with the test procedures set out in Annex V;
hydrogen systems must be installed in accordance with Annex VI.
Manufacturers must ensure that hydrogen components and systems function in a correct and safe way and reliably withstand electrical, mechanical, thermal and chemical operating conditions without leaking or visibly deforming. Hydrogen systems must be protected against over-pressurisation.
The Commission may adopt implementing measures, such as specifications for requirements relating to the use of pure hydrogen or a mixture of hydrogen and natural gas/biomethane, new forms of hydrogen storage or usage, the impact protection of vehicles with regard to the integrity of hydrogen components and systems, integrated system safety requirements, covering at least the detection of leakage and requirements relating to purge gas, and electrical isolation and electric safety.
Member States must lay down the provisions on penalties applicable for infringement by manufacturers of the provisions of this Regulation and its implementing measures and must take all measures necessary to ensure that they are implemented. The penalties provided for must be effective, proportionate and dissuasive.

Summary 149:
rules for the internal gas market
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down basic principles and rules for access to and use of gas networks, including gas storage facilities and liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities, in order to ensure that the gas market operates in a fair, transparent and efficient manner.
It also establishes a European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gas (ENTSOG) to promote the completion and functioning of the internal market in natural gas and cross-border trade, and to ensure the optimal management, coordinated operation and sound technical evolution of the natural gas transmission network.
KEY POINTS
The ENTSOG is composed of the national transmission system operators (TSOs) in the EU. It is responsible for developing and implementing network codes, non-binding ten-year network development plans and annual work programmes, and for coordinating and promoting regional cooperation structures.
TSOs are responsible for developing and implementing non-binding guidelines and harmonised contracts for the internal market in gas. They are also responsible for implementing the network codes and for providing network users with information on tariffs, capacity and physical status of the network.
TSOs must make available their transmission systems to all users on a non-discriminatory basis. They must develop and implement transparent and non-discriminatory balancing systems and transparent, non-discriminatory congestion-management procedures. They must also ensure the physical integrity of the gas transmission network.
TSOs must ensure the provision of third-party access services on the basis of harmonised transport contracts, which provide for the availability of short-term and long-term capacity, as well as for the possibility of reselling or subletting contracted capacity.
TSOs must provide network users with information on tariffs, capacity and physical status of the network. They must also provide network users with information on balancing, congestion-management and capacity-allocation mechanisms.
The Commission has adopted 6 network codes:
Capacity Allocation and Congestion Management
Security of Gas Supply
Guidelines for System Integrity and System Restoration
Guidelines for Harmonised Transmission Tariffs
Guidelines for Security of Supply and Integrity of Electricity Systems
Guidelines for Electricity Balancing.
FROM WHEN DO THE RULES APPLY?
The regulation applies from 3 May 2010.
BACKGROUND
The internal gas market is not yet fully integrated. The regulation seeks to further develop the internal gas market in order to ensure that it operates in a fair, transparent and efficient manner.
The regulation is one of the measures adopted by the EU to establish the single market for gas.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on the internal market for gas.

Summary 150:
procedure for authorising Member States to amend or conclude agreements with third countries in civil matters
SUMMARY
This Regulation establishes a procedure to authorise a Member State to amend an existing agreement or to negotiate and conclude a new agreement with a third country, subject to the conditions laid down in this Regulation. This procedure is without prejudice to the respective competences of the Community and of the Member States.
This Regulation shall apply to agreements concerning particular matters falling, entirely or partly, within the scope of Regulation (EC) No 593/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 June 2008 on the law applicable to contractual obligations (Rome I) and Regulation (EC) No 864/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 on the law applicable to non-contractual obligations (Rome II).
This Regulation shall not apply if the Community has already concluded an agreement with the third country concerned on the same subject matter.
This Regulation shall not apply to agreements with Switzerland.
Where a Member State intends to enter into negotiations in order to amend an existing agreement or to conclude a new agreement falling within the scope of this Regulation, it shall notify the Commission in writing of its intention at the earliest possible moment before the envisaged opening of formal negotiations.
Upon receipt of the notification, the Commission shall assess whether the envisaged agreement meets the conditions set out in Article 4(2) of this Regulation.
If the envisaged agreement meets the conditions set out in Article 4(2) of this Regulation, the Commission shall, within 90 days of receipt of the notification, give a reasoned decision on the application of the Member State authorising it to open formal negotiations on that agreement.
If the envisaged agreement does not meet the conditions set out in Article 4(2) of this Regulation, the Commission shall, within 90 days of receipt of the notification, give an opinion to the Member State concerned.
Before signing a negotiated agreement, the Member State concerned shall notify the outcome of the negotiations to the Commission and shall transmit to it the text of the agreement.
Upon receipt of the notification, the Commission shall assess whether the negotiated agreement:
—
meets the condition set out in Article 4(2)(b);
—
meets the condition set out in Article 4(2)(c), in so far as there are new and exceptional circumstances in relation to that condition; and
—
fulfils the requirement under Article 5(2).
If the negotiated agreement fulfils the conditions and requirements referred to in the first subparagraph, the Commission shall, within 90 days of receipt of the notification, give a reasoned decision on the application of the Member State authorising it to conclude that agreement.
If, on the basis of its assessment under Article 8(2), the Commission intends not to authorise the conclusion of the negotiated agreement, it shall give an opinion to the Member State concerned, as well as to the European Parliament and to the Council, within 90 days of receipt of the notification.
This Regulation shall expire three years after the submission by the Commission of the report referred to in Article 13 of this Regulation.

EUROSTAT is responsible for collecting and compiling EU statistics on migration and international protection. These statistics are used to develop and monitor EU policies and legislation in these areas.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?

KEY POINTS

reporting and review.
International migration
EU countries must provide the European Commission (Eurostat) with statistics on:
immigration to and emigration from their territory;
the number of persons entering and leaving their territory;
the number of persons staying in their territory for more than 12 months;
the number of persons entering and leaving the territory of another EU country;
the number of persons staying in another EU country for more than 12 months;
the number of persons staying in another EU country for more than 12 months;
the number of births and deaths.
These statistics must relate to a reference period of 1 calendar year and be supplied to the Commission (Eurostat) within 12 months of the end of the reference year. They must be disaggregated by age and sex, and by the citizenship of the persons concerned.
International protection
EU countries must provide the Commission (Eurostat) with statistics on:
the number of persons having submitted an application for international protection or having been included in such an application as a family member during the reference period;
the number of persons who are the subject of applications for international protection under consideration by the responsible national authority at the end of the reference period;
applications for international protection having been withdrawn during the reference period.
These statistics must relate to reference periods of 1 calendar month and be supplied to the Commission (Eurostat) within 2 months of the end of the reference month. The first reference month is January 2008.
Data sources and quality standards
EU countries must supply the Commission (Eurostat) with information on the data sources used, the reasons for the selection of these sources and the effects of the selected data sources on the quality of the statistics, and on the estimation methods used, and must keep the Commission (Eurostat) informed of changes thereto.
EU countries must inform the Commission (Eurostat) without delay of revisions and corrections to the statistics supplied under this regulation, and of any changes in the methods and data sources used.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It has applied since 20 August 2007.
BACKGROUND
International migration, international protection and the prevention of illegal entry and stay are important areas for EU action. The EU needs to know how many people are moving in and out of the EU, and where they come from and are going to.
EU countries collect and provide statistics to the Commission (Eurostat) on migration and international protection. These statistics are used to develop and monitor EU policies and legislation in these areas.
For more information, see the Eurostat website.
KEY TERMS
International migration: the movement of persons across international borders.
International protection: the right of asylum, which is a fundamental human right and is enshrined in the EU Treaties.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EC) No 862/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 on the Community statistics on migration and international protection (OJ L 199, 31.7.2007, pp. 15-25)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Decision 2006/684/EC of 23 August 2006 on the adoption of the format for the transmission of data referred to in Article 9(3) of Regulation (EC) No 862/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council on Community statistics on migration and international protection (OJ L 264, 26.9.2006, pp. 7-8)
Commission Recommendation 2013/444/EU of 17 September 2013 on the quality of the statistics on migration and international protection (OJ L 247, 18.9.2013, pp. 1-9)

Summary 152:
EU audit reform
SUMMARY
EU audit reform
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION AND DIRECTIVE?
The EU audit reform package aims to improve the quality and transparency of statutory audits of companies and other entities. It also aims to enhance the EU’s financial market supervision.
KEY POINTS
The reform package comprises two main elements:
a regulation laying down the conditions for carrying out statutory audits of companies and other entities;
a directive laying down the rules on the quality of statutory audits.
The regulation sets out the conditions for carrying out statutory audits of public-interest entities, including banks, insurance companies, investment firms and credit institutions.
The directive establishes a system of quality assurance for statutory auditors and audit firms.
FROM WHEN DO THE REGULATION AND DIRECTIVE APPLY?
The regulation applies from 17 June 2016.
The directive applies from 6 July 2016.
BACKGROUND
The EU audit reform package is part of the EU’s response to the financial and economic crisis. It is a comprehensive package that improves the quality and transparency of statutory audits of companies and other entities, and enhances the EU’s financial market supervision.
The regulation and directive together establish a new EU audit model, which aims to:
ensure high quality of statutory audits of public-interest entities, such as banks, insurance companies, investment firms and credit institutions;
ensure that the financial statements of such entities are prepared in compliance with the relevant accounting standards;
ensure that the financial statements are reliable, credible and transparent;
ensure that investors, creditors and other interested parties can have confidence in the integrity of the financial reporting system;
ensure that the EU’s financial market supervision is enhanced.
The regulation sets out the conditions for carrying out statutory audits of public-interest entities, while the directive establishes a system of quality assurance for statutory auditors and audit firms.
The regulation and directive complement Directive 2006/43/EC, which establishes a framework for statutory audit in the EU.
KEY TERMS
Statutory audit: the audit of the annual and consolidated accounts of public-interest entities, which are subject to the audit.
Public-interest entity: a public-interest entity is an entity which is either a credit institution, an insurance undertaking or an investment firm, or an entity which is subject to the accounting and auditing rules applicable to credit institutions, insurance undertakings or investment firms.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Directive 2014/56/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 amending Directive 2006/43/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council and Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards audit exemptions for certain small and micro entities (OJ L 158, 27.5.2014, pp. 96-100)
Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2014 on EU audit regulation and of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 April 2014 on EU audit regulation and public interest entities audit (OJ L 158, 27.5.2014, pp. 131-156)
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Directive 2006/43/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 May 2006 on statutory audits of annual accounts and consolidated accounts (OJ L 157, 9.6.2006, pp. 87-110)
Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 June 2013 on prudential requirements for credit institutions and investment firms and amending Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 (OJ L 176, 27.6.2013, pp. 1-145)

Summary 153:
reforming the common fisheries policy
The common fisheries policy (CFP) is the European Union's (EU's) system for managing and conserving its marine resources. The CFP is a crucial element of the EU's maritime policy, which aims to develop the potential of the Union's seas and coasts.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It lays down the objectives and principles for the common fisheries policy (CFP) and the conditions for its implementation.
KEY POINTS
The CFP aims to:
conserve and manage marine biological resources (fish stocks) and aquatic ecosystems;
ensure the sustainability of fisheries and the economic, social and environmental viability of fishing activities;
promote the competitiveness of the EU's fishing and aquaculture sectors;
ensure the economic and social viability of coastal communities;
ensure that fishing activities are compatible with other activities in the marine environment;
promote the sustainable development of the Union’s oceans and seas;
contribute to the implementation of the Union’s international obligations;
ensure the involvement of operators in the CFP;
ensure the involvement of the EU’s regions and cities in the CFP.
The CFP shall be guided by 6 principles of good governance:
clear definition of responsibilities at the EU, regional, national and local levels;
regional specificities through a regionalised approach;
scientific advice;
a long-term perspective;
administrative cost-efficiency;
appropriate involvement of operators.
The CFP shall apply the precautionary approach to fisheries management, and shall aim to ensure that exploitation of living marine biological resources restores and maintains populations of harvested species above levels which can produce the maximum sustainable yield.
The CFP shall contribute to the protection of marine ecosystems by establishing:
fish stock recovery areas;
biologically sensitive protected areas.
It shall also contribute to the sustainable exploitation of marine biological resources by:
establishing multiannual plans;
avoiding and minimising unwanted catches;
introducing a landing obligation for certain species;
introducing measures to address the impact of fishing activities on the marine environment.
The CFP shall be implemented in a way that is consistent with other Union policies and, in particular, that takes into account interactions with other maritime policy areas. It shall be implemented in a way that is consistent with the Union's international obligations regarding conservation and cooperation under those international instruments.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2014.
BACKGROUND
The CFP is the EU's system for managing and conserving its marine resources. The CFP is a crucial element of the EU's maritime policy, which aims to develop the potential of the Union's seas and coasts.
For more information, please see the European Commission's website on the common fisheries policy.
KEY TERMS
Fish stock: a population of fish of the same species and age group, within a defined geographical area, which is capable of producing maximum sustainable yield.
Fish stock recovery area: an area of the sea designated by the Commission, in accordance with the best available scientific advice, where the fishing mortality is very low or negligible and the biomass of the fish stocks is very high or close to the carrying capacity of the environment.
Biologically sensitive protected area: an area of the sea designated by the Commission, in accordance with the best available scientific advice, where the fishing mortality is very low or negligible and the biomass of the fish stocks is very high or close to the carrying capacity of the environment.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 on the Common Fisheries Policy (OJ L 354, 20.12.2013, pp. 1-29).
Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013 have been incorporated into the basic text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only.
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions: Towards a future common fisheries policy (COM(2011) 165 final, 28.4.2011).
last update 14.02.2018

penalties applicable to members who infringe decisions adopted to implement the plan concerned.
The competent national authorities must approve the production and marketing plan.

The Commission may adopt implementing acts concerning the format of publication by the EU countries of the trigger prices.

the quality, size, weight, packing, presentation or labelling of the products;
the minimum marketing sizes;
specifications of preserved products in accordance with conservation requirements and international obligations.

Summary 155:
safety and transparency in the settlement of financial transactions
SUMMARY
SETTLEMENT OF FINANCIAL TRANSACTIONS
Settlement of financial transactions plays a key role in the financial markets. It is the process that transfers ownership of securities from the seller to the buyer.
The settlement process is complex and involves several players, such as banks, investment firms, central securities depositories (CSDs) and central counterparty clearing houses (CCPs). In the absence of uniform rules, this has led to a fragmentation of the settlement process across the EU. This Regulation aims to ensure the safety and transparency of the settlement process for financial transactions in the EU.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It lays down rules on the settlement of financial transactions and on the activities of CSDs, which operate securities settlement systems.
KEY POINTS
Settlement of financial transactions
The Regulation lays down rules on the settlement of financial transactions in order to ensure the safety and transparency of the settlement process.
The Regulation applies to the settlement of all financial instruments, such as transferable securities, money-market instruments, units in collective investment undertakings and emission allowances, unless otherwise specified in the Regulation.
The Regulation requires CSDs to ensure the timely settlement of securities transactions and the integrity of the securities issue. The Regulation also requires CSDs to monitor settlement fails, which are transactions that have not been settled on the intended settlement date. It also establishes rules for the buy-in and the sell-out procedures to address settlement fails.
Activities of CSDs
The Regulation also lays down rules on the activities of CSDs. CSDs must provide certain core services, which consist of settlement, implying the operation of a securities settlement system, notary and central securities accounts maintenance services.
CSDs must also provide certain ancillary services, such as custody, safe custody and sub-custody services, which contribute to enhancing the safety, efficiency and transparency of the securities markets.
The Regulation also lays down rules on the authorisation and supervision of CSDs. CSDs are subject to authorisation and supervision by competent authorities in the EU. The competent authorities are responsible for ensuring that CSDs comply with the requirements of the Regulation. They may impose administrative penalties and other measures in the event of non-compliance with the Regulation.
The Regulation establishes a system of recognition for third-country CSDs, which are CSDs established outside the EU. Third-country CSDs that intend to provide certain services or to set up a branch in the EU must be recognised by ESMA. The Regulation also lays down rules on the application of the prudential requirements applicable to CSDs.
The Regulation contains rules on the capital requirements of CSDs and of credit institutions that are part of the same group of undertakings as a CSD.
The Regulation lays down rules on the law applicable to proprietary aspects in relation to the securities held in the accounts maintained by CSDs.
The Regulation provides that CSDs may provide services in other Member States, including through setting up a branch. It lays down rules on the authorisation and supervision of CSDs operating in other Member States.
The Regulation establishes a system of recognition for third-country CSDs that intend to provide certain services or to set up a branch in the EU.
The Regulation lays down rules on the cooperation between competent authorities.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 9 January 2015.
BACKGROUND
The settlement process is complex and involves several players, such as banks, investment firms, central securities depositories (CSDs) and central counterparty clearing houses (CCPs). In the absence of uniform rules, this has led to a fragmentation of the settlement process across the EU.
The Regulation aims to ensure the safety and transparency of the settlement process for financial transactions in the EU.
For further information please see the Commission’s website on the central securities depository regulation and the Commission’s website on the central counterparty clearing houses regulation.
KEY TERMS
Settlement: the process that transfers ownership of securities from the seller to the buyer.
Central securities depository: an institution that provides the services of settlement, notary and central securities accounts maintenance services.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 909/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 July 2013 on central securities depositories and template standardised contractual terms (OJ C 229, 11.8.2014, pp. 1-27).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1287/2013 of 14 August 2013 laying down standardised templates for the application of Regulation (EU) No 909/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on central securities depositories and Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning restrictive measures against Iran (OJ C 229, 11.8.2014, pp. 28-36).
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1288/2013 of 14 August 2013 on the calculation of the capital surcharge for credit institutions and central securities depositories in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 909/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on central securities depositories and Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning restrictive measures against Iran (OJ C 229, 11.8.2014, pp. 37-39).

Summary 156:
EU Cohesion Fund
The EU Cohesion Fund aims to reduce disparities between the various regions of the EU by financing infrastructure and environmental projects.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the tasks of the EU Cohesion Fund and the scope of its support in order to promote sustainable development and economic, social and territorial cohesion in the European Union (EU).
KEY POINTS
The Cohesion Fund supports
investment in the environment, including areas related to sustainable development and energy which present environmental benefits;
transport infrastructure projects of European added value provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1316/2013;
technical assistance.
It does not support:
the decommissioning or the construction of nuclear power stations;
investment to achieve the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from activities listed in Annex I to Directive 2003/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council;
housing, other than that related to the promotion of energy efficiency or renewable energy use;
activities in the field of research and innovation;
activities in the field of health;
activities in the field of education, training, youth, sport and culture;
activities in the field of justice, fundamental rights and citizenship;
activities in the field of security and safeguarding public spaces;
activities in the field of employment, social inclusion and poverty reduction;
activities in the field of tourism.
It supports activities which contribute to achieving the investment priorities set out in Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013. These priorities cover:
developing the energy union;
developing a low-carbon economy;
supporting growth and jobs;
enhancing institutional capacity of public authorities and stakeholders and efficient public administration.
It supports technical assistance in order to improve the administrative capacity of public authorities to manage the implementation of the Cohesion Fund.
It supports projects of common interest in the transport sector.
The Cohesion Fund is established for a period from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2023.
KEYWORDS
EU Cohesion Fund, infrastructure, environmental projects, transport sector, technical assistance, investment priorities.
REFERENCES
The regulation has the following references:
Official Journal L 261, 15.10.2013, pp. 179-184.
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1085/2006 [Official Journal L 347, 20.12.2013, pp. 320-326].

Summary 158:
European territorial cooperation goal
SUMMARY
This Regulation establishes the scope of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) with regard to the European territorial cooperation goal and lays down specific provisions concerning that goal.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes the scope of the ERDF with regard to the European territorial cooperation goal and lays down specific provisions concerning that goal.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The European territorial cooperation goal covers cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation.
The scope of the ERDF with regard to the European territorial cooperation goal includes:
cross-border cooperation, which covers cooperation between regions in different Member States;
transnational cooperation, which covers cooperation between regions within the same Member State;
interregional cooperation, which covers cooperation between regions in different Member States.
Cross-border cooperation
The regions to be supported for cross-border cooperation are the NUTS level 3 regions* of the European Union along all internal and external land borders other than those covered by programmes under the external financial instruments of the Union, and all NUTS level 3 regions of the Union along maritime borders separated by a maximum of 150 km.
The Commission adopts a decision, by means of implementing acts, setting out the list of cross-border areas to receive support, broken down by cooperation programme.
Transnational cooperation
The European territorial cooperation goal also covers transnational cooperation programmes, which aim to strengthen cooperation by means of actions conducive to integrated territorial development linked to the Union's cohesion policy priorities, and which also include maritime cross-border cooperation not covered by cross-border cooperation programmes.
Interregional cooperation
The European territorial cooperation goal also covers interregional cooperation programmes, which aim to reinforce the effectiveness of cohesion policy by developing and testing new approaches and good practices in the fields of territorial development and cooperation.
Resources for European territorial cooperation goal
The outermost regions* are allocated not less than 150 % of the ERDF support they received in the 2007-2013 programming period for cooperation programmes.
Each Member State receives an allocation from the ERDF, broken down by cooperation programme, for cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation. Member States may use the flexibility between the components of the European territorial cooperation goal, and are encouraged to allocate at least 80 % of their allocation to cross-border cooperation.
Thematic concentration and investment priorities
At least 80 % of the ERDF allocation to each cross-border cooperation and transnational cooperation programme must be concentrated on a maximum of four of the thematic objectives set out in the first paragraph of Article 9 of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013.
The ERDF must also support cooperation between the Union and its neighbouring third countries, including through specific arrangements, in order to offset the higher administrative costs.
Cooperation programmes
Cooperation programmes must:
set out the objectives of the cooperation programme;
set out the priority axes and their objectives;
set out the actions to be implemented;
set out the indicators to be used to measure the progress of implementation;
set out the management and control systems;
set out the arrangements for the involvement of partners.
Monitoring and evaluation
The managing authority must submit annual implementation reports to the Commission, which must include information on:
the implementation of the cooperation programme;
the progress in preparation and implementation of major projects and joint action plans.
The Commission must assess the implementation reports and, if necessary, decide on the need for an interim review meeting.
Indicators for the European territorial cooperation goal
For common and programme-specific output indicators, baselines must be set at zero.
Technical assistance
The amount of the ERDF allocated to technical assistance must be limited to 6 % of the total amount allocated to a cooperation programme.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 1 January 2014.
BACKGROUND
              
The European territorial cooperation goal covers cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation.
Cross-border cooperation aims to reduce disparities between the levels of development of the various regions and to reduce the backwardness of the least favoured regions, among which particular attention is to be paid to rural areas, areas affected by industrial transition, and regions which suffer from severe and permanent natural or demographic handicaps such as the northernmost regions with very low population density and island, cross-border and mountain regions.
Transnational cooperation aims to strengthen cooperation by means of actions conducive to integrated territorial development linked to the Union's cohesion policy priorities, and aims to also include maritime cross-border cooperation not covered by cross-border cooperation programmes.
Interregional cooperation aims to reinforce the effectiveness of cohesion policy by developing and testing new approaches and good practices in the fields of territorial development and cooperation.
For further information, please see the European Commission's website.
KEY TERMS
              
NUTS: Nomenclature of Territorial Units at the NUTS level 3.
Outermost regions: the Azores, Canary Islands, French Guiana, Guadeloupe, Réunion, Madeira and Martinique.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EU) No 1301/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1081/2006 (OJ L 347, 20.12.2013, pp. 804-884).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1085/2006 (OJ L 347, 20.12.2013, pp. 320-370).

Summary 159:
establishing a framework for the development of the trans-European transport network and its interconnection
SUMMARY
The Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) is a network of road, rail, inland waterway and maritime links that will cover the whole of the European Union (EU) territory. The Commission's priority is to develop the TEN-T network and its interconnections to improve transport links between the EU and neighbouring countries.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework for the development of the trans-European transport network and its interconnection in order to achieve the EU’s energy policy objectives of competitiveness, sustainability and security of supply.
KEY POINTS

North Sea–Baltic corridor (electricity and gas);

Southern Gas Corridor;
North Sea–Baltic Energy Connection (gas);
Baltic–Adriatic corridor (gas);
Cross-border carbon dioxide network;
LNG and gas storage infrastructure;
Electricity highways;
Smart grids.
The Commission establishes a list of projects of common interest, which are projects that are necessary to implement the priority corridors and areas for investment in transport infrastructure in the energy sector.
The regulation lays down rules for the application of the European energy network policy and sets out the procedures for the designation of European coordinators.
The regulation also provides for the establishment of a competent authority or authorities to coordinate the granting of permits for infrastructure projects.
The regulation also provides for the establishment of a competent authority or authorities to coordinate the granting of permits for infrastructure projects.

BACKGROUND
The European Commission's ‘Energy infrastructure priorities for 2020 and beyond — A Blueprint for an integrated European energy network’ communication of 2011 called for a new energy infrastructure policy to optimise network development at European level for the period up to 2020 and beyond, in order to allow the Union to meet its core energy policy objectives of competitiveness, sustainability and security of supply.
The Commission has identified 12 strategic trans-European energy infrastructure priorities, the implementation of which by 2020 is essential for the achievement of the Union's energy and climate policy objectives.
The European Council of 4 February 2011 underlined the need to modernise and expand Europe's energy infrastructure and to interconnect networks across borders, in order to make solidarity between Member States operational, to provide for alternative supply or transit routes and sources of energy and to develop renewable energy sources in competition with traditional sources.
The European Council of 18 June 2011 called for the development of the Trans-European Energy Networks (TEN-E) in order to contribute to the development of the internal market in energy and to the security of energy supply.
The European Council of 24-25 May 2012 called for a new European industrial policy, which includes a new energy infrastructure policy.

Summary 161:
2014-2020 direct payments: EU countries to get better value for their money
EU countries are to get better value for their money from direct payments to farmers from 2014 to 2020. The reform will ensure that the money goes to those farmers who need it most, while helping to protect the environment and rural areas.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rules for direct payments* to farmers under the common agricultural policy (CAP) from 1 January 2014 to 31 December 2020.
KEY POINTS
The reform of the CAP introduced in 2013 provides for a gradual reduction in direct payments and for the introduction of ‘greening’*, a new set of rules for farmers.
Direct payments
Direct payments are divided into 2 categories:
basic payments for farmers and
coupled support for young farmers, small farms and farms in less-favoured areas.
The basic payment scheme
Under the basic payment scheme, each farmer receives a flat rate for the area of his or her holding, regardless of the type of crops grown. This replaces the single payment scheme, which is abolished from 2014.
The basic payment scheme is a key instrument for the convergence of direct payments per hectare in the EU. It will be progressively adjusted to take account of the differences in the cost of production between Member States.
To ensure that the support is better targeted, Member States may decide not to grant direct payments to certain natural and legal persons unless such persons can demonstrate that their agricultural activity is not marginal.
EU countries may also decide to grant a reduction of direct payments to large beneficiaries. The proceeds of the reduction of payments to large beneficiaries are to be made available as support for rural development measures financed under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
The basic payment scheme is subject to certain conditions:
the payment is granted only to farmers who are active in farming;
the payment is granted only to farmers who are established in the EU;
the payment is granted only to farmers who have not exceeded the ceiling fixed by the EU country;
the payment is granted only to farmers who have not received payments from the EU or from the EU country from another support scheme;
the payment is granted only to farmers who have not exceeded the ceiling fixed by the EU country for young farmers, small farms or farms in less-favoured areas.
Young farmers, small farms and farms in less-favoured areas
Farmers who are young, small or in less-favoured areas receive a coupled support, which is based on the area of their holding. The support is calculated as a flat rate per hectare of eligible land.
The support for young farmers is granted only to farmers who are under 40 years old, who have received direct payments for the 2 preceding years and who have not received payments from the EU or from the EU country from another support scheme.
The support for small farms is granted only to farmers who are not young and who have received direct payments for the 2 preceding years and who have not received payments from the EU or from the EU country from another support scheme.
The support for farms in less-favoured areas is granted only to farmers who are not young or small and who have received direct payments for the 2 preceding years and who have not received payments from the EU or from the EU country from another support scheme.
EU countries may decide to grant a reduction of direct payments to large beneficiaries. The proceeds of the reduction of payments to large beneficiaries are to be made available as support for rural development measures financed under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.
EU countries may decide to transfer funds from their direct payments ceiling to their support assigned for rural development.
The EU country may decide to use part of its direct payments ceiling to grant an annual area-based payment, on top of the basic payment, to all farmers operating in areas with specific natural constraints.
EU countries may decide to use part of their direct payments ceiling to support the production of protein crops.
The EU country may decide to grant an annual area-based payment, on top of the basic payment, to all farmers operating in areas with specific natural constraints.
EU countries may decide to grant an annual area-based payment, on top of the basic payment, to all farmers operating in the following areas:
the outermost regions*;
the smaller Aegean islands*;
the mountainous regions*;
the islands*;
the regions suffering from serious difficulties*.

Summary 162:
specific support measures for the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EU) No 223/2013 on the common organisation of the agricultural markets and on specific provisions for sugar – promotion of the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It establishes a support programme for the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea (‘the smaller islands’) with the aim of promoting their agricultural sector.
KEY POINTS
The support programme aims to:
ensure continuity and development of local lines of agricultural production in the smaller islands;
mitigate the difficulties caused by the insularity, small size and distance from markets of the smaller islands;
ensure the supply of agricultural products and the preservation and development of local agricultural production.
The support programme includes the following measures:
specific supply arrangements for the smaller islands;
measures to assist local agricultural products;
accompanying measures.
Specific supply arrangements
Aid is granted to supply the smaller islands with agricultural products that are essential for human consumption, for the manufacture of other products or as agricultural inputs.
In the case of agricultural inputs and products intended for processing, such aid takes account of the additional costs associated with insularity, small size and distance from markets.
The specific supply arrangements apply only to products of sound, fair and marketable quality.
Measures to assist local agricultural products
The support programme contains the measures necessary to ensure continuity and development of local lines of agricultural production in the smaller islands.
The support programme contains the following actions:
studies, demonstration projects, training and technical assistance;
investment in the production, processing, marketing and transport of agricultural products;
preventing or reducing the effects of natural disasters and adverse climatic conditions;
introducing new products;
supporting the diversification of agricultural production;
assisting the processing, marketing and transport of products;
promoting the development of processing, marketing and transport facilities;
improving the competitiveness of the agricultural sector;
improving the environmental conditions of the agricultural sector;
improving the conditions of the agricultural sector in terms of hygiene, safety and welfare;
improving the conditions of the agricultural sector in terms of animal and plant health;
supporting the development of the rural economy;
improving the economic conditions of the agricultural sector;
supporting the development of the agricultural sector in the fields of research and development, innovation and training;
promoting the use of the common agricultural policy and other Union programmes.
The Commission adopts implementing acts concerning the requirements for the provision of the aid described in this chapter.
Accompanying measures
The support programme contains the following accompanying measures:
state aid;
additional financing.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 22 March 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The scheme promoting the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea was established by Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006. It has been implemented by means of a support programme, which constitutes an essential tool for supplying those islands with agricultural products and for supporting local agricultural production.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
The regulation applies from 22 March 2013.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EU) No 223/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 February 2013 on the common organisation of the agricultural markets and on specific provisions for sugar – promotion of the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea (OJ L 60, 6.3.2013, pp. 1-12).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
              
Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 September 2006 on the common organisation of the agricultural markets and on specific measures for sugar – promotion of the smaller islands of the Aegean Sea (OJ L 262, 6.10.2006, pp. 1-10).

Summary 163:
EU statistics on road haulage
EU statistics on road haulage
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the methods used by EU countries to collect and process data on the carriage of goods by road.
KEY POINTS
Scope
This regulation applies to the carriage of goods by road, whether in national, international or extra-EU traffic, using:
goods road transport vehicles registered in the EU;
goods road transport vehicles registered in a non-EU country that are used for international transport;
goods road transport vehicles registered in a non-EU country that are used for transport between that country and an EU country.
Exclusions
Goods road transport vehicles whose load capacity or maximum permissible weight is lower than a certain limit may be excluded from the scope of the regulation.
The regulation does not apply to:
goods road transport vehicles whose authorised weight or dimensions exceed the limits normally permitted in the EU country concerned;
agricultural vehicles, military vehicles and vehicles belonging to central or local public administrations, with the exception of goods road transport vehicles belonging to public undertakings, and in particular railway undertakings.
Definitions
For the purposes of the regulation, the following definitions apply:
‘carriage of goods by road’: all transport of goods by means of a goods road transport vehicle;
‘road transport vehicle’: a road vehicle fitted with an engine whence it derives its sole means of propulsion, which is normally used for carrying persons or goods by road, or for drawing, on the road, vehicles used for the carriage of persons or goods;
‘road vehicle for the transport of goods’: a road vehicle designed exclusively or primarily to carry goods (lorry, trailer or semi-trailer);
‘load capacity’: maximum weight of goods declared permissible by the competent authority of the country of registration of the vehicle.
Variables
EU countries must collect and process data on the following variables:
vehicle;
journey;
goods.
EU countries must provide Eurostat, the EU’s statistical agency, with information on the methods used in compiling statistical data.
EU countries must transmit to Eurostat individual data corresponding to the variables referred to above, without indicating the name, address or registration number.
EU countries must transmit statistical data relating to the carriage of goods by road to Eurostat every quarter.
Eurostat must disseminate the results within 12 months of the end of the period to which the results relate.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 23 February 2012.
BACKGROUND
              
Road haulage is one of the most important modes of transport in the EU. It plays a vital role in the economy, accounting for 75 % of the total distance travelled by freight vehicles in the EU.
KEY TERMS
              
Goods road transport vehicle
Road vehicle fitted with an engine whence it derives its sole means of propulsion, which is normally used for carrying persons or goods by road, or for drawing, on the road, vehicles used for the carriage of persons or goods.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Regulation (EC) No 1076/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 October 2012 on road infrastructure information systems and on administration and fiscal information systems, interoperability specifications (OJ L 293, 8.11.2012, pp. 1-8).
RELATED DOCUMENTS
            
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1096/2013 of 30 October 2013 on the transmission of statistical data relating to the carriage of goods by road (OJ L 299, 4.12.2013, pp. 1-7).
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) No 1095/2013 of 30 October 2013 on the dissemination of statistical results relating to the carriage of goods by road (OJ L 299, 4.12.2013, pp. 8-11).

Summary 164:
The service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in the EU
The service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in the EU
SUMMARY:
This Regulation establishes an area of freedom, security and justice in civil and commercial matters in the European Union (EU). It covers the service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in the EU.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a system for the transmission and service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in the EU. It provides for the transmission of judicial documents between the agencies designated by the EU Member States for this purpose. It also provides for the service of judicial documents in the Member States in which they are to be served.
KEY POINTS
The Regulation applies to the transmission and service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil and commercial matters between Member States. It does not apply to revenue, customs or administrative matters or to liability of the State for actions or omissions in the exercise of state authority (acta iure imperii).
The Regulation does not apply where the address of the person to be served with the document is not known.
Each Member State designates the public officers, authorities or other persons competent for the transmission of judicial or extrajudicial documents to be served in another Member State and those competent for the receipt of judicial or extrajudicial documents from another Member State.
The designation has effect for a period of 5 years and may be renewed at 5-year intervals.
Each Member State provides the European Commission with the following information:
the names and addresses of the receiving agencies;
the geographical areas in which they have jurisdiction;
the means of receipt of documents available to them; and
the languages that may be used for the completion of the standard form.
The Commission is notified of any subsequent modification of such information.
The Commission publishes the information communicated in the Official Journal of the European Union.
The Regulation provides for the transmission of judicial documents directly and as soon as possible between the agencies designated pursuant to Article 2.
The documents to be transmitted are accompanied by a standard form which is completed in the official language of the Member State addressed or in another language which that Member State has indicated it can accept.
The documents and all papers that are transmitted are exempted from legalisation or any equivalent formality.
The applicant is advised by the transmitting agency to which he forwards the document for transmission that the addressee may refuse to accept it if it is not in one of the languages provided for in Article 8.
The applicant bears any costs of translation prior to the transmission of the document.
On receipt of a document, a receiving agency sends, as soon as possible and in any event within 7 days of receipt, a receipt to the transmitting agency by the swiftest possible means of transmission using the standard form set out in Annex I.
If the request for service cannot be fulfilled on the basis of the information or documents transmitted, the receiving agency contacts the transmitting agency by the swiftest possible means in order to secure the missing information or documents.
If the request for service is manifestly outside the scope of the Regulation or if non-compliance with the formal conditions required makes service impossible, the request and the documents transmitted are returned, on receipt, to the transmitting agency, together with the notice of return using the standard form set out in Annex I.
A receiving agency receiving a document for service but not having territorial jurisdiction to serve it forwards it, as well as the request, to the receiving agency having territorial jurisdiction in the same Member State if the request complies with the conditions laid down in Article 4(3) and informs the transmitting agency accordingly using the standard form set out in Annex I. That receiving agency informs the transmitting agency when it receives the document, in the manner provided for in paragraph 1.
The receiving agency serves the document or has it served either in accordance with the law of the Member State addressed or by a particular method requested by the transmitting agency, unless that method is incompatible with the law of that Member State.
The receiving agency takes all necessary steps to effect the service of the document as soon as possible, and in any event within 1 month of receipt.
The receiving agency informs the addressee that he may refuse to accept the document at the time of service or by returning the document to the receiving agency within 1 week if it is not either in a language which he understands or in the official language or one of the official languages of the place of service. This rule also applies to service by diplomatic or consular agents, service by postal services and direct service. It is established that the service of the refused document can be remedied through the service on the addressee of a translation of the document.
The receiving agency continues to take all necessary steps to effect the service of the document also in cases where it has not been possible to effect service within the month, for example, because the defendant has been away from his home on holiday or away from his office on business.

Summary 165:
Regulation on advanced therapy medicinal products
SUMMARY OF:
Regulation (EC) No 1394/2007 on advanced therapy medicinal products
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It lays down rules for the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs).
KEY POINTS
Advanced therapy medicinal products (ATMPs) are products which are intended to be used for the diagnosis, prevention, treatment or alleviation of a serious disease or serious injury, and which are produced using human or animal cells or tissues, or combining human or animal cells or tissues with non-human biological substances.
They include:
gene therapy medicinal products;
somatic cell therapy medicinal products;
tissue engineered products.
The definition of ATMPs is set out in Article 2 of the regulation.
The regulation defines the conditions and procedures for the authorisation, supervision and pharmacovigilance of ATMPs. It also defines the conditions for the donation, procurement, testing, processing, preservation, storage and distribution of human cells and tissues used in ATMPs.
The regulation provides for a number of exemptions, in particular for ATMPs used in the course of a hospital care activity.
The regulation provides for a harmonised authorisation procedure for ATMPs, which is based on the procedure laid down in Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
The regulation provides for a procedure for the evaluation of the quality, safety and efficacy of ATMPs, which is based on the procedure laid down in Regulation (EC) No 726/2004.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 30 December 2008.

Summary 166:
emission standards for vehicles
The European Union (EU) has adopted new emission standards for cars and light commercial vehicles. The aim is to reduce emissions of pollutants from road vehicles and to improve the environment.
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out common technical requirements for the type approval of motor vehicles (vehicles) and replacement parts, such as replacement pollution control devices, with regard to their emissions.
It lays down rules for in-service conformity, durability of pollution control devices, on-board diagnostic (OBD) systems, measurement of fuel consumption and accessibility of vehicle repair and maintenance information.
KEY POINTS
Emissions
The regulation sets out emission limits for the main pollutants emitted by vehicles, namely carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter and methane. These limits, referred to as Euro standards, are set out in Annex I to the regulation.
The regulation introduces separate limit values for total hydrocarbons and total non-methane hydrocarbons.
The regulation also sets out emission limits for the evaporative emissions of hydrocarbons and for low ambient temperature emissions.
In-service conformity
Manufacturers are required to ensure that vehicles comply with the emission limits set out in Annex I. They are also required to ensure that the pollution control devices are durable, i.e. they are able to meet the emission limits for the duration of the vehicle's life.
The regulation sets out specific requirements for in-service conformity, including a 5-year or 100 000 km in-service conformity check, as well as a 160 000 km durability test.
OBD systems
Manufacturers are required to equip vehicles with an OBD system. The regulation sets out the requirements for OBD systems, including the type of information that they must provide.
Accessibility of vehicle repair and maintenance information
Manufacturers are required to make vehicle repair and maintenance information available to authorised dealers and repairers. The regulation sets out the requirements for the information to be provided and the format in which it is to be provided.
The regulation also sets out the fees that may be charged for access to vehicle repair and maintenance information.
Replacement pollution control devices
Manufacturers are required to ensure that replacement pollution control devices meet the emission limits set out in Annex I. The regulation sets out the procedures for type approval of replacement pollution control devices.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 3 January 2009, with the exception of Articles 10(1) and 12 which apply from 2 July 2007.
KEY WORDS
Regulation (EC) No 715/2007
Euro 5
Euro 6
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2007 on type-approval of heavy work vehicles (HCV) and standardised exhaust emissions values for the assessment of type-approval requirements for those vehicles (OJ L 163, 22.6.2007, pp. 6-16).
Successive amendments to Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 have been incorporated into the basic text.
RELATED DOCUMENTS

Summary 167:
EU procedure for assessing and authorising food additives, enzymes and flavourings
EU procedure for assessing and authorising food additives, enzymes and flavourings
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It establishes a common procedure for the assessment and authorisation of food additives, enzymes and flavourings in the European Union (EU).
KEY POINTS
This regulation sets out the stages of the procedure for updating the list of authorised substances and the role of the parties involved.
The European Commission (the EU’s executive body) sets up the procedure and, where necessary, seeks the opinion of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA).
The EFSA provides an independent scientific assessment of the risks that the substances pose to human health.
The Commission then takes a risk management decision based on the opinion of the EFSA and other legitimate factors relevant to the matter under consideration.
The Commission publishes a list of authorised substances.
The procedure can be started either by the Commission or following an application by an interested party.
The Commission informs the Member States and, where applicable, requests the opinion of the EFSA.
The EFSA delivers its opinion within 9 months of receipt of a valid application.
If the EFSA requests additional information, the procedure may be extended.
The Commission submits a draft regulation to the Committee for Food Safety, which then takes a decision within 24 months.
The Commission may decide not to proceed with a planned update if it judges that such an update is not justified.
The Commission updates the list of authorised substances.
The Commission may request additional information on risk management issues from applicants.
The Commission decides whether the information provided is sufficient and whether it should proceed with the update.
The Commission may decide not to proceed with the update.
The Commission publishes the list of authorised substances.
The procedure ends with the adoption of a regulation updating the list of authorised substances.
The Commission may decide not to proceed with a planned update if it judges that such an update is not justified.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 January 2009.
BACKGROUND
This regulation complements the sectoral food laws on food additives, enzymes and flavourings, which establish the criteria for authorising these substances.
It completes the regulatory framework concerning the authorisation of the substances by laying down the stages of the procedure, the deadlines for those stages, the role of the parties involved and the principles that apply.
