Summary 168:
accreditation and market surveillance of products
SUMMARY
This Regulation sets out a comprehensive framework for accreditation and market surveillance of products.
It lays down the principles for the operation and organisation of accreditation and market surveillance activities in the European Union (EU).
What does the Regulation say?
The Regulation lays down the principles for the operation and organisation of accreditation and market surveillance activities in the EU.
It defines the terms used in the Regulation.
It sets out the tasks of national accreditation bodies.
It lays down the rules for the organisation of border controls and market surveillance.
It establishes the principles of the CE marking.
It sets out the conditions for EU financing of activities carried out by the European Accreditation for Accreditation (the EA) and by the competent authorities of the EU countries.
When does the Regulation apply?
It applies from 1 January 2010.
WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION?
It aims to ensure a high level of protection of health and safety and of the environment, and a high level of confidence in products placed on the market.
KEY POINTS
Accreditation
The Regulation defines the term ‘accreditation’ as an attestation by a national accreditation body that a conformity assessment body meets the requirements set by harmonised standards and, where applicable, any additional requirements including those set out in relevant sectoral schemes, to carry out a specific conformity assessment activity.
National accreditation bodies
The Regulation lays down the tasks of national accreditation bodies, which are to:
appoint a single national accreditation body;
ensure that the national accreditation body is a not-for-profit body;
have in place the necessary procedures to deal with complaints against the conformity assessment bodies they have accredited;
subject themselves to peer evaluation organised by the body recognised under Article 14;
accept, on the basis of the presumption of conformity, the accreditation certificates of those bodies and the attestations issued by the conformity assessment bodies accredited by them;
inform the Commission and the other EU countries of the identity of their national accreditation body and of any changes thereto;
accept requests from other EU countries and the Commission for the accreditation of conformity assessment bodies in respect of specific conformity assessment activities;
inform the Commission and the other EU countries of all conformity assessment activities in respect of which they operate accreditation in support of EU harmonisation legislation.
Border controls and market surveillance
The Regulation establishes the rules for the organisation of border controls and market surveillance.
It defines the term ‘market surveillance’ as the activities carried out by competent authorities to ensure that products covered by EU harmonisation legislation which, when used in accordance with their intended purpose or under conditions which can be reasonably foreseen and when properly installed and maintained, are liable to compromise the health or safety of users, or which otherwise do not conform to applicable requirements set out in EU harmonisation legislation, are withdrawn or their being made available on the market is prohibited or restricted.
It lays down the obligations of the EU countries in respect of the organisation of border controls and market surveillance.
It establishes the principles of the CE marking.
It sets out the conditions for EU financing of activities carried out by the European Accreditation for Accreditation (the EA) and by the competent authorities of the EU countries.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 1 January 2010.
BACKGROUND
This Regulation lays down a comprehensive framework for accreditation and market surveillance of products.
It aims to ensure a high level of protection of health and safety and of the environment, and a high level of confidence in products placed on the market.
For further information, please see the European Commission’s website on conformity assessment and market surveillance.
REFERENCES
              
Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 13 July 2008 setting out the requirements for accreditation and market surveillance analyses and tests.
Council Directive 93/95/EEC of 23 November 1993 on the uniformity of the conditions for accreditation of conformity assessment bodies in the European Union and the European Free Trade Association.
RELATED ACTS
Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 is repealed by Regulation (EU) 2017/625 on veterinary checks and veterinary rules on animals imported into the EU.
Council Directive 93/95/EEC is repealed by Directive 2014/30/EU on harmonisation of laws relating to electromagnetic compatibility and Directive 2014/30/EU on harmonisation of laws relating to the marketing of products.

Summary 169:
Agreement on the surrender of persons between the EU and Iceland and Norway
The European Union (EU) and Iceland and Norway have agreed on the surrender of persons for the purposes of prosecution or execution of sentence between them.
WHAT DOES THIS AGREEMENT DO?
It establishes an extradition system between the EU and Iceland and Norway.
It covers all offences that are punishable by deprivation of liberty for a period of at least one year or by a penalty involving deprivation of liberty and a monetary penalty imposed together.
It does not cover offences that are punishable by a maximum penalty of less than 6 months imprisonment or by a monetary penalty.
KEY POINTS
The agreement provides for the surrender of persons between the EU and Iceland and Norway. It is based on a mechanism of surrender pursuant to an arrest warrant in accordance with the terms of this agreement.
It does not have the effect of modifying the obligation to respect fundamental rights and fundamental legal principles as enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, or, in the case of execution by the judicial authority of an EU Member State, of the principles referred to in Article 6 of the Treaty on European Union.
The agreement covers the following areas:
definition of terms;
conditions for surrender;
execution of the arrest warrant;
situations pending the decision;
rights of the person being surrendered;
consequences of surrender.
The agreement is applicable to Iceland and Norway and to the EU and its Member States.
The agreement is applicable to all offences which are punishable by deprivation of liberty for a period of at least one year or by a penalty involving deprivation of liberty and a monetary penalty imposed together.
It does not cover offences that are punishable by a maximum penalty of less than 6 months imprisonment or by a monetary penalty.
The agreement does not cover offences that constitute a political offence or an offence connected with a political offence or an offence inspired by political motives.
The agreement does not cover military offences or service offences.
The agreement does not cover offences that constitute an offence against the security of a State or offences of a like kind to those offences.
The agreement does not cover offences that constitute an offence against the fiscal, trade or customs legislation of a State or offences of a like kind to those offences.
The agreement does not cover offences that constitute an act of terrorism.

The agreement does not cover offences that constitute an infringement of environmental protection legislation.
The agreement does not cover offences that constitute an infringement of legislation protecting intellectual, industrial, commercial or professional property.

Summary 170:
Passenger rights in transport by rail
SUMMARY
The aim of this regulation is to ensure a high level of protection for passengers travelling by rail throughout the European Union (EU).
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out minimum service quality standards for rail passengers, including:
—
the right to be provided with adequate information about the rail service;
—
the right to be provided with a ticket or reservation;
—
the right to be provided with compensation in the event of delay or cancellation;
—
the right to be provided with assistance for disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility;
—
the right to be provided with compensation in the event of death or injury.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all rail journeys and services throughout the EU provided by one or more railway undertakings licensed in accordance with Directive 95/18/EC.
Railway undertakings must:
—
offer tickets or reservations for journeys;
—
provide information about the rail service;
—
provide compensation in the event of delay or cancellation;
—
provide assistance for disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility;
—
provide compensation in the event of death or injury;
—
provide information about the right of passengers to make complaints and how to submit them;
—
provide information about service quality standards.
Railway undertakings must ensure that:
—
tickets are available for purchase without undue difficulty;
—
passengers have access to travel by rail;
—
disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility have access to travel by rail;
—
passengers are provided with compensation in the event of delay or cancellation;
—
passengers are provided with compensation in the event of death or injury;
—
passengers are provided with assistance for disabled persons or persons with reduced mobility;
—
passengers are provided with information about the right of passengers to make complaints and how to submit them;
—
passengers are provided with information about service quality standards.
Railway undertakings must take into account the needs of disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility through compliance with the technical specifications for interoperability (TSI) for persons with reduced mobility, so as to ensure that, in accordance with Community public procurement rules, all buildings and rolling stock are made accessible through the progressive elimination of physical obstacles and functional hindrances when acquiring new material or carrying out construction or major renovation work.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend the annexes to this regulation, except Annex I, in order to take account of technical progress relating to rail passenger services or to adapt them to changes in the market or to the effects on service quality of this regulation.
The Commission is also empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend Annex II to this regulation in order to adjust the financial amounts provided for therein for inflation.
The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend Annex III to this regulation in order to take account of changes in the service quality standards provided for therein.
The regulation does not apply to certain journeys operated by railway undertakings in certain Member States, in particular journeys operated under public service contracts. The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend Annex II to this regulation in order to include the financial amounts provided for therein for journeys operated under public service contracts in certain Member States.
The regulation does not apply to journeys operated by urban, suburban and regional rail passenger services in certain Member States. The Commission is empowered to adopt delegated acts to amend Annex II to this regulation in order to include the financial amounts provided for therein for journeys operated by urban, suburban and regional rail passenger services in certain Member States.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 13 December 2010.
BACKGROUND
Rail passenger services are an important part of the transport system in the EU. This regulation aims to ensure that rail passengers receive the same level of protection throughout the EU.
For more information, please see the European Commission's website on passenger rights in transport.
KEY TERMS
              
Railway undertaking: a railway undertaking as defined in Article 2 of Directive 2001/14/EC (on the trans-European rail network).

Summary 171:
EU statistics on education and training
EUROSTAT is responsible for producing statistics on education and training in the EU. These statistics cover education and training systems, the participation of adults in lifelong learning and other statistics on education and lifelong learning.
EUROSTAT is responsible for producing statistics on education and training in the EU. These statistics cover education and training systems, the participation of adults in lifelong learning and other statistics on education and lifelong learning.
ACT
Regulation (EC) No 448/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 July 2008 on the annual accounts and balance sheets of the European Investment Bank.
SUMMARY
What does this Regulation do?
It establishes a common framework for the production of EU statistics on education and lifelong learning. These statistics cover education and training systems, the participation of adults in lifelong learning and other statistics on education and lifelong learning.
These statistics are intended to support policy-making and monitoring of progress in the implementation of EU policies in the fields of education and lifelong learning.
When applying this Regulation, account should be taken of the notion of people at a disadvantage in the labour market referred to in the Guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States.
What does the Regulation cover?
The Regulation applies to the production of statistics in three domains:
Domain 1 covers statistics on education and training systems;
Domain 2 covers statistics on the participation of adults in lifelong learning;
Domain 3 covers other statistics on education and lifelong learning, such as statistics on human capital and on the social and economic benefits of education, not covered by Domains 1 and 2.
The production of statistics in those domains is carried out in accordance with the Annex to the Regulation.
Available capacities within the Member States for data collection and the processing and development of concepts and methods are taken into account by the Commission.
Where appropriate, data are systematically broken down by gender.
KEY TERMS
Domain
Subject matter covered by a particular piece of legislation.
MAIN DOCUMENTS
Regulation (EC) No 448/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 July 2008 on the annual accounts and balance sheets of the European Investment Bank.

Summary 173:
rights of bus and coach passengers
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the rights of bus and coach passengers in the EU. It establishes minimum standards for the protection of bus and coach passengers in the EU and ensures that they are not discriminated against.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to all bus and coach services where the initial boarding point or the final alighting point of the passenger is situated in the territory of a Member State.
The regulation covers:
transport services operated by regular transport;
transport services operated by occasional transport;
transport services operated by special transport.
The regulation does not apply to certain services such as:
services which are not available to the general public;
services which are organised on a non-commercial basis;
services operated by vehicles which are exempt from vehicle tax.
The regulation does not apply to certain vehicles such as:
buses and coaches used for the carriage of goods;
buses and coaches used exclusively for the carriage of children to and from school or other educational establishments;
buses and coaches used exclusively for the carriage of patients to and from hospital or other health establishments;
buses and coaches used exclusively for the carriage of prisoners;
buses and coaches used exclusively for the carriage of police, gendarmerie or military personnel.
The regulation does not apply to certain vehicles which are exempt from vehicle tax.
The regulation does not apply to certain services which are exempt from the application of the regulation.
The regulation does not apply to certain vehicles which are exempt from the application of the regulation.
Passengers have the right to:
a ticket;
non-discriminatory contract conditions;
compensation and assistance in the event of accidents;
rights of disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility;
rights in the event of cancellation or delay;
information and complaints;
enforcement and national enforcement bodies.
Carriers must issue a ticket to the passenger, unless other documents give entitlement to transport.
Carriers must offer passengers non-discriminatory contract conditions and tariffs.
Carriers must offer passengers compensation in the event of death, personal injury or loss of or damage to luggage due to accidents arising out of the use of the bus or coach.
Carriers must offer disabled persons and persons with reduced mobility the right to transport.
Carriers must offer passengers the right to continue their journey, to be rerouted or to have their tickets reimbursed in the event of cancellation or significant delay of their journey.
Carriers must offer passengers the right to assistance at designated terminals and on board buses and coaches.
Carriers must offer passengers the right to receive information on their journey before and during the journey.
Carriers must offer passengers the right to submit complaints.
Member States must ensure that carriers comply with the regulation.
Member States must designate a competent body or bodies to carry out supervision and enforcement tasks.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 3 December 2013.
BACKGROUND
              
The regulation is part of the EU’s transport policy and aims to improve the rights of bus and coach passengers in the EU.
For more information, please see the European Commission’s website on bus and coach passengers.
MAIN DOCUMENT

Summary 174:
EU statistics on the aquaculture sector
EU countries must collect, process and publish statistics on the aquaculture sector. The statistics cover:
the production of aquaculture;
the input to capture-based aquaculture;
the production of hatcheries and nurseries;
the structure of the sector.
Production
EU countries must collect statistics on the annual production of aquaculture, i.e. the output from aquaculture at first sale, including production from hatcheries and nurseries offered for sale. They must also collect data on the input to capture-based aquaculture.
Production of hatcheries and nurseries
EU countries must collect statistics on the production of hatcheries and nurseries, i.e. places for the artificial breeding, hatching and rearing through the early life stages of aquatic animals.
Structure of the sector
EU countries must collect data on the structure of the aquaculture sector, including:
the number of facilities;
the size of the facilities;
the species grown;
the method of production;
the type of water used (freshwater or saltwater).
EU countries must submit these data to the European Commission (Eurostat) within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year.
What data are collected?
The data collected include:
the annual production (volume and unit value) of aquaculture;
the annual input (volume and unit value) to capture-based aquaculture;
the annual production of hatcheries and nurseries;
the structure of the aquaculture sector.
When are these data collected?
EU countries must submit the data referred to in Annexes II, III and IV to the Commission (Eurostat) within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year. The first reference calendar year shall be 2008.
Starting with the data for the year 2008 and at intervals of three years thereafter, the data on the structure of the aquaculture sector referred to in Annex V shall be submitted within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year to the Commission (Eurostat).
What are the deadlines for submitting the data?
The first data must be submitted by 31 December 2009.
Regulation (EC) No 1898/2005 repeals Regulation (EC) No 788/96. EU countries must continue to apply the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 788/96 for the duration of the transitional period granted.
What does the regulation say?
The regulation requires EU countries to collect, process and publish statistics on the aquaculture sector.
EU countries must submit the data to the Commission (Eurostat) within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year.
Starting with the data for the year 2008 and at intervals of three years thereafter, the data on the structure of the aquaculture sector referred to in Annex V shall be submitted within 12 months of the end of the reference calendar year to the Commission (Eurostat).
Regulation (EC) No 1898/2005 repeals Regulation (EC) No 788/96. EU countries must continue to apply the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 788/96 for the duration of the transitional period granted.

Summary 175:
control scheme for fishing vessels in the Convention Area
SUMMARY
The North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC) adopted a scheme of control and enforcement applicable to fishing vessels operating in the Convention Area which lies beyond the waters under the fisheries jurisdiction of the Contracting Parties (the Regulatory Area). The scheme provides for control and enforcement measures applicable to vessels flying the flag of Contracting Parties and operating in the Regulatory Area, and arrangements for inspection at sea which include inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures which must be implemented by the Contracting Parties.
The scheme also comprises provisions to promote compliance by vessels flying the flag of a non-Contracting Party with the control and enforcement measures in order to ensure full respect of conservation and management measures adopted by NEAFC. The Regulation incorporates the NEAFC scheme into Union law.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The Regulation applies to:
the landing or transhipment of fishery resources frozen after being caught in the Convention Area by fishing vessels flying the flag of another Contracting Party;
fishing vessels flying the flag of a non-Contracting Party used or intended for use for fishing activities carried out in respect of fishery resources in the Convention Area;
EU fishing vessels and fishing vessels flying the flag of another Contracting Party used or intended for use for fishing activities carried out in respect of fishery resources in the Convention Area.
Monitoring measures
The Commission must be informed by the end of each year of the vessels authorised to fish in the Regulatory Area, as well as any subsequent amendments. It must forward this information to the NEAFC Secretary.
Vessels flying the flag of a Member State must carry on board:
a valid fishing licence;
a fishing logbook or an electronic logbook;
a valid catch certificate.
EU vessels may only engage in transhipment operations or joint fishing operations with vessels flying the flag of a Contracting Party and vessels of a non-Contracting Party granted the status of a cooperating non-Contracting Party by NEAFC.
Inspections at sea
NEAFC inspectors may board a fishing vessel flying the flag of a Contracting Party at any time, day or night, and without prior notice being given to the vessel. The vessel must provide the inspectors with any assistance which is required. The duration of an inspection must not exceed 4 hours, or the time it takes to haul in the net and to inspect the net and the catch, whichever is longer.
The Commission or the body designated by it must send to the NEAFC Secretary before 1 January each year details of the plan, including the names of the NEAFC inspectors and special inspection vessels as well as the types of aircraft and their identification details (registration number, name, radio call-sign) which Member States are assigning to the Scheme during that year.
Port state control of fishing vessels flying the flag of another Contracting Party
Member States must designate and notify the Commission of ports where the landing or transhipment of fishery resources frozen after being caught in the Convention Area by fishing vessels flying the flag of another Contracting Party are permitted.
When the master of a fishing vessel carrying fish intends to call into a port to land or tranship fish, he must notify the competent authorities of the Member State of the port he wishes to use no later than three working days before the estimated time of arrival.
Landing or transhipment operations may only start after authorisation has been given by the competent authorities of the port Member State. Such authorisation shall only be given if the confirmation from the flag state has been received.
Each Member State must carry out inspections of at least 15 % of landings or transhipments in its ports during each reporting year.
Infringements
The Regulation applies to EU fishing vessels and to fishing vessels flying the flag of another Contracting Party used or intended for use for fishing activities carried out in respect of fishery resources in the Convention Area.
The Commission or the body designated by it must forward the information to the NEAFC Secretary.
Reporting and follow-up of infringements
The Commission or the body designated by it must compile a Union report on the basis of the reports of the Member States.
Reporting of non-Contracting Parties’ activities
The Commission or the body designated by it must send a global report on non-Contracting Parties’ activities to the NEAFC Secretary by 1 March each year.
Confidentiality
The Commission or the body designated by it may grant access to the inspectors to the databases, registers and other information held by the Commission or the body designated by it, or by the Member States, which are relevant for the purpose of carrying out the inspection and surveillance procedures, provided that such access is granted on a case-by-case basis and that the confidentiality of the information is preserved.
The Commission or the body designated by it may grant access to the inspectors to the databases, registers and other information held by the Commission or the body designated by it, or by the Member States, which are relevant for the purpose of carrying out the inspection and surveillance procedures, provided that such access is granted on a case-by-case basis and that the confidentiality of the information is preserved.

Summary 176:
Ecolabel for environmentally friendly products
The EU Ecolabel is a voluntary scheme that aims to encourage the marketing of products and services that are environmentally friendly throughout their life cycle. It is awarded to products and services that have a high level of environmental performance, verified by an independent body.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It establishes a framework for the EU Ecolabel scheme, which is intended to promote products and services that have a high level of environmental performance.
It sets out the conditions under which the EU Ecolabel may be used, in particular the conditions for the award of the label and the market surveillance and control of its use.
KEY POINTS
Scope
The EU Ecolabel scheme covers products and services that are supplied for distribution, consumption or use in the EU, whether in return for payment or free of charge.
It does not apply to medicinal products for human use or for veterinary use, or to any type of medical device.
Criteria
EU Ecolabel criteria are based on the environmental performance of products, taking into account the latest strategic objectives of the EU in the field of the environment.
In determining such criteria, the following are considered:
the most significant environmental impacts, in particular the impact on climate change, the impact on nature and biodiversity, energy and resource consumption, generation of waste, emissions to all environmental media, pollution through physical effects and use and release of hazardous substances;
the substitution of hazardous substances by safer substances, as such or via the use of other substances.
EU Ecolabel criteria include requirements intended to ensure that the products bearing the EU Ecolabel function adequately in accordance with their intended use.
The Commission decides, taking into account the outcome of a study and the opinion of the European Union Ecolabelling Board (EUEB), for which group of food and feed, if any, the development of EU Ecolabel criteria is feasible.
Development and revision of EU Ecolabel criteria
The EUEB may initiate and lead the development or revision of EU Ecolabel criteria. In this regard, consortiums consisting of more than one interest group are favoured.
The party which initiates and leads the development or revision of EU Ecolabel criteria produces the following documents:
a preliminary report;
a proposal for draft criteria;
a technical report in support of the proposal for draft criteria;
a final report;
a manual for potential users of the EU Ecolabel and competent bodies;
a manual for authorities awarding public contracts.
The Commission decides, taking into account the outcome of the study and the opinion of the EUEB, for which group of food and feed, if any, the development of EU Ecolabel criteria is feasible.
Award of the EU Ecolabel and terms and conditions of its use
The EU Ecolabel may be awarded by a competent body to a product or service only if it complies with the relevant EU Ecolabel criteria and the assessment requirements.
To be awarded the EU Ecolabel, the product or service must first be registered. The competent body may reject the application if the operator fails to complete the documentation within 6 months after such notification.
If the product complies with the EU Ecolabel criteria and the assessment requirements, the competent body shall assign a registration number to the product. The operator may place the EU Ecolabel on the product only after conclusion of the contract.
The EU Ecolabel may be used on the products for which the EU Ecolabel has been awarded and on their associated promotional material.
The right to use the EU Ecolabel does not extend to the use of the EU Ecolabel as a component of a trademark.
Market surveillance and control of the use of the EU Ecolabel
The competent body shall, as appropriate, undertake on-site verifications or assign an authorised agent for that purpose.
The user of the EU Ecolabel shall allow the competent body which has awarded the EU Ecolabel to the product to undertake all necessary investigations to monitor its on-going compliance with the product group criteria and Article 9.
Where, after giving the user of the EU Ecolabel the opportunity to submit observations, any competent body finds that a product bearing the EU Ecolabel does not comply with the relevant product group criteria or that the EU Ecolabel is not used in accordance with Article 9, it shall either prohibit the use of the EU Ecolabel on that product, or, in the event that the EU Ecolabel has been awarded by another competent body, it shall inform that competent body.
The competent body shall without delay inform all other competent bodies and the Commission of that prohibition.
Ecolabelling schemes in the Member States
In order to harmonise the criteria of European ecolabelling schemes (EN ISO 14024 type I), EU Ecolabel criteria shall also take into account existing criteria developed in officially recognised ecolabelling schemes in the Member States.
Promotion of the EU Ecolabel
The Commission shall promote the EU Ecolabel via the EU Ecolabel website providing basic information and promotional materials on the EU Ecolabel, and information on where to purchase EU Ecolabel products, in all EU languages.
Exchange of information and experiences
In order to foster consistent implementation of this Regulation, competent bodies shall regularly exchange information and experiences, in particular on the application of Articles 9 and 10.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 3 July 2013.
BACKGROUND
The EU Ecolabel scheme was first established in 1992. In 2009, the Commission launched a public consultation on the EU Ecolabel scheme and on the revision of Regulation (EC) No 1980/2000.
In 2011, the Commission adopted a communication on a Roadmap for Sustainable Chemicals and a legislative proposal on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) amendment regulation.
The aim of the amendment was to address the lack of information on the risks of certain substances, to improve the functioning of the authorisation and restriction processes, and to ensure a better functioning of the process of authorisation and restriction of certain substances. It was also intended to improve the functioning of the process of registration of substances and the evaluation of their effects on human health and the environment.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It applies from 3 July 2013.
KEY TERMS
              
EU Ecolabel: a label awarded by an independent body to products and services that have a high level of environmental performance, verified by an independent body.
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Commission Regulation (EU) No 66/2013 of 7 March 2013 establishing the framework for the assessment of the environmental performance of products and organisations. OJ L 99, 15.4.2013, pp. 24-45.
RELATED DOCUMENTS
            
Commission Regulation (EC) No 1980/2000 of 17 July 2000 on a common EU Ecolabel award scheme for environmental excellence (OJ L 194, 18.8.2000, pp. 30-36).

Summary 177:
supplementary protection certificates for medicines
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THIS REGULATION DO?
It sets out the conditions for granting a supplementary protection certificate (SPC) for medicines.
WHEN DOES THIS REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 May 2009.
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION COVER?
It covers medicines protected by a patent or similar protection.
It does not cover plant protection products.
It does not cover medicines that have been authorised in the EU before 1 January 1985.
KEY POINTS
The regulation sets out the conditions for granting a certificate and the conditions for extending its duration.
An SPC is granted in each EU country where the basic patent is valid.
A holder of a patent or similar protection may apply for a certificate within 6 months of the date the EU authorises the medicine for sale.
The certificate is valid for 5 years after the patent expires.
The certificate covers the medicine that has been authorised for sale in the EU.
The certificate covers the medicine that has been authorised for sale in the EU.
It is valid in all EU countries.
It is not transferable.
The certificate is granted by the industrial property office in the EU country where the patent was granted.
The holder of the certificate may apply for an extension of its duration.
The duration of the certificate is limited to 15 years.
It is valid in all EU countries.
It is not transferable.
The certificate may be revoked or lapse in certain circumstances.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
It applies from 20 May 2009.
BACKGROUND
The regulation codifies Regulation (EEC) No 1768/92, which has been amended several times since it was adopted in 1992.
It was adopted on 23 April 2009.
For more information, see the European Commission website on SPCs.
KEY TERMS
Basic patent: the patent that covers the medicine.
Supplementary protection certificate (SPC): a certificate that extends the protection granted by the patent for up to 5 years.
MAIN DOCUMENT
Regulation (EC) No 469/2004 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2004 concerning the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Economic Community and the Swiss Confederation (OJ L 163, 30.4.2004, pp. 0001-0010).

Summary 178:
Brussels I Regulation (EC No 44/2001)
Brussels I Regulation (EC No 44/2001)
SUMMARY
WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO?
It lays down the rules for determining the jurisdiction of a court in another EU country.
KEY POINTS
The regulation applies to civil and commercial matters. It does not apply to criminal matters or revenue, customs or administrative matters.
The regulation sets out the rules for determining the jurisdiction of the courts of the EU countries in civil and commercial matters.
It provides that a person domiciled in an EU country may be sued in the courts of that country, whatever their nationality. The regulation defines the term 'domicile' and sets out the rules for determining the place of domicile of natural persons and legal persons.
The regulation also sets out the rules for determining the jurisdiction of the courts of EU countries in certain specific situations.
The regulation provides that, in certain cases, a person may be sued in the courts of an EU country other than the one where he/she is domiciled.
The regulation sets out the rules for the recognition and enforcement of judgments.
The regulation contains certain provisions on provisional, including protective, measures.
The regulation provides for the possibility of contracting out of certain provisions of the regulation.
The regulation provides for the possibility of contracting out of certain provisions of the regulation between EU countries.
The regulation provides for certain exceptions and special rules for Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom.
FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY?
              
It has applied since 2002.
KEY WORDS:
              
Court
Domicile
Jurisdiction
MAIN DOCUMENT
            
Council Regulation (EC) No 44/2001 of 28 January 2001 on the standing of judgments in civil and commercial matters (OJ C 302, 30.9.2005, pp. 0001-0023).
